What is Carbon Deed?

We are a Finnish forest startup on the mission to allow all of us a more sustainable way of life by offering a way to compensate for your CO₂ emissions with ease. We provide permanent carbon removal (also known as carbon farming) services to individuals and companies by growing forest efficiently.

Be aware, we are not an industrial foresting company and we do not grow our forests for economic purposes. Our target is to maximize CO₂ absorption of forests, while also cultivating biodiversity and natural life. This means we only plant trees to unused land and will grow the trees for as long as possible.

For the time being forests are the only globally recognized feasible method of carbon removal at a large scale. Forests are not only very efficient at capturing CO₂, but the results are also measurable and verifiable.

Finland has the highest forest to land ratio in the world, and also the biggest forest companies, thus it is an ideal place for founding a forest-technology start-up. Prior to founding Carbon Deed we’ve received support from some of the most knowledgeable forestation experts in the world (e.g. University of Helsinki and the Forestation administrative of Finland). We have fine-tuned our approach based on these discussions and validated our Carbon farming business plan. The amount of support and the involvement of experts will expand as we progress with Carbon Deed.
Our process is very simple and we do all of this ourselves: ​

We buy unused land in Finland, for example old farm land. We plant it with trees and make sure they grow as fast as possible. Each tree is given a unique tree identifier (UTI) by which all trees are linked to contributors. When the trees start growing, we measure their CO₂ absorption.
The Project
Goal of the Indiegogo campaign:
To plant the first trees and reach a broader audience with Carbon Deed, we are looking for an initial 20,000 EUR.
We have set up a limited liability company for purchasing the land area. We have a ready-made plan for planting the trees – we will take action immediately after the Indiegogo campaign ends.
We also have first-hand experience of planting trees in Finland – we’ve done it ourselves.
How we would spend the funding:

column3: >Our initial ask of 20,000 EUR is planned to be spent as follows:

column1: <ul>
<li><span style=""font-family: benton-sans, Helvetica, sans-serif
column3: >Estimated 13,000 - 17,000 for purchase of the required land area (depending on what exact land areas are for sale at the time)

column1: <li><span style=""font-family: benton-sans, Helvetica, sans-serif
column3: >All the remaining funds will go to the purchase of trees in the total amount of bought carbon dioxide removal

column1: <li><span style=""font-family: benton-sans, Helvetica, sans-serif
column3: >In case of exceeding our funding goal, we will simply purchase more land and more trees

>NOTE: the 20,000 EUR does not include any personnel costs. For the time being we are all employed and thus able to work with 0 personnel costs. As Carbon Deed grows, the amount of administrative work is of course going to grow with it, and in the long-term we plan to employ ourselves and others in the enterprise.

>IndieGoGo campaign is the grounds for setting up the operation. Going forward the business will be maintained through monthly carbon removal subscriptions through our website at https://www.carbondeed.earth/

column4: L results and the amount of CO₂​
column6: > removed in an easy-to-read format on our website, in order to maintain transparency of our cost-structure. We will also give monthly updates to the amount we have received, as well as a quarterly summary of how our operations have developed.

column3: >If we do not reach our goal of 20,000 EUR, the money will be used to remove carbon through the non-profit Compensate Foundation (compensate.com), which is already operating through purchases of CO₂​

column1: What You Get

In addition to removing the CO₂ on your behalf, you will get a Carbon Deed Certificate of CO₂ removal equal to the amount you have contributed to the campaign. The CO₂ emission calculations are based on average OECD per capita figures, which shows that average citizen living in a OECD country has yearly CO₂ emissions of 10.9 tons.
Our Indiegogo campaign has four different packages:
<ol>
• 13 € - remove 1 tonne of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting one tree ( 1 month of OECD average citizen's emissions)
• 38 € - remove 3 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting three trees (3 months of OECD average citizen's emissions)
• 154 € - remove 12 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting twelve trees (12 months of OECD average citizen's emissions)
• 13,952 € - remove 1200 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting twelvehundred trees (equal to a lifetime's emissions)
All IndieGoGo supporters also get their names under our website’s hall of fame “People that made Carbon Deed possible.""
The Impact

Every second, more than 1,000 tons of carbon dioxide is released to the atmosphere. This amounts to 36,000 000 000 tons of carbon dioxide per year. Reducing carbon emissions is crucial to mitigate the effects of our changing climate. As we can't suddenly stop producing emissions, the value of carbon farming is to neutralize our emissions. This is done by removing CO₂ from the atmosphere and binding it to newly planted forest.

One tree absorbs 1 ton of carbon over its cautious lifetime estimate of 40 years. This means that planting as few as 5-20 new trees every year can neutralize your personal CO2 emissions, depending on how much you emit per year.

We periodically examine our forests to ensure optimal CO₂ absorption. Our forests are insured against natural disasters. If a tree needs to be harvested we make sure it is used in long-term causes, such as building material.
<h3>Risks &amp

As our business is based on growing forests, there always exists a risk of a natural disaster that has the potential to destroy part of our forest or seeds planted. Our approach to risk mitigation in case of a natural disaster is three-fold:
<ol>
<li>

Location we plant our seeds and grow the forest in Finland, where natural disasters are very uncommon. Our forests are covered by Finnish forest regulation which has proven to be a historically successful form of pre-emptive protection.
<li>

Forest insurance all our forests are insured against natural disasters by an insurance partner. In case of a natural disaster that would wipe out our forest, we will receive compensation amounting to the amount of CO₂ currently removed the atmosphere. This compensation will go directly to re-forestation and a forest preservation program to minimize the effects of CO₂ emitted back to the atmosphere.
<li>

Over compensation for each ten trees planted, we will plant an additional tree. In effect this extra tree ton is a hedge against natural disaster. In practice, this means that even if 10% of the forest we have planted burnt down, which is highly unlikely in Finland, the CO2 removal you have paid for has still been removed.

An existential risk for our business is that we do not have enough time to remove CO₂. That is why we need to act sooner rather than later, planting as much forest as possible to reduce the CO₂ levels in the atmosphere. Do your Carbon Deed and join us today!
","What is Carbon Deed?

We are a Finnish forest startup on the mission to allow all of us a more sustainable way of life by offering a way to compensate for your CO₂ emissions with ease. We provide permanent carbon removal (also known as carbon farming) services to individuals and companies by growing forest efficiently.

Be aware, we are not an industrial foresting company and we do not grow our forests for economic purposes. Our target is to maximize CO₂ absorption of forests, while also cultivating biodiversity and natural life. This means we only plant trees to unused land and will grow the trees for as long as possible.

For the time being forests are the only globally recognized feasible method of carbon removal at a large scale. Forests are not only very efficient at capturing CO₂, but the results are also measurable and verifiable.

Finland has the highest forest to land ratio in the world, and also the biggest forest companies, thus it is an ideal place for founding a forest-technology start-up. Prior to founding Carbon Deed we’ve received support from some of the most knowledgeable forestation experts in the world (e.g. University of Helsinki and the Forestation administrative of Finland). We have fine-tuned our approach based on these discussions and validated our Carbon farming business plan. The amount of support and the involvement of experts will expand as we progress with Carbon Deed.

We buy unused land in Finland, for example old farm land. We plant it with trees and make sure they grow as fast as possible. Each tree is given a unique tree identifier (UTI) by which all trees are linked to contributors. When the trees start growing, we measure their CO₂ absorption.
The Project
Goal of the Indiegogo campaign:
To plant the first trees and reach a broader audience with Carbon Deed, we are looking for an initial 20,000 EUR.
We have set up a limited liability company for purchasing the land area. We have a ready-made plan for planting the trees – we will take action immediately after the Indiegogo campaign ends.
We also have first-hand experience of planting trees in Finland – we’ve done it ourselves.
How we would spend the funding:
Our initial ask of 20,000 EUR is planned to be spent as follows:
Estimated 13,000 - 17,000 for purchase of the required land area (depending on what exact land areas are for sale at the time)
All the remaining funds will go to the purchase of trees in the total amount of bought carbon dioxide removal
In case of exceeding our funding goal, we will simply purchase more land and more trees

NOTE: the 20,000 EUR does not include any personnel costs. For the time being we are all employed and thus able to work with 0 personnel costs. As Carbon Deed grows, the amount of administrative work is of course going to grow with it, and in the long-term we plan to employ ourselves and others in the enterprise.

IndieGoGo campaign is the grounds for setting up the operation. Going forward the business will be maintained through monthly carbon removal subscriptions through our website at https://www.carbondeed.earth/

We will publish the company’s P&L results and the amount of CO₂​ removed in an easy-to-read format on our website, in order to maintain transparency of our cost-structure. We will also give monthly updates to the amount we have received, as well as a quarterly summary of how our operations have developed.

If we do not reach our goal of 20,000 EUR, the money will be used to remove carbon through the non-profit Compensate Foundation (compensate.com), which is already operating through purchases of CO₂​ removal certificates.
What You Get

In addition to removing the CO₂ on your behalf, you will get a Carbon Deed Certificate of CO₂ removal equal to the amount you have contributed to the campaign. The CO₂ emission calculations are based on average OECD per capita figures, which shows that average citizen living in a OECD country has yearly CO₂ emissions of 10.9 tons.
Our Indiegogo campaign has four different packages:
13 € - remove 1 tonne of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting one tree ( 1 month of OECD average citizen's emissions)
38 € - remove 3 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting three trees (3 months of OECD average citizen's emissions)
154 € - remove 12 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting twelve trees (12 months of OECD average citizen's emissions)
13,952 € - remove 1200 tonnes of CO₂ from the atmosphere by planting twelvehundred trees (equal to a lifetime's emissions)
All IndieGoGo supporters also get their names under our website’s hall of fame “People that made Carbon Deed possible.""
The Impact

Every second, more than 1,000 tons of carbon dioxide is released to the atmosphere. This amounts to 36,000 000 000 tons of carbon dioxide per year. Reducing carbon emissions is crucial to mitigate the effects of our changing climate. As we can't suddenly stop producing emissions, the value of carbon farming is to neutralize our emissions. This is done by removing CO₂ from the atmosphere and binding it to newly planted forest.

One tree absorbs 1 ton of carbon over its cautious lifetime estimate of 40 years. This means that planting as few as 5-20 new trees every year can neutralize your personal CO2 emissions, depending on how much you emit per year.

We periodically examine our forests to ensure optimal CO₂ absorption. Our forests are insured against natural disasters. If a tree needs to be harvested we make sure it is used in long-term causes, such as building material.
Risks & Challenges

As our business is based on growing forests, there always exists a risk of a natural disaster that has the potential to destroy part of our forest or seeds planted. Our approach to risk mitigation in case of a natural disaster is three-fold:

Location we plant our seeds and grow the forest in Finland, where natural disasters are very uncommon. Our forests are covered by Finnish forest regulation which has proven to be a historically successful form of pre-emptive protection.

Forest insurance all our forests are insured against natural disasters by an insurance partner. In case of a natural disaster that would wipe out our forest, we will receive compensation amounting to the amount of CO₂ currently removed the atmosphere. This compensation will go directly to re-forestation and a forest preservation program to minimize the effects of CO₂ emitted back to the atmosphere.

Over compensation for each ten trees planted, we will plant an additional tree. In effect this extra tree ton is a hedge against natural disaster. In practice, this means that even if 10% of the forest we have planted burnt down, which is highly unlikely in Finland, the CO2 removal you have paid for has still been removed.

An existential risk for our business is that we do not have enough time to remove CO₂. That is why we need to act sooner rather than later, planting as much forest as possible to reduce the CO₂ levels in the atmosphere. Do your Carbon Deed and join us today!",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Helsinki, Finland",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/co2-removal-by-carbon-deed/pica

Help us save Lake Atitlán from an environmental, ecological and human disaster !!

Goal:                    $200,000 

Purpose:              Enable 2 year scientific research to save Lake Atitlán
column3:
>$80,000 for scientific excursions and research

                              $40,000 for laboratory equipment

                              $30,000 for remodeling of lake house as scientific home base
column4:
>                              $30,000 for biological experiments and scientist

                              $20,000 for general maintenance 

Lake Atitlán is the most important fresh water lake in Central America. It is located in the western mountain range of Guatemala, in the department of Sololá. It is without a doubt the most important natural attraction of the country, and one of its principal economic sources since it attracts not only international tourists from all over the world but local tourists as well.

column1: Lake Atitlán complements its beauty with panoramic roadways, riverside towns, mountains, and volcanoes.
It has a surface area of 130 square kilometers. It is 1,554 meters above sea level and over 324 meters deep, having an average depth of 188 meters.

The main towns that surround its basin are: Santa Catarina Palopo, San Antonio Palopo, San Lucas Toliman, Santiago Atitlan, San Pedro La Laguna, San Juan La Laguna, San Pablo La Laguna, San Marcos La Laguna, Santa Cruz La Laguna, and Panajachel.
Origin
Its origin is volcanic, it formed after a long tectonic and volcanic process of almost 14 million years in which several volcanoes surged, exploded, and scattered, giving way to new ones.

88,000 years ago, the explosion of the present day Caldera formed Atitlán. The formation of its three volcanos followed on the south side: Toliman 3158 meters, Atitlan 3537 meters, and San Pedro 3020 meters.
On the north side of the lake are the jagged high mountains that formed from the explosion of the caldera. All this geological magnificence makes it a lake with unparalleled beauty and uniqueness.
Lake Situation

Atitlán is a lake without a natural visible outlet, which classifies it as an endorheic basin. The contents of the load that enters the lake take up to 80 to 100 years to dissolve.

After years of contamination, Lake Atitlán has presented signs of severe environmental stress. In 2009 satellite images from NASA showed that approximately 38% of its surface was affected by algae and cyanobacteria.
<div>

Lake Atitlán is going from oligotrophic – crystalline and potable waters- to mesotrophic – turbid and green – and if this degradation continues it will go on to become an eutrophic lake impossible to recuperate.

The deepest 140 meters out of its 340, once had a healthy reading of oxygen. Now the deepest meters no longer have any oxygen due to all the organic material that has accumulated at the bottom of Lake Atitlán and is now decomposing and in a putrefying state. Lake Atitlán has reached its maximum saturation level, and with the constant entry of sewage waters it is no longer given the opportunity to regenerate itself.
The principal threats that must be addressed in short term are:
<ul>
• Sewage water
• The use of the soil, which includes three principal factors: the expansion of the agricultural frontier, erosion, use of fertilizers, and use of agro chemicals.
• Solid waste
<div>
The principal source of contamination of Lake Atitlán is raw sewage generated by the more than 400,000 inhabitants of the lake basin.
<div>
<div><div>
In 2009, with the surprising outbreak of the cyanobacteria, Amigos, in alliance with the Universities of San Carlos, Rafael Landivar and Del Valle of Guatemala
column2: and the stateside universities at Chico and Davis, California and Reno, Nevada began to investigate the cause of the sudden deterioration of Lake Atitlán due to the deficit of scientific information.

column1: In 2011, Amigos created in Santa Catarina Palopo, the Center for Investigation of Amigos of Atitlán (CIAA), to facilitate the work of the team and to guarantee the continuity of their scientific work.

Since its opening, we have received several groups of scientists and students from foreign and Guatemalan universities that support the rescue of Atitlán. There have been four major scientific expeditions, with the participation of more than forty people, experts and students. These expeditions have been followed by periodical monitoring and investigation which have all been in part, financed by Amigos.
Below detailed budget to be able to continue the necessary studies during a 2 year period and save Lake Atitlán.<div>
<div>
Your contribution can make the difference !!
<div>
All Perk pictures and details in Gallery Tab .....
<div>
<div>
<div>

Jamaican Almonds, LLC’s objective is to be the first company to ever import almonds from Jamaica, while maintaining local farming employment and prudent environmental protection. Our CEO, Bruce Satter has been visiting Jamaica since the early eighties and considers it his second home, having spent many relaxing vacations. While he was there in 2012, he was introduced to the fact that almonds are grown organically all over the island and no one has ever cultivated them for export.

column1: It’s Going
The initial funding will be distributed among the following expenses:
<ol style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Arial, sans-serif !important

<span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
Follow-up meetings with government agencies in Jamaica for coordination
efforts

Coordination of CFC’s (Central Farming Collectives) and individual almond
farmers in Jamaica.
<li>
<span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
Regulatory Affairs including Organic Certifications, FDA &amp
Laboratory testing in Jamaica.
Impact / A Brand New Industry
<span>Jamaica has a rare opportunity to export a commodity
for the very first time.
Almonds, LLC is committed to the following aspects of pioneering this brand new
industry:
<ol style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Arial, sans-serif !important
<li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
As stated in our Mission Statement, we are committed to maintaining
manual process of the collection of almonds, thereby providing
long-term economic progress and sustainable employment for the farmers of
Jamaica.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
The Environmental Footprint of Jamaica is extremely important to
maintain through protection and ecological balance. One example of this is
to advise farmers to seed new crops according to recommended agricultural
methods that will discourage the utilization of “shakers” from being
implemented for the removal of nuts from trees. This process is used in
other industrialized countries, which involve mammoth sized vehicles with
“tweezer-like” claws that shake the nuts off the trees, thereby eliminating
the need for manual labor. Another example is when time approaches to plant
new tree seedlings for continuous and future crops, it is done with
environmental protection standards in mind and not resort to the less than
acceptable “orchard-style”planting, which wastes far too much land and
produces a lessor quality of almonds.
<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
From the beginning we have maintained the concept of “dotting every I
and crossing every T”, as we take the responsibility of pioneering this new
industry very seriously. We have included the most upstanding individuals in
our company that have proven to have outstanding credentials and the same
passion for integrity that we have. We have a Registered Trademark for the
words, “Jamaican Almond” in the United States which requires our company to
do everything possible to ensure and uphold the continued reputation of
Jamaican almonds and derivative products. This includes the adherence to
specific requirements for importing almonds and derivative products from
Jamaican farmers and companies, including and not limited to FDA, USDA,
Import/Export, Organic Certifications and Laboratory labeling.
<li>
<span style=""font-family: 'Benton Sans', Helvetica, sans-serif
As the company grows licenses will be issued to industry for all aspects of
the almond farming and exporting processes, including future launches, such
as flavoring extract products and fertilizer/mulch products, etc.
Farming Collectives:
<span>We are seeking farmers that are interested in becoming
a part of this new opportunity to
almonds for export through our company’s network. These companies
and/or individuals must reside in the country of Jamaica and satisfy the minimum
standards and requirements set forth by Jamaican Almonds, LLC.
All inquiries should be directed to our “
Questionnaire” that can be filled out
electronically submitted through our website at
Questionnaire
a copy can be requested by emailing us at
For anyone unable to access the internet from your location, please call

and return phone number.
A customer service representative will give you a call back and take a verbal
application.
&amp
<span>The risk is that the US and/or Jamaican government
agencies, such as the FDA would make the importation of Almonds  more
challenging. The challenge to us is to cross every T and dot every I,
it comes to Organic Certifications and required testing. However, this is not
rocket science and having our COO, Allen F McSherry over-seeing our Regulatory
Affairs department will be a great asset. Mr. McSherry is a licensed Pharmacist
in five US states and very familiar with the scientific aspects of our project.
Additionally, the government of Jamaica is working with our company to ensure
that this new industry comes to fruition, as everyone is in agreement that we’re
talking about a Super-food here that can only have positive results with Jamaica
sharing their almonds with other countries.
<span>We plan on spending a lot of our time in many parishes
in Jamaica, where our Central Farming Collectives will be  housed and
over-seeing this and the processes that will be put in place from
and pasteurization equipment to the collection of almond’s work-flow from local
farmers.
<span>It’s important to point out that perhaps the most
important emphasis of this journey, as stated in
Mission Statement, is “our emphasis will be to maintain the farming of Jamaican
organic almonds while utilizing as many processes as possible to ensure the
utilization of local farmers for a higher quality of life in the country of
Jamaica”.
<span>Another challenge will be to design the most
economical and prudent transportation system for
actual export process when we’re ready to bring our first load of product to
Florida for further distribution. This will be handled by our CEO, Bruce H.
Satter who spent over thirty years managing and selling in the “transportation
of commodities” industry for over thirty years and has a solid reputation,
including experience in all facets of transport. He is particularly
knowledgeable of import/export regulations, including precise cutting of
international documentation and to the adherence to customs requirements for
both countries.

<span><b style=""font-weight: bold
We totally understand if you’re not in a position to contribute to our campaign,
but it would
most appreciated if you can help us by spreading the word through Social Media
and by using the Indiegogo share tools!

emulsifier for all parts of the human body,
the skin, hair, and lips. The first part of the process is the hand-collection
of the nuts by local farmers and then transferred to a Central Farming

that ready the kernels for the cold-pressing step. The final leg will be the

for final distribution.

Summary

Hello.  My name is Timothy T. Visi and I am the founder and co-owner of Sea Plants Solutions LLC in Port Townsend, WA. (www.seaplantssolutions.com).  I have been in the marine science field for about 28 years with 13 years as a NMFS Marine Fisheries Observer (domestic and foreign). Since 2002 I one of the handful of individuals in North America pioneering sustainable land based intensive seaweed cultivation systems-farms.

I believe we all can make a difference in so many ways by offering alternative monetary gains for businesses as they actively clean up the environment. There are 50,000 proprietary products sold in the world today that require compounds that are found NOWHERE else in nature except seaweed.

Over the last 10 yrs or so the US has been importing 200,000 metric tons of seaweed biomass to supply a thriving $2.5-Billion economy in this country.

A few years ago I developed a land based seaweed system  from a large greenhouse that re-mediates or cleans up the environment.  I called this system a SSTC-Systems - (Synergistic Sustainable Tumble Culture-Systems)

SSTC-Systems are proprietary land-based sustainable and fully environmental controlled. These seaweed growing systems produce high quality biomass for nutritious food &
column2:
other high grade commodities. By aggressively phyto-remediating - or using plants to filter, eutrophic water – or water saturated with concentrated carbon dioxide, nitrogen and phosphorus, which is food for plants AND one of the “root causes” that impacts and creates widespread areas of eutrophication zones- otherwise known as ocean acidification.

In 2013
column3:
SSTC-Systems were re-designed into more versatile configurations of modular SSTC-Systems refurbished from shipping containers, which is what this campaign is all about.

Eutrophic water is concentrated with organic compounds like carbon dioxide, nitrogen &
column4:
phosphorus and causes low oxygen concentration of the water and changes the natural water chemistry by causing pH to drop to an acidic condition.

SSTC-Systems can reverse these  eutrophic – acidic conditions by phyto-remediating, removing or reducing this “eutrophic brew” as food while simultaneously increasing the oxygen concentration of the water and balancing the pH thereby returning the water chemistry back to normal. This happens 365 days/year without seasonal fluctuations as it is in nature.

column1: <li>

We have, for almost a decade, grown sustainable commercial growing of 143-metric tons of seaweed on land.  Our research and development into phyto-remediation abilities of various species of seaweed has led to an understanding of how they can be used in various aquatic (freshwater, estuarine and saltwater) environments.

<li><strong>Our system has cleaned over 198-million gallons of eutrophic water from point source discharge (first above photo @ NOAA/NMFS Fisheries Research Lab in Manchester, WA) and 8-million gallons from no-point multi-discharge-eutrophic watershed and several micro-habitats (second above photo &amp
<li><strong>Our system can remediate-clean-remove thousands of gallons of eutrophic water from the environment on a daily basis
column3: while producing organic certifiable biomass.  This occurs with NO seasonal growth or remediation fluctuations as it would occur in nature.

column8:
surpassed all building codes, shoreline impact statements, and water quality requirements. This results in exemption status to all federal, state (our home in Washington) and county codes/regulations. 

Our website show the phyto-remediation capabilities of each tank. It also contains information on SGC Ratio (Seaweed Growth Co-efficient) of seaweed that addresses nutrients/seaweed biomass balancing for flow-through water circulation or re-circulated systems like mariponics.

In 2009 I was joined by Karacan Salkuci whose decades of scientific research assisted in cultivar development, a method for carrageenan extraction and the development of essential protocols.

This allowed me to finalize my research in 2011 into the development of a fully controlled growing system that added to and complimented the 2005 achievement of sustainable seaweed growing &
column9:
harvesting techniques at Manchester, WA. 

In 2013 I re-designed the SSTC-System into a more versatile configuration by refurbishing used shipping containers into  Modular SSTC-Systems.  Even though they have a smaller footprint
column10:
they still can remediate several thousands of gallons of eutrophic water/day.

Since seaweed has different remediation rates, growth rates and affinities for different nutrients. Generally speaking a 20’ Modular can remediate at least 7,200 gallons-per-day while a 53’ Modular can remediate at least 24,000 gallons per day -- 365-days/year!

Our self contained modular systems can virtually be placed almost anywhere space is available to remediate a particular site and depending upon site specifics, can be used as an integrated system or stand-alone system.

On May of 2013 Washington Fish Growers Associations (www.wfga.net) liked our SSTC-System design and published an article about Sea Plants Solutions on their website. 

In July 2013 my business proposal-using refurbished shipping containers into Modular SSTC-Systems and was accepted as one out of nine participants in the Bio-Marine International Aquaculture Entrepreneur Challenge in Nova Scotia.  Due to the lack of funding I had to unfortunately decline the invitation.

Some Examples of  Sea Vegetables Grown by This Method

We sustainably grew nine commercially important species with high growth rates (35% - 45% - depending on species).

Briefly Describe Your Campaign and Why it's Important to You

I founded Sea Plants Solutions in 2012 for several important reasons. The first and most important is cleaning up the environment by  phyto-remedaiting or bio-filtration of eutrophic water by using land based seaweed farms before it reaches the environment, or phyto-remediate a eutrophicated watershed before it grows and collectively creates ocean acidification.

Seaweed as a raw material can be used as a sustainable food supply. The raw materials of seaweed can be used for bio-plastic, bio-fuels and a myriad of other uses.

It was these two reasons for the driving forces that caused me to become dedicated into developing this new economic &
column11:
ecological paradigm that presently does not exist – yet!

We would like to use this technology to remediate-clean up more eutrophic sites as they come available through our seaweed consulting-remediation services/contracts/partnerships.

Our Short Term Goal is
column12:
To realistically achieve these goals of remediating as many eutrophic sites as possible. Sea Plants Solutions presently has two sites to expand at and plenty of growing markets to fulfill BUT we do not have the  funding to bring these two pieces of the project together.

We need funding to build the first THREE (Prototypes) 53’ modular SSTC-Systems to grow SIX of the NINE species grown by this method so far.

In addition we also need the funding for the FIRST YEAR’S operational  costs.

If we are able to achieve our goal these THREE 53’ Modulars will be able to collectively phyto-remediate roughly 110,000 gpd of eutrophic source water!

We also seek funding for a small modular organic certified carrageenan lab using our proprietary method.

Our long term goal is:

To have sustainable prototypes and to be ready to pursue other locations while creating a new revenue sources.

  • We would like to create new sustainable economic and ecological paradigms from the SSTC-System.  This can be achieved by whether a SSTC-System is used as a modular integrated into a restricted site space or greenhouses for large remediation projects to clean the aquatic environments like estuaries, watersheds, lagoons, bays, marina's or larger bodies of water.

We hope people see the future as we do. 

We want to start a “Seaweed Seed Stock Bank” for various other species that would be used in our seaweed consulting business of custom designs of SSTC-Systems to tackle any particular eutrophic - remediation job available, using species that are in commercial demand.

The various sized turn-key modular SSTC-Systems would be furnished with a hybridized seed stock that would ensure full production &
column13:
remediating capabilities one month from set up time at any particular site.

The Modular sizes we will work with will be 20’, 24’, 40’, &
column14:
53’.

Since seaweed has different remediation, growth rates &
column15:
various affinities for different compounds. Generally speaking, a 20’ Modular SSTC-System can remediate at least 7,200 gallons-per-day eutrophic water and produce at least 1,000 pounds/month.  A 53’ Modular SSTC-System can remediate at least 24,000 gallons-per-day of eutrophic water and produce at least 2,400 pounds/month.

Some examples of sites that can utilize our SSTC-System are:

•  Any remediation company that requires industry or agricultural clean up processes of affected sites.

About Us

Tim Visi’s career began in 1987 as a fisheries technician on a research project in the Bahamas involving ocean cage rearing of tilapia.  His next adventure took him to almost the other side of the world, to Seattle, WA to become a NMFS Marine Fisheries Biologist (Observer) for the next 12 years.                                                

Starting in 2002 to 2008
column2: Tim Visi became one of the few individuals in North America who pioneered intensive &amp
column3:
sustainable land based seaweed systems.  He was asked to join a Sea Grant project at the (NOAA / NMFS) NW Fisheries Research Lab in Manchester, WA.  It was here that he eventually oversaw the project and proved from his research that seaweed could be grown sustainable and intensively while remediating aquaculture fish farm effluent or nutrient streams-- which if left untreated would eventually add to the eutrophication (acidification) of the environment.                                                                                        

Here he grew an average of 23 metric tons per year on a 4,800  square foot farm while phyto-remediating 31.2 million gallons of finfish effluent per year.  In 2007
column4:
his research was critiqued by his peers at NOAA/NMFS.                                                                                                                                             

He was also on the cover of the June 2007 Aquaculture Europe magazine and gave a short presentation to international aquaculture scientists visiting the Manchester NOAA/NMFS facility. 

From 2007 to 2008
column5: he advised several Puget Sound bio-fuel companies on species selection and growing techniques of seaweed &amp
column6: marine microalgae (Diatoms) for various commodities derived from the biomass generated from such growing systems, as well as
column7:
growing strains/cultivar of marine microalgae.                                                                                                             

In 2008, Tim Visi left NOAA/NMFS to continue the research &
column8:
development on his own. In 2009 to 2011 he put together and managed a 2,400 square foot greenhouse farm located on Sequim Bay, WA.  It was here that he started the first land based, sustainable sea vegetables farm for human consumption in the UnitedStates.                                                                                                                    

In 2009 Mr. Visi won Washington State’s Clallam County Entrepreneur Challenge Contest for the most innovative “green” business plan involving a SSTC-System farm using a large greenhouse. A $5,000 grant was the prize.  These funds were used to continue the research in the “Full Environmental Controlled” cultivation methodology of many other species of seaweed.

Karacan Salkuci was born in Germany and is a multilingual person who has lived in the United    States since 1961.  She is a retired counselor, psychology teacher, retired faculty member of  several universities, research scientist, movement meditation instructor and is trained in animal psychology.

She has worked extensively with Tim Visi at developing the SSTC-System farm at the Sequim Bay, Washington location where she was directly involved with cultivar development, proprietary carrageenan extraction, protocol development and photographic documentation of the systems and processes.

","SummaryHello.  My name is Timothy T. Visi and I am the founder and co-owner of Sea Plants Solutions LLC in Port Townsend, WA. (www.seaplantssolutions.com).  I have been in the marine science field for about 28 years with 13 years as a NMFS Marine Fisheries Observer (domestic and foreign). Since 2002 I one of the handful of individuals in North America pioneering sustainable land based intensive seaweed cultivation systems-farms.I believe we all can make a difference in so many ways by offering alternative monetary gains for businesses as they actively clean up the environment. There are 50,000 proprietary products sold in the world today that require compounds that are found NOWHERE else in nature except seaweed.Over the last 10 yrs or so the US has been importing 200,000 metric tons of seaweed biomass to supply a thriving $2.5-Billion economy in this country.A few years ago I developed a land based seaweed system  from a large greenhouse that re-mediates or cleans up the environment.  I called this system a SSTC-Systems - (Synergistic Sustainable Tumble Culture-Systems)SSTC-Systems are proprietary land-based sustainable and fully environmental controlled. These seaweed growing systems produce high quality biomass for nutritious food & other high grade commodities. By aggressively phyto-remediating - or using plants to filter, eutrophic water – or water saturated with concentrated carbon dioxide, nitrogen and phosphorus, which is food for plants AND one of the “root causes” that impacts and creates widespread areas of eutrophication zones- otherwise known as ocean acidification.In 2013
column2: SSTC-Systems were re-designed into more versatile configurations of modular SSTC-Systems refurbished from shipping containers, which is what this campaign is all about.Eutrophic water is concentrated with organic compounds like carbon dioxide, nitrogen & phosphorus and causes low oxygen concentration of the water and changes the natural water chemistry by causing pH to drop to an acidic condition.SSTC-Systems can reverse these  eutrophic – acidic conditions by phyto-remediating, removing or reducing this “eutrophic brew” as food while simultaneously increasing the oxygen concentration of the water and balancing the pH thereby returning the water chemistry back to normal. This happens 365 days/year without seasonal fluctuations as it is in nature.

column1: We have, for almost a decade, grown sustainable commercial growing of 143-metric tons of seaweed on land.  Our research and development into phyto-remediation abilities of various species of seaweed has led to an understanding of how they can be used in various aquatic (freshwater, estuarine and saltwater) environments.

Our system has cleaned over 198-million gallons of eutrophic water from point source discharge (first above photo @ NOAA/NMFS Fisheries Research Lab in Manchester, WA) and 8-million gallons from no-point multi-discharge-eutrophic watershed and several micro-habitats (second above photo & below photos @ Sequim Bay, WA).
Our system can remediate-clean-remove thousands of gallons of eutrophic water from the environment on a daily basis
column3: while producing organic certifiable biomass.  This occurs with NO seasonal growth or remediation fluctuations as it would occur in nature.

column2: receives ONE dried pound of organic-quality sea vegetables of your choice, a 6” X 9” clear resin plaque that will have a ""thank you"" in your name along with the kelp photo above  & samples of the seaweed species we would be growing, and a T-shirt with our logo on it.

column1: Donations for the $1,000 level receives THREE dried pounds variety pack of 1/2 Lb samples of organic -quality sea vegetables we would be growing, a seaweed cookbook, a desktop resin plague with thanks in your name and the sea vegetables we are growing, and a T-shirt.
Donations for the $5,000 level
column2: receives SIX dried one-pound packs of organic-quality sea vegetables, a desktop resin plague with thanks in your name and the sea vegetables we are growing, a seaweed medicinal book, a T-shirt, 11 ounce coffee mug, & a grocery tote bag
column3: all with our logo on it.

column1: The Impact

Obviously the greatest impact this project can have AND is the REASON why I kept at it all these years of waiting for the right time to launch this campaign is the reduction or reversal of ocean & estuarine acidification of the environment that we are presently witnessing.
We also accomplish an alternative way to create a responsible revenue source by helping to achieve multiply products
column2: food and bio-energy.  There is no waste or negative impact from our system as all biomass is utilized and all water cleaned as it passes through our high growth tumble culture system.  We can achieve ZERO or negative carbon footprint by utilizing alternative energy sources like solar, wind powered generator. The seaweed can be used as feed stock for bio-ethanol & bio-methane. Other Ways You Can Help

column1: Some folks might not have the economic ability to become monetary involved, but what I have found out over the years is that once people understand what I am trying to do they become active in their own way by reading on the internet or speaking to others.
Once we achieve the proper funding for the first three 53’ Modulars, we would be positioned to start expanding into other sites after the first year.  More sites mean more water that is cleaned
column2: a chance to create an economic sustainability in areas where employment is scarce.

column1: Sites for these Modular’s could be placed almost anywhere, be it rural or a metropolis.
It’s up to us (the people) to make the change towards a more sustainable economic & ecological paradigm.",16.0,0,"1 Campaign

to both.

","I
am Tony Tweedale, an American in Brussels, the European Union (EU) capital,
helping NGOs improve the risk assessment of toxic chemicals. Industry
always supplies the toxicity studies on which their products' risk is
evaluated(!), but no-one is allowed to evaluate them--only brief
summaries are released.
Recently,
I was auditing for the NGO PAN-E the quality of toxicity studies in some new EU
pesticide authorizations–industry newly must evaluate all information on their agent, though they aren't–including those of the world's largest
selling pesticide, the herbicide glyphosate. That's
when industry attacked the academics (Séralini et al.) who published
shocking toxicity findings (photo from the study, above): exposing rats over most of their lives (for the first time) to
the glyphosate formulation Roundup, to genetically modified corn, and
to both.
Since
this and other studies were ignored in glyphosate's risk assessment,
I badly wanted to look at the details of industry's
two
key chronic exposure studies, but they told the European agency EFSA that they
can not be released, as competitors could use toxicity information
to compete against them. Safety
should not be subservient to commerce!
Recent
court decisions, under appeal, may force EU agencies to release
any information
that concerns 'a release to the environment', so I was pleased to
discover that those specialized lawyers were interested in my idea of suing to release
toxicity studies. I
did so last year, suing EFSA for the release of these two key
studies ... but now I have to pay for the estimated 11,000 Euro
cost.
WHAT
IS AT STAKE in the RELEASE of THESE TWO STUDIES?
Multinational
petrochemical companies use the same toxicity studies across
continents and time for market authorization of their chemicals. For
decades they have entirely controlled these risk assessments, using
test methods that are very insensitive. In fact, independent
academia's toxicity studies, which very often find lower dose
toxicity, are entirely
excluded
column2: even though they accumulate at an ever faster rate.

column1: Even
when industry gives
their regulator a complete toxicity study, none
has ever been released to the public, so that financially independent
scientists can critique it.
The release of industry's poor quality key toxicity studies would be

revolutionary, transforming risk assessment, as the previously secret details could then be compared to the methods used for so many low dose toxicity findings of independent academic scientists, promoting dialogue with regulators about the elements of good quality data (and industry's studies would be available to all).
This
effort may fail -- European courts may decide to shut down public
access to key technical information. But the lower court decisions
are hopeful, and there is a treaty (the Aarhus Convention) driving
these decisions towards openness.
To
date I have raised only ~1,000 of the estimated 11,000 Euro (U$
13,000) cost to take this case through the first decision (not the
appeal). I hope to raise at least half the remainder (if I am lucky,
most of it). So I hope to have convinced you of the importance of
assisting this campaign!
Whether
your donation is big, small, or ""can't"", I hope to have
motivated you to let friends and colleagues know about this
opportunity, create a link to this fundraising effort, etc....and
don't
forget you can use the Indiegogo share tools on the left!
Thanks
for your consideration.  Questions?: ttweed@base.be",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Eastpointe, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/release-industry-s-glyphosate-key-toxicity-studies/pica

PadisFest si Campania Padis

Suntem un grup de 10 ONG-uri de mediu din Oradea, Cluj si Alba care de peste 10 ani sustinem dezvoltarea turismului responsabil in Padis, sus in inima Parcului Natural Apuseni. Impreuna am prevenit distrugerea unei rezervatii naturale stiintifice, am responsabilizat turistii sa isi stranga gunoaiele si am atras atentia unui public tot mai mare.

Totusi, in Padis nu exista un camping decent, nu exista toalete, iar o dezvoltare haotica a zonei risca sa alunge ursul (mascota Parcului), sa sece pesterile din cel mai mare platou carstic impadurit din Europa si sa usuce plantele carnivore. Ursul a fost pacalit de vulpe, natura a fost pacalita de lacomie. Acum e momentul sa schimbam povestea!

In 2015 ne-am unit cu Administratia Parcului Natural Apuseni sa incercam ceva diferit: sa atragem sprijinul tinerilor din Oradea, Cluj si Alba. Impreuna organizam PadisFest in august, un festival-campanie care va aduce concerte intre brazi si la Cetatile Ponorului, teatru pe stanci, arta culinara, tiroliana, escalada, concursuri de bicicleta, targ de produse traditionale si cate si mai cate. Vom avea dezbateri cu investitori, oameni din comunitati si turisti.

Cu ajutorul vostru vom avea posibilitatea sa atragem cat mai multa atentie a presei pentru festivalul-campanie, sa oferim un exemplu de infrastructura turistica curata la festival si sa invitam niste artisti care sa va relaxeze intre brazi si sa va faca sa visati la o lume mai verde.

Ce avem nevoie

Avem nevoie de 2000 de euro pentru inchiriere de scena, plata artistilor, mobilizarea presei, inchirierea de toalete ecologice, asigurarea salubrizarii si promovarea dinamica a festivalului. Dintre acestia, vrem sa strangem 1000 din contributiile voastre, mana de la mana, iar 1000 din partea unor sponsori. Pe langa acesti bani, am castigat deja o finantare de 26110 lei de la Fundatia pentru Parteneriat Miercurea-Ciuc si MOL Romania prin programul Spatii Verzi, componenta Arii Naturale Protejate.
Cum ne puteti ajuta?
Furnica - pentru 5 euro va daruim un zambet. Stim ca furnica duce graunte mari in spate, si furnica de la furnica construim un musuroi mare.
Albina - pentru 10 euro va daruim o sacosa de panza PadisFest. Sa va transportati mierea cu ea.
Scoica - pentru 20 de euro va daruim o sacosa de panza PadisFest si va scriem numele in piatra, sa il gaseasca oamenii de stiinta peste sute de ani ca o scoica-fosila.
Fluturele - pentru 30 de euro va daruim o sacosa de panza PadisFest, va scriem numele in piatra si va daruim si un tricou PadisFest, sa zburati cu culorile Padisului  prin lume.
Maimuta - pentru 50 de euro va daruim o sacosa, numele scris in piatra, un tricou si 5 intrari gratuite la tiroliana si escalada de la Padis in timpul festivalului.
Gorila - pentru 200 de euro va daruim o sacosa, numele scris in piatra, un tricou, o lampa frontala si 20 de intrari gratuite la viitorul parc de aventura Scorbura Motului pe Valea Ariesului.
Elefantul - pentru 500 va daruim o sacosa, numele scris in piatra, un tricou si un weekend surpriza in Muntii Apuseni.

PadisFest 2015 e doar inceputul. Vrem sa organizam acest festival anual, sa crestem mari, iar in restul anului sa continuam campania pentru un turism responsabil in Padis. Primul target: sa cerem constuirea unui camping decent la Padis, pentru ca noi toti sa mergem in weekenduri cu placere acolo.
Share pe Facebook si prin email ca sa afle si prietenii tai!

Based on Environmental Protection
Agency estimates ,Tulsa County's population of 600,000 people will
produce approximately 12  million pounds  of electronic waste per
year. The EPA also estimates less than 30% of this of this gets
recycled. This means over 8 million pounds of ewaste are making it
into the landfills each year.
This is unacceptable. This is a waste
of recyclable resources as well as creating an environmental toxic
time bomb. Electronics are made of both easily recyclable materials
and substances that are toxic in the environment. It is essential for
future generations that this material gets diverted from landfills.
Electronic Synergy Foundation (ESF) is
a non-profit (501c3) electronic recycling company. We were formed to
help combat this problem. Our mission is to leverage the recycling of
electronic waste (ewaste) for the community benefits of environmental
stewardship (keeping ewaste out of landfills) and charitable works
(donating usable electronics to other non-profit organizations).
We accomplish this by holding ewaste
collection events in Tulsa and surrounding areas. The way it works is
as follows:
We choose a centralized location in the
targeted community (a park, shopping center, civic organization's
parking lot,) etc. We bring out a big truck (rental) and invite
donors to bring their unwanted electronics.
We load the donations onto the truck,
haul it to our warehouse, and sort through it.  As a general rule 90%
of what we receive has no use left (mostly old televisions). The
computers intended for re-use get refurbished (repairs + data
destruction).
The unusable electronics get sorted and
aggregated into truckload quantities and sent to ECS Refining a
R2/E-Steward electronic recycling facility in Dallas Texas.
We do not charge recycling fees, as we
believe they are a barrier to recycling. We have heard ""I won't
pay to dispose of this TV, I'll just put it in a dumpster instead""
more times than we care to count.  Instead we fund ourselves through
donations of money and the revenue we generate from our recycling
efforts.
What We Need
To put it simply, we need money:
Rental Trucks cost money, We've sought
sponsorships from the major truck rental companies, They were not
interested. On average it can cost $100 or more a day to use a rental
truck. (rental + mileage + fuel)
Event Insurance (average of $100 per
event) required by many venues
Wages: It would be great if we had
volunteers to handle the workload of collecting and processing this
stuff, but while i'm waiting for them to volunteer, we need workers
willing to brave the weather and handle the load.
Infrastructure Support: Warehouse
Rent, Pallets, Shrink-wrap, etc. all cost money.

column9: >What We Will Do With The Money

column1: We will spend the money on holding
longer and more frequent collection events in Tulsa and surrounding
counties.
Marketing (the more people know about
an event, the greater likelihood of participation) via radio in Tulsa
and mass mail marketing in the rural areas.
Setup collection sites and partnership
programs.
Any leftover funds will be used to
upgrade our collection and processing infrastructure (ie:  purchase
forklift, truck, etc)
Keep in mind that every dollar not
consumed by our collection efforts or overhead  will be used to
support our charitable works (donated electronics and IT support to
other non-profit organizations)
What We've Done So Far
A clean-out of a rural public school
system. They had several years worth of accumulated ewaste standing
in the way of renovations.
http://electronicsynergy.org/?page_id=551
Lafortune Park Collection Event,
December 27th, 28th, 29th 2014
Fox 23 Came out and did a report, you
can see it here:
http://www.fox23.com/videos/news/tulsa-group-ho...
Broken Arrow Ewaste Collection Event,
February 22nd,23rd,24th 2015
Jenks Ewaste Collection Event, March
15th-17th
http://www.fox23.com/news/news/local/tulsa-grou...
Owasso e-Waste Diversion , April
http://electronicsynergy.org/?p=667
Owasso Ewaste Collection Event, May

http://electronicsynergy.org/?page_id=657

Bixby Ewaste Collection Event,June 18th through 20th

http://electronicsynergy.org/?page_id=715
Where We Wish To Go
All over Tulsa and it's adjoining
counties. Including but not limited to:
Coweta, Jenks, Sand Springs, Sapulpa,
Owasso, Skiatook, Claremore, Collinsville, Catoosa, Muskogee,
Okmulgee, Bixby and Bartlesville.
We are happy to host and promote our
own events, but we are also looking for other events and sponsors to
partner with.

Future Projects

Where many people see junk and problems, ESF sees opportunity. As we grow we can use our material stream to grow ESF into an agent of change in North Tulsa, by providing jobs and job training along with educational opportunities for disadvantaged individuals.
Establishment of an eWaste
hotline.  Callers would report eWaste in dumpsters and curbside,

ESF would send someone out to retrieve it for proper recycling. 

eWaste diversion programs set up in partnership with local landfills and waste haulers.
eWaste
urban Tulsa area, possibly as a fundraising partnership with local
school systems
Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to financial support we
need volunteers willing to assist us in our collection efforts, this

includes but is not limited to:

Be our Ambassador. If you know of a business or other organization with a pile of unwanted electronics, please let the owner/manager of said material know that they can do a lot of good by donating it to ESF.
Volunteers willing to pick up and
transport ewaste to us
Volunteers willing to work collection
events
Vonors willing to share their social
media space to help spread the word about our mission to divert
ewaste from landfills
Event organizers willing to add ewaste
collection to their event
Donate a truck, van or other cargo
capable vehicle to us
BRING YOUR UNWANTED ELECTRONICS TO US
at any recycling event or our drop-off locations  Call us at (918)

951-3902 to make arrangements.



Please Note:  ESF is a 501c3 non-profit organization, donations to us may be tax deductible. Consult your tax adviser for more information.

column5: >Dogs Are Better Than People Film Productions

column1: Our upcoming film, ""Adventure: Alaska,"" will show and teach kids about the popular places in Alaska and highlight the wildlife, nature, culture and adventure the state provides while showing the needs that Alaska has due to climate change. We as a team have realized how much kids really miss out by never being outside anymore, and how our world is disintegrating before kids even realize how beautiful it is. Our goal is to change kids' perspectives on what the world is going to look like in the future by showing them how they can help keep our world from dying now, we also want to show kids that they can be heroes too by showing them projects on our video blog that can help the environment.
<h3><b>Meet Our Cast &amp

In Summer of 2016, Miranda and Tanner will spend three months in Alaska filming all of their adventures while recording the facts about animal habitats and how we can help protect them and learn more about them, plus all the cool things that kids can enjoy outdoors. We hope that you will contribute to this cause in an effort to not only show kids and adults alike the greatness of the vast and amazing world beyond, but to pass on our passion to you and to them as well.
Join Us On Our Adventure

All contributions will go toward camping gear and weather gear (living in Texas doesn't really require any cold gear) in addition to gas, food, safety supplies, additional film gear, tours/adventures, kayak and ATV rentals, lodging and campsites, in addition to a vehicle built for trails and road-tripping while still being as safe as we can. Our team will be working hard to meet this goal and we greatly appreciate your interest in this project and welcome you to our supporting family!

column4: >            So you might ask what you get for your contribution other than the knowledge that you are promoting a love of the outdoors in our current and future generations. We have a few perks to offer: our film production decal for your car (or really anything you'd like to stick it to), t-shirts with our company
column5: > logo or our film title on them, donations to the Alaska Conservation Foundation, and an opportunity to be on location with us!

column1: All donations are greatly appreciated and we thank everyone who has ever donated to Indiegogo, which provides people with amazing opportunities to reach their goals with your help. Thank you again for any support!
The Impact

Independent film-making is becoming more and more popular, but filming documentaries, whether independent or not, is still not quite as popular to watch as we wish it was. We hope to help the world discover how great watching documentaries is and how much you can learn from them. Your contribution can help make this impact!
<h3>Risks &amp

No matter what this documentary is happening! In every leap of faith there is a risk of failure. If we don't raise up all of the money by summer 2016 then we will use the money to go up to Alaska and do more research then go in summer 2017.
My (Director) theory is that you only truly fail if you don't keep trying
column2: the rest are just obstacles along the way. Yes, this endeavor is a leap of faith without the backing of a motion picture company but it is not impossible! <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column3:
>I was raised by parents who believe in and fight for causes and do not back down in the face of challenges. My dad grew up in Alaska for a lot of his childhood and that was the beginning of my inspiration. My dad was a Marine, who fought in Desert Storm, turned police officer, 20 years and counting. My mom was a police officer turned counselor (yes, they met in the Police Academy and have been married ever since). So, I am stubborn, I do not quit even when my path gets tough, and I always hold true to my beliefs...because of my parents and others who helped me become who I am today. I am counting on these characteristics to overcome hurdles that gets in my way, from gear malfunction to weather to sheer mistakes!

Call To Action!

column1: Some of you can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please spread the word about our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, E-mail, Instagram, etc. I appreciate any donations or publicity, even a ""good luck"" will go a long way! Thanks again!
Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
","Dogs Are Better Than People Film Productions

Our upcoming film, ""Adventure: Alaska,"" will show and teach kids about the popular places in Alaska and highlight the wildlife, nature, culture and adventure the state provides while showing the needs that Alaska has due to climate change. We as a team have realized how much kids really miss out by never being outside anymore, and how our world is disintegrating before kids even realize how beautiful it is. Our goal is to change kids' perspectives on what the world is going to look like in the future by showing them how they can help keep our world from dying now, we also want to show kids that they can be heroes too by showing them projects on our video blog that can help the environment.
Meet Our Cast & Crew
Hanna- Photographer Lucas- Marketer
Miranda- Director, Documentary Host
Tanner- Technical Director, Documentary Host
Tegan- Artist/Storyboarder Trevor- Editor

In Summer of 2016, Miranda and Tanner will spend three months in Alaska filming all of their adventures while recording the facts about animal habitats and how we can help protect them and learn more about them, plus all the cool things that kids can enjoy outdoors. We hope that you will contribute to this cause in an effort to not only show kids and adults alike the greatness of the vast and amazing world beyond, but to pass on our passion to you and to them as well.
Join Us On Our Adventure

All contributions will go toward camping gear and weather gear (living in Texas doesn't really require any cold gear) in addition to gas, food, safety supplies, additional film gear, tours/adventures, kayak and ATV rentals, lodging and campsites, in addition to a vehicle built for trails and road-tripping while still being as safe as we can. Our team will be working hard to meet this goal and we greatly appreciate your interest in this project and welcome you to our supporting family!

So you might ask what you get for your contribution other than the knowledge that you are promoting a love of the outdoors in our current and future generations. We have a few perks to offer: our film production decal for your car (or really anything you'd like to stick it to), t-shirts with our company logo or our film title on them, donations to the Alaska Conservation Foundation, and an opportunity to be on location with us!

All donations are greatly appreciated and we thank everyone who has ever donated to Indiegogo, which provides people with amazing opportunities to reach their goals with your help. Thank you again for any support!
The Impact

Independent film-making is becoming more and more popular, but filming documentaries, whether independent or not, is still not quite as popular to watch as we wish it was. We hope to help the world discover how great watching documentaries is and how much you can learn from them. Your contribution can help make this impact!
Risks & Challenges

No matter what this documentary is happening! In every leap of faith there is a risk of failure. If we don't raise up all of the money by summer 2016 then we will use the money to go up to Alaska and do more research then go in summer 2017.
My (Director) theory is that you only truly fail if you don't keep trying

column9: >We live in an exciting time of technological innovation, but most of the world is still lagging behind.
column27: >Believe it or not, more people live without access to electricity today than did before Edison invented the lightbulb.
column33: >2.5 billion people around the world live in energy poverty and do not have access to an energy source. They use kerosene or candles or flashlights to light their homes at night and often have to travel and pay to charge their cell phones. This is a misplacement of resources. Living in energy poverty is a major impediment to income poverty alleviation. Energy poverty means limited productivity-- less time to work, study, read, or play-- and poor health and environmental impacts. Furthermore, households in energy poverty have to pay for these low-quality ""solutions"". They're spending between $5-15/month on lighting and cell charging expenses.
column39: >But there is a real solution.
column45: > Solar technology-- it provides environmental and financial returns and improves quality of life. Colibrí currently operates in Nicaragua (where 2 million people live in energy poverty) distributing and financing solar technology so that our customers can live healthier, wealthier, and happier lives. Life-changing technology should be as commonplace in people's lives as is coca-cola, bananas, nail polish, and cell phone credit.
column53: >Now you’re probably wondering one simple thing: Are you really expecting me to believe that someone living in poverty on as little as $2/day can afford a solar lamp?

column1:
You’re right. $120, $50, or even $20 upfront and in one sum is a lot of money for the average low-income consumer. That’s why Colibrí doesn’t expect that. Colibrí believes technology should be conveniently and consistently accessible to all, and that means providing flexible financing options.

Colibri’s target market already spends between $2-$6 per week on kerosene, candles, or flashlight batteries, and traveling to pay to charge their cell phones. Over 90% of the market owns a cell phone and makes weekly $1-$5 credit top ups. Let’s think of this as “single serving,” which is often the only option for someone making expenditure decisions on a day-to-day basis. In fact, even Unilever found wild success at the bottom of the pyramid when they started offering single-serving shampoo packets.

So, single-serving solar? It’s possible! And it’s called pay-as-you-go. Colibrí allows customers to rent to own solar technology, paying for it in installments equal to current lighting and cell charging expenses.
We’re not solving a bite-sized problem.

Talk about a distribution challenge worth solving…)

column1: <div style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px

","We live in an exciting time of technological innovation, but most of the world is still lagging behind. Believe it or not, more people live without access to electricity today than did before Edison invented the lightbulb. 2.5 billion people around the world live in energy poverty and do not have access to an energy source. They use kerosene or candles or flashlights to light their homes at night and often have to travel and pay to charge their cell phones. This is a misplacement of resources. Living in energy poverty is a major impediment to income poverty alleviation. Energy poverty means limited productivity-- less time to work, study, read, or play-- and poor health and environmental impacts. Furthermore, households in energy poverty have to pay for these low-quality ""solutions"". They're spending between $5-15/month on lighting and cell charging expenses. But there is a real solution. Solar technology-- it provides environmental and financial returns and improves quality of life. Colibrí currently operates in Nicaragua (where 2 million people live in energy poverty) distributing and financing solar technology so that our customers can live healthier, wealthier, and happier lives. Life-changing technology should be as commonplace in people's lives as is coca-cola, bananas, nail polish, and cell phone credit.Now you’re probably wondering one simple thing: Are you really expecting me to believe that someone living in poverty on as little as $2/day can afford a solar lamp?

You’re right. $120, $50, or even $20 upfront and in one sum is a lot of money for the average low-income consumer. That’s why Colibrí doesn’t expect that. Colibrí believes technology should be conveniently and consistently accessible to all, and that means providing flexible financing options.Colibri’s target market already spends between $2-$6 per week on kerosene, candles, or flashlight batteries, and traveling to pay to charge their cell phones. Over 90% of the market owns a cell phone and makes weekly $1-$5 credit top ups. Let’s think of this as “single serving,” which is often the only option for someone making expenditure decisions on a day-to-day basis. In fact, even Unilever found wild success at the bottom of the pyramid when they started offering single-serving shampoo packets. So, single-serving solar? It’s possible! And it’s called pay-as-you-go. Colibrí allows customers to rent to own solar technology, paying for it in installments equal to current lighting and cell charging expenses.

We’re not solving a bite-sized problem. We’re educating individuals on how doing business for the base of the pyramid is possible and how the world does not need another design of a solar lamp, rather distribution and financing for consumers in need. We are raising money to fund our pay-as-you go pilot including inventory purchase & warehousing, staff salaries, agent recruitment & training, in-country expansion, & some exciting BoP marketing campaigns.

There’s no reason that more people should lack electric light today than did before Edison invented the lightbulb 130 years ago. Affordable solar exists to let individuals leapfrog grid electricity, just as cell phones leapfrogged landlines in emerging markets. No longer are you waiting for telephone lines to be laid out for you house
column2: no longer are you waiting for electricity lines to be laid out to your community. The power is in your hands. None this will happen without serious, dedicated work to providing creative distribution and financing tactics for those in need. The future is here
column3: what will you make of it? EXTRASPerksIn addition to the impact you’ll be creating, we’re hoping to give you a taste of Nicaragua, too, with fun perks (hauled all the way from a market in Matagalpa, through the Miami airport for hours, lost in transit, found in Boston, and then driven across the country to San Francisco! Talk about a distribution challenge worth solving…)

Background

Colibrí (formerly SolarRoute) was founded around a year ago by Morgan Babbs, James Downer, and William Garcia. Colibrí distributed over 200 lamps during a small pilot in the summer of 2014. Colibrí is currently preparing for full launch for September 2015, focusing extensively on both distribution & financing. Colibrí (which means “hummingbird” in Spanish) is a for-profit social enterprise based in Matagalpa, Nicaragua. To learn more check out www.colibri-global.com, follow us on Twitter @Colibri_Global.
If you are interested in become part of our larger fundraising effort, please email morgan@colibri-global.com.
Learn about the Team
Morgan Babbs (Founder & CEO) loves iced mochas, traveling, and dreaming up ways to be more financially inclusive. Her favorite things about Nicaragua are the peras de agua and mangoes.
James Downer (Co-founder & COO) is an avid sailor, unrelatable-ly obsessed with Bitcoin, and loves mobile money. His favorite thing about Nicaragua are the constant surprises.
William Garcia (Country Director) is a technology aficionado, a jack of all trades, and likely the kindest man in La Dalia. His favorite thing about his home country of Nicaragua are the volcanoes.
Recognition

Colibrí is a member of the United Nation’s Energy Practitioner Network. Colibrí won a D Prize, a Hitachi Prize, placed 2nd in the Social Track of the Tufts $100k New Ventures Competition, is a MassChallenge Finalist, won the Tufts University 100 Projects for Peace grant, and was the first social enterprise in the First Round Capital-back Dorm Room Fund portfolio.

L'Île-des-Soeurs, dans l'arrondissement de Verdun, porte le surnom de « cité-jardin » depuis le début de son développement résidentiel, en raison de ses nombreux parcs aménagés et espaces verts. Depuis une quinzaine d'années, les projets de construction se multiplient rendant L'Île-des-Soeurs de moins en moins « jardin » et de plus en plus « cité ». Il faut protéger ce qu'il reste de parcs et espaces verts et faire en sorte que les lois soient appliquées en matière environnementale et que cessent les irrégularités. Cette campagne de collecte de fonds nous permet de financer les activités, la recherche et le développement de l'Action citoyenne de L'Île-des-Soeurs par les cofondateurs Lise Baucher-Morency, auteure et éditrice et les chefs d'orchestre de renommée internationale Agnès Grossmann et Raffi Armenian.
