The world's best sustainable alternative & replacement to 'single-use' plastic bags. AVAILABLE IN 3 STYLES(BLACK, AQUA, PURPLE)A FULL RANGE OF DESIGNS WILL COME AFTER FRIST PRODUCTION RUNHow to get your Eko Bag?1. Back this project. Pre-Order an Eko Bag.2. Select how many Bags you want & Click on the Perk 3. Enter your postal address & payment details.When this campaign is finished your Eko bags will be shipped to you within 4 weeks.Hi, I’m EkoA friendly, reusable shopping bag thats sustainable, stylish & good for the environment. A beautifully convenient, multipurpose bag that makes life easier to replace plastic bags when you shop.
I'm your new 'best buddy' for everyday shopping!
I make life easier to replace 'single-use' plastic bags in style
Take me anywhere! I'm portable and easy to store.
I'm fun to play with and easy to use
I’m strong, I can hold up to 20 Kilos.
I'm 100% waterproof, packable and fit in your pocket
I’m stylish & good for the environment
I'm made from 100% recycled plastics
I'm comfortable & unforgettable
I have a unique fold up bag design with cool inner pockets for keys & personal items.
I can also replace fruit & veg plastics bags in the store.
When i’m shopping i’m helping save the environment by reducing plastic bags
When i’m not shopping, I’m cleaning up & recycling discard plastic waste
Made from 100% recycled plastics.rPET (Recycled PET Polyester Fabric)The most sustainable textile production method on the planet. Up-cycling industrial plastic waste & post consumer plastic bottles.

If each Australian family used just one less plastic shopping bag each week,Australians would save 253 million plastic bags a year.We want to get rid of plastic bags starting with Australia.Our mission is to inspire as many shoppers as possible to change their plastic habits and share our passion for an environmentally friendly planet. Do you believe we could use less plastics?Then we need your support!EKO WANTS TO PLAY& NEEDS YOUR HELP!Join us on a journey & help Eko go to production.
Eko buddy needs 5,000 unit sales for our first production.

Your welcomed & appreciated contributions & pre-orders will go towards making our first production run possible and help us continue with this passion for purpose project. We truly intend these little beauties can make a positive impact on our plastic shopping habits for a better environment.
If you would like to use an Eko buddy. Please pre order a bag today!
Save 20% off RTP by pre-ordering before it hits the market.
All Eko buddy supporters receive a free Eko veggie bag.
Worldwide shipping included.
Perfect gifts for friends & family.
Show you care for the environment & we can make a difference.
Design & create your own Eko bag for your business with your own branded colour & logo.

Help us get these beautiful little bags into all supermarkets & stores so they're accessible & available to all. EKO STORYWe’ve designed the best alternative/replacements to single use plastics to inspire as many shoppers as possible to change their plastic habits and share our passion for an environmentally friendly planet. A bag designed specifically to replace single use plastic bags.Quick & easy checkout, fits right in to all checkout hooks as the best replacement & alternative to single use plastic bags.A revolutionary bag like no other in the market!WHY CHOOSE EKO?1. Eko practices as it preaches. We are grassroots social change, actively partaking in many ways to live more sustainable & bring awareness to the market.2. Save 20% Off Retail Price before it hits the market.3. Free Worldwide Shipping4. Get a Free Fruit & Veg Bag5. Get the best quality reusable bag in the world & support Australian company.We've developed ekobuddy so, single-use plastics bags don’t end up in our food, oceans and landfills. Also, to protect our sea life, sea mammals, sea birds. The market does not have quality accessible reusable bags and their needs to be a replacement /alternative that works and that people want to use and be seen with.

Adheres to fair trade working environments. For example, part of the product is made from women working at home, an initiative for Bangladesh women to be close to family during their long working hours to support their families.
The designs are fun and stylish and fits in your pocket! (You will want to be seen with one!).
Creative design features, helping to make the shopping experience easy and comfortable.
An eco bag that inspires humanity to shop smarter, creating awareness of the huge plastic habits & waste problems in Australia & around the world.

Eko is executing a rewards platform for their customers and giving 5% of net profit back to this reward platform rewarding people for their support in NOT using single-use plastics. THE PLASTIC PROBLEM IN AUSTRALIAAustralia is the second highest producers of waste in the world, per person.
Australians use 4 billion plastic bags a year
That's over 10 million new bags being used every day
50 million of these end up in our waterways and oceans
Plastic bags are only used for 12 minutes but they last for ever!
They are non biodegradable, endangering and killing our animals and are toxic for the earth.
Australians use enough plastic bags per year that if these were tied together they would stretch around the world 24 times

THIS IS NOT OK!But we just don’t think about it because we don’t see it! Think about it next time you shop.​Your 12 minutes of shopping convenience can make a difference!Out of sight out of mind right?It's time rid the plastic waste problem. HELP SAVE OUR OCEAN & PLANET BY CHANGING OUR CONSUMPTION HABITS!​Less Waste = More Life For the planet, for the animals & for your health. COME'ON AUSSIES!!! WE GOT THIS!If each Australian family used just one less plastic shopping bag each week,Australians would save 253 million plastic bags a year.Thats just one ""No Bag, Thanks!"" for just 12minutes a day!Together we can create a better world for generations to come.Let's do this!#saynotosingleuseplasticsChoose to Reduce & Reuse with Eko Buddy!The best alternative & replacement to single use plastic bags.It's feels good to Say ""No Bag thanks!"" and knowing your part of the solution.1 Eko Buddy - Replaces about 500+Plastic bags / per person / per year!That's an average of 5000 plastic bags saved!Otherwise ending up into landfills, our oceans and endangering animals.Help save the planet when you shop!Make a difference, shop with style and be kind for the environment THE EKO SOLUTIONOur mission is to inspire as many shoppers as possible to change their plastic habits and share our passion for an environmentally friendly planet. How to Support Eko Join us on this journey & help Eko go to production so these beautiful little bags can be easily accessible & available to all from all stores & super markets.
Pre-order an Eko bag to support our up-cycled purpose project & help us go to production.
Tell your friends & family about Eko buddy.
Spread the love & awareness about the plastic problem in Australia and choose to refuse, reduce, reuse.
Please like & follow us on social media to stay in the loop for when the bags will be ready.
Share this crowding funding page.
Share our videos on social media.
Tag @ekobuddyau in any eko plastic free life & when you get your bag.
Tag #ekorevolution for any photos on your plastic free living.
If you like Eko please send us a photo/video of you saying 'Hi Eko, yes I'd play with you'. This will help us pitch to Woolworth's, Coles & other major stores to stock Eko bags.
On Instagram @ekobuddyau

JOIN THE EKO REVOLUTION!@ekobuddyau SustainabilityOur manufactures have great work ethics and encourage women to work from home. Eko comes with no extra packaging for as little impact on the environment as possible. We use organic screen printing. Upcycled Purpose ProjectBeautiful design, sustainable reusable bags made from recycled plastic bottles & discarded plastic waste. Production StageWe have gone through 4x generations of prototyping and have now finalized the best looking, collapsible, easy to store, easy to remember bag on the market, with a sustainable production line ready to go. We have Woolworth & Coles pre-approved manufacture ready (see updates for a video of Eko - in Production). Eko Bags are Australia owned, designed in Bondi Beach and made friendly in Bangladesh. Use of Funds
100% of all funds will go towards creating the first production of EKO BUDDY bags and effectively delivering them to market.
Eko buddy needs 5,000 unit sales for our first initial production run (minimum order quantity).
All factory costs for fabric engineering, pattern making & prototyping (4 generations).
Legal costs with patent & corporate structuring.
Digital marketing.
Website Development & Design Costs
Stretch goal of $180,000

Founders StoryEko was born from a shopping experience in Europe then to witness the amount of plastics being used in Australia, something just had to be done.“After living in Germany for 2.5 years and having to pay for plastic bags at the grocery store, it was only a matter of weeks before I changed my ways. Living now back in Australia and seeing the amount of single-use plastic bags being used I had to do something. It was through a nice meditation where I saw the finished product in the form of a ‘baby sleeping bag’! Support Eko Today!JOIN THE EKO REVOLUTION!on Facebook & Instagram@ekobuddyau",20.0,0,"1 Campaign

Our research

Our research provides relevant findings in how new species appear. Volcanic crater lakes are isolated habitats that are particularly well suited to investigating ecological and evolutionary divergence and modes of speciation. Cichlid fish species from crater lakes of western Nicaragua make up a perfect and unique system for comparative analysis of colonization and speciation. Cichlids have speciated considerably within and among crater lakes, forming small adaptive radiations of up to six endemic species in each crater lake. Hence, Nicaraguan crater lakes offer a replicated setting for examining the evolutionary history of colonization events that may be independent across lakes and species. Studying these species, we have reported cases of sympatric and allopatric speciation, convergence, parallel evolution and a wide range of processes related to adaptation and evolution of species.

Find it in spanish here (lee sobre esto en español aquí: https://aixadelolmo.wordpress.com/)

Nevertheless, this system is so complex that much more research will be needed in order to fully understand all the information that this system is providing on how species diversify. Our project aims to continue with this task, and it is becoming more relevant given that a huge canal comparable to the Panama Canal is going to be built across Nicaragua, and will probably affect or destroy these unique ecosystems.

If you are interested in reading more about some of these studys, please email me. And if you want to follow our trip I will be posting frecuently in my blog: https://aixadelolmo.wordpress.com/

How we are funded and what your donations do

Our group works at the National Museum of Natural History of Madrid and most of the project is financed by this institution. Unfortunatelly, the project grant does not fund tripfields for interns, so your donations are needed to cover flights, lodging and food during the month that two of us will be spending in Nicaragua. Our total budget for accommodation, food, gear and flights is about 3500$, For now, we have stablished a lower budget in order to cover the basics: flights and some accommodation.

To thank you, we are very happy to offer our perks, which are beautiful printed photographs taken in our trip, so that you can share with us a bit of this magical country. You can email me with preferences if you like (I will be posting some of the pictures in my blog).

Difussion is always a nice way to help too!

Join together with Friends of Pinnacles, Pinnacles National Park Foundation, the Access Fund, the American Alpine Club, Pacific Edge Climbing Gym, Stokes Signs and the people who started PCAD, Mountain Tools to support the Pinnacles Trail Crew at California’s newest National Park. You will learn skills, make some friends and have a lot of fun!

 

Every person must register. EACH registration includes:  ($15 for each adult and $10 for each child/student) Park admission, group camping Friday and Saturday nights, Saturday night meal, auction (1 ticket included, more can be purchased. See other levels of registration), commemorative T-Shirt and climbing on Sunday. Don’t miss a great opportunity!

Monies raised will go towards more events at the Pinnacles, donations back to Friends of Pinnacles, Pinnacles NP Foundation, the Access Fund, the American Alpine Club, and youth climbing programs.

Pass this along to all your climbing partners and friends! Join us for some fun!!! Thanks for your support!

Who are we?

We are a Community Supported Agriculture program in the Wairarapa (the first of its kind in New Zealand) following Agroecological and EcoDynamic principles based on food quality and inclusive thinking. Help us change the future of food!

 

We are dedicated to growing and maintaining high quality, local, seasonal and fresh organic produce in a sustainable and ethical way.The CSA creates an environment where individuals can grow a connection with their food and the land. A CSA basically means people support a local farmer by purchasing a weekly harvest share of seasonal fruit, veggies and other products grown on the farm such as eggs. We have been running our CSA for around two decades and currently have around 130 families relying on our produce.

Big changes leading towards a better future!

We are currently in the middle of an infrastructural change. We have decided to downsize our farm and become more efficient by doing everything from our home in Greytown as opposed to leasing a farm in Masterton (40 minute commute). We have called this move, “The Shift” which started to unfold in June of this year and is an ongoing process. The Shift will allow us to increase our sustainability, cut down on our fuel consumption and most importantly increase the access our members and community will have to visit the farm and learn from our knowledge and expertise. We want to be able to turn our piece of paradise into a paradise those interested can enjoy and prosper from too. Our joined vision for the farm is to be able to develop it further as a community knowledge and experience center for food quality and environmental care.

Please take a few moments to watch this wonderful interview Sam Buys took with Frank van Steensel about what a CSA stands for
column4:
showinfo=0"">

 

We need your help!

Years of investment has provided us with plentiful first hand experience and knowledge however in order to continue doing what we love we are now asking something back.We need financial help with purchasing material for finishing our new packing shed, installing a chilling unit and insulation for our new chiller, irrigation and buying some of the tractor equipment back from the previous land owner as we are struggling to juggle funds to continue our CSA the way we would like to. We believe that this is an amazing opportunity for our farm, family and will ultimately serve our members and community better. Let us show you around our new property so far in the video below, with a the start of a new packing shed, greenhouses, permaculture gardens, spiraling herb garden, adorable farm animals and so much more!
column6:
showinfo=0"">

 

Spread the word!

CSAs are becoming more and more common around the world. There are many well established in America and they are beginning to pop up across the ditch in Australia, however here in New Zealand knowledge is limited as they have not yet been well explored. This makes it harder for us to gain members and raise funds. By joining or donating to/with us you are aiding in the worldwide movement towards a more sustainable and restorative way of agriculture.

One of the best ways in which you can help us would be to share this campaign with your friends and family on social networking sites and help us spread the word!

We hope you share in this vision and will help us turn this vision into reality. Your contribution makes all the difference.

With much gratitude,

Your Farmers, Frank and Josje and the Wairarapa Eco Farm team.

 

 

Award winners for :

• Biosea Horticulture
• Be Pure Paddock To Plate

Why Support Us?
<div><ul>
• Huge cost savings on electricity
• Create a greener future for our planet
• Utilizes a free, safe, clean, renewable resource
• A conscious business with a conscience

We have the solution to maximizing efficiency in creating solar power. Our commercial dual axis tracking frame is the only roof top tracking frame that will be commercially available in North America.

In contrast to existing fixed frame systems, Energycostsaver Inc.'s solar solutions has a unique moving frame that tracks and maximizes the sun's energy throughout the day and seasonally so that the solar panels are always facing the Sun. This means 40% more efficiency than fixed solar panels.
We are now ready to take the next step to commercialize our system and are looking for like-minded people to assist.
The Opportunity

Besides reducing carbon emissions and realizing tremendous financial savings, solar energy is a clean, reliable power with little maintenance and is a free resource/fuel.  Solar energy could conceivably represent 20% of the new electricity supplied in the next 20 years in Canada.  Ten megawatts supplied by a solar farm could service 2500 to 3000 homes but requires 4 to 5 acres of land per megawatt to produce.
There are three primary markets for which our systems will be ideally suited:
1. Flat roofs found on most warehouses, schools, shopping centres, auto dealerships and big box stores
2. Solar farms on or off-the-grid, to service First Nation Reserves, northern oil installations and large farming operations
3. Mobile systems for temporary locations, small farms and acreages.

We are working with First Nations communities to assist in the assembly and installation of our first solar system in Alberta.  Our system will be able to employ trainees from all education and skill levels, and some who may be otherwise unemployable.

The Alderville First Nations Solar Farm is the first to be developed and owned by a First Nations community. Typical of new and innovative technologies, there was a steep learning curve and many obstacles to be overcome. The issues were resolved and Chief Marsden is very happy with the result and has been kind enough to offer to share information with us. The Alderville First Nations Solar Farm was a huge undertaking and demonstrates the vision of the Chief and Council who have created a legacy that will benefit their people for generations to come.

We currently have letters of intent from several First Nation communities in Alberta to install solar fields on their tribal lands.  Our agreement calls for the training and the active involvement of First Nations in the assembly and installation of the solar fields.
What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We are requesting $35,000 CDN to complete our commercial dual axis tracking frame patent application, to copyright our trade mark and have a prototype built for testing prior to large scale manufacturing.

column1: In exchange for every $25, $50 or $100 you generously donate, you will receive an Energycostsaver Inc. Preferred Share certificate which will bear interest at 5% with principal and interest repayable in two years from the date of the successful raising of the required funds.

The Impact

The Green Revolution has just started and we, and our partners, will be in the forefront with innovative solar solutions.

Over 50% of Alberta's electricity is generated from coal fired power plants, all of which are being phased out.  All of the new plants to be built in Alberta will be using natural gas. 

Alberta's power generation is at capacity and unable to meet the expected doubling of demand over the next 20 years.  To meet demand, billions of dollars will need to be spent on new power generation, resulting in huge increases in the cost of electricity.  

Our commercial dual axis solar tracking system will mitigate this essential and costly operating expense.  Our system will provide lower power bills and eliminate any future rate increases.

Solar power is the perfect Private/Public Partnership vehicle, providing tax incentives and long-term stable income for investors, and low cost power for the user.  Governments have thousands of roof tops that could be used to generate electricity at no cost to the government, and give investors attractive investment returns.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support Energycostsaver Inc. financially, please know that you can help us in other ways too.  Please share information about our desire to develop practical solar solutions that harness the sun's power in a clean environmental manner as well as helping to train and employ communities to support their own energy needs.
Thank you so much for your support!

column5: > Hi Everyone, I would like you all to know that on February 2nd, 2016, at 2:16 a.m, my mother passed away, she was an amazing woman, mother, and wife. Some people say she lost her fight to cancer but I think she won her fight. I am putting this project in memory of my mom, Jennifer Garrison.

column1: <span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

Hi, my name is Kelsey, I am a student in high school and i am in a class called quest (an entrepreneurial class). My project is trying to help relieve pain in cancer patients by creating a heat/cooling pad that is freezable and microwavable. 

This project is very important to me because my mom has type 4 endometrial cancer (uterine cancer) . Which has metastasis (spread) to her brain. 

I am making these to help cancer patients and to spread cancer awareness.

What We Need

With the funding I will be receiving it will be used on materials and a webpage for my product. 

Materials
• 100% cotton so it will be microwave safe
• Essential oils
• 100% cotton threads
• needles
• rice

Also with other donations I will be researching what better materials I can use. 

The Impact

Like how i said a few paragraphs above i will be donating some of the pads to organizations with cancer patients. I hope this product i make will be beneficial to cancer patients everywhere so they can feel relief and comfort. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you aren't able to donate anything, the best thing you can do is tell people about my products, and this page! 

Ribbon Colors

Pink is for Breast Cancer, 
Teal is for Ovarian Cancer,
White is for Lung Cancer,
Purple is for Pancreatic Cancer and Leiomyosarcoma,
Orange is for Leukemia and Kidney Cancer,
Navy is for Colon Cancer,
Burgundy is for Multiple Myeloma,
Grey is for Brain Cancer,
Blue is for Prostate Cancer,
Gold is for Childhood Cancer and Osteusarcoma,
Burgundy and Ivory is for Head and Neck Cancer,
Lime is for Lymphoma,
Peach is for Uterine Cancer,
Teal and White is for Cervical Cancer,
Yellow is for Sarcoma/Bone Cancer,
Green is for Liver Cancer and Adrenal Cancer,
Periwinkle is for Esophageal Cancer and Stomach Cancer,
Teal, Pink, and White is for Thyroid Cancer,
Lavender is for All Cancers,
Orchid is for Testicular Cancer,
Amber is for Appendix Cancer,
Marigold, Blue, and Purple is for Bladder Cancer,
Zebra Print is for Carinoid Cancer and Endocrine Cancer,
Rainbow is for Adrenocortical Cancer.
If I missed any, or got any wrong, please feel free to tell me. Thank you all!!!
","Update: Hi Everyone, I would like you all to know that on February 2nd, 2016, at 2:16 a.m, my mother passed away, she was an amazing woman, mother, and wife. Some people say she lost her fight to cancer but I think she won her fight. I am putting this project in memory of my mom, Jennifer Garrison.
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Kelsey, I am a student in high school and i am in a class called quest (an entrepreneurial class). My project is trying to help relieve pain in cancer patients by creating a heat/cooling pad that is freezable and microwavable. This project is very important to me because my mom has type 4 endometrial cancer (uterine cancer) . Which has metastasis (spread) to her brain. I am making these to help cancer patients and to spread cancer awareness.What We NeedWith the funding I will be receiving it will be used on materials and a webpage for my product. Materials
100% cotton so it will be microwave safe
Essential oils
100% cotton threads
needles
rice

Also with other donations I will be researching what better materials I can use. The ImpactLike how i said a few paragraphs above i will be donating some of the pads to organizations with cancer patients. My name is Tisa Zito. I am a filmmaker who is wildly passionate about getting out and documenting
column2: >mother nature.  Over the past years I have been impassioned
column3: > to document bow hunts and in particular elk bow hunts. This will be my third elk hunt. Each year I return with a film and each year I aim to make them better. Last years was decent but this year I hope to up the quality and storyline.

column1: I will be following a Cherokee Indian on his search for the perfect bull that he will take home to
column2: >feed himself and family.  The terrain we will be covering can be quite grueling to navigate. Without giving away the exact location we will be in the the mountains of eastern Oregon at elevation 7200 feet.

column1: If you help me in this project you will be helping myself and my gear get to our location site. Your funds will go towards a few dehydrated meals for my journey and most importantly your funds will help me raise the quality of production by renting a better lens and *fingers crossed* a drone to capture the aw and beauty of the landscape.
If I don’t reach my entire goal, I’m still doing this. I just want to do this right.

I feel this film will educate viewers and bring understanding to people regarding how difficult it is to hunt for your own food by way of the bow.  I have a track record of successfully making films in various topics. Please take a look at other work of mine. Www.Vimeo.com/TisaZito   This project is very near and dear to my heart and so far expenses have 100% come out of pocket.
There are two primary concerns next to staying warm at night and not getting eating by creatures of prey, that is that the hunter makes the kill and that I of course get that kill on film.
I completely understand if you can’t contribute. Please, if you know hunting and nature enthusiasts pass this along.

","My name is Tisa Zito. I am a filmmaker who is wildly passionate about getting out and documenting mother nature.  Over the past years I have been impassioned to document bow hunts and in particular elk bow hunts. This will be my third elk hunt. Each year I return with a film and each year I aim to make them better. Last years was decent but this year I hope to up the quality and storyline.

I will be following a Cherokee Indian on his search for the perfect bull that he will take home to feed himself and family.  The terrain we will be covering can be quite grueling to navigate. Without giving away the exact location we will be in the the mountains of eastern Oregon at elevation 7200 feet.

If you help me in this project you will be helping myself and my gear get to our location site. Your funds will go towards a few dehydrated meals for my journey and most importantly your funds will help me raise the quality of production by renting a better lens and *fingers crossed* a drone to capture the aw and beauty of the landscape.
If I don’t reach my entire goal, I’m still doing this. I just want to do this right.

I feel this film will educate viewers and bring understanding to people regarding how difficult it is to hunt for your own food by way of the bow.  I have a track record of successfully making films in various topics. Please take a look at other work of mine. Www.Vimeo.com/TisaZito   This project is very near and dear to my heart and so far expenses have 100% come out of pocket.
There are two primary concerns next to staying warm at night and not getting eating by creatures of prey, that is that the hunter makes the kill and that I of course get that kill on film.
I completely understand if you can’t contribute. Please, if you know hunting and nature enthusiasts pass this along.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

  • Ir a la parte de abajo para ESPAÑOL y PORTUGUÉS
The
environmental and climate crisis has been an increasingly constant concern
in many places around the world. From the young and elderly, women and
men, to institutions, companies and governments, all have expressed concern
about the environmental costs that have been provoked due to unrestrained
economic growth and rampant consumption.
In
this reality the United Nations proposed a new economic model, the “Green Economy”, beginning in the 1990s. The plan was designed to assist governments
in ""greening"" their economies by reshaping and refocusing policies,
investments and spending towards an emerging range of sectors. These areas
include “clean” technologies, renewable energies, hydroelectric dams, wind
farms, renewed water services, green transportation, eco friendly waste
management, building green cities, agriculture and promoting sustainable
forests.
On the other hand, there are a plurality of original peoples, indigenous and
farmworkers, in many parts of the world who believe in other world views, and
whose connection with nature and the land has been historic and
constant. Yet over the course of the last two or even three decades,
specifically in Latin America, these indigenous peoples have been displaced or
evicted from their ancestral lands to make way for megaprojects under the guise
of ‘sustainable development and conservation of the environment. In many cases,
these people have been criminalized, even charged under anti-terror laws, as
they seek to have a voice and resist this particular kind of “development”. In
Latin America rate of murders of environmental activists, mostly indigenous,
have increased. These individuals have struggled to stop clean energy
megaprojects, industrial agriculture, deforestation, mining, among others. murders
of activists.
<blockquote style=""text-align: center
Many
of the people being killed in these struggles are not only protecting their
local land and water. By keeping carbon in the ground, and defending ecological
farming practices, they are showing the rest of us how to prevent catastrophic
climate change.
Our
project is to rigorously investigate the real impact of this new model of the
Green Economy. Likewise, we seek to expose different alternatives that are
being created from below in response to environmental and the climate change
crisis.
Goals:
1. Creating a Green Economy watch dog organization, essentially a website or
digital platform where the following materials will document and make public
the relationship between the Green Economy and Human Rights violations:
<ul><li> Interviews, expert analysis, articles and reports made during the period in
which we will tour and document Mexico-Central America
<ul><li>
Multimedia, Photographs, video reports
<ul><li>
Maps and documents
<b>This material will be directed towards and made free and accessible for
the indigenous and farmworking communities, their leadership organizations,
NGOs, non-profits and independent media.
Production and final publication of a book-report derived from research and
interviews conducted in the course of the trip, with the aim of observing the
link between the Green Economy and human rights violations against indigenous
peoples, farmworkers, minorities, small-scalle producers, and placing emphasis
on the role of women.
The
book will be made available in print as well as in a digital format. The
electronic version will be accompanied by an interactive and dynamic map, which
will allow for the user to locate in each of the countries and regions of
Mexico and Central America, the major projects of the Green Economy model. The
map will also provide visual and textual elements that identify and locate the
major transnational companies as well as their financing, and the groups of
people who are directly and indirectly negatively impacted by the actions of
these companies.
Our commitment is to deepen our research and reach the
places where the commercial or mass media fail to reach.
<blockquote>
<h4 align=""justify"" style=""text-align: justify
kindly request that you be part of this project, give it a push, and support
not only independent and ethical journalism, but to better our understanding of
the dramatic changes to our environment, the people most affected, and to
emphasize ground-up democratic solutions.
<h2 align=""center"">
About the team members:
Renata Bessi (Brazil) is a freelance journalist. She has written for : Truthout the Americas
programand collaborates with the Mexico
based Subversiones Communications Agency. Bessi was a finalist for the
Libero Badaro of Jornalismo"" award in 2014 in Brazil, with her
exhaustive report <i>“Transposição do
Rio São Francisco ameaça terras indígenas”.  She has
also published in Upside Down World, Agência Pública de Periodismo Investigativoand Repórter
Brazil.
Santiago Navarro F. (Mexico) is a
freelance journalist and photographer. Navarro F is a member of the the SubversionesCommunications Agency and is a collaborator of the
community radio station of the Autonomous University of Chapingo. Navarro F has
also published in Truthout, the Americas
program, and Upside Down World.
The documentary <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jHNbfftjA4c"" rel=""noopener nofollow""><span>""Aquí estamos, no estamos
extintos (2015)"" (Here we
are, we are not extinct) of Renata Bessi and
Santiago Navarro F., was recognized by the jury of the International Film and
Video Festival of Indigenous Peoples - 2015 as best documentary in the category
of socio-organizational process of Indigenous Peoples. The documentary was
exhibited in Chile, Argentina and Spain.
Clayton Conn  is a photographer and journalist whose
work has been published in such outlets as Free Speech Radio News, Upside Down
World, and NACLA. He was formerly a member of the editorial group of
Desinformémonos. Since 2014 he has been the Mexico correspondent for TeleSUR
English.
All the names of contributors to this campaign will be on our site: avispa.org
If you cannot contribute but still want to
help us, please share our campaign.<span>
Get the word out!  You can
share directly from this page with Indiegogo share tools.
VERSIÓN ESPAÑOL
La crisis ambiental y climática ha sido una preocupación constate en
las diversas geografías del planeta. Desde jóvenes y ancianos, mujeres y hombres,
hasta instituciones, empresas y gobiernos han mostrado su preocupación sobre
los costos ambientales que ha provocado el crecimiento económico y el consumo
desenfrenado.
Es en ese sentido que, las Naciones Unidas
propusieron un nuevo modelo económico, la Economía Verde, cuya implementación
fue intensificada desde la década de 1990, diseñada para asistir a los
gobiernos en el ""reverdecimiento"" de sus economías mediante la
reestructuración y la reorientación de sus políticas, inversiones y gastos
hacia una gama de sectores, tales como las tecnologías limpias, las energías renovables,
como hidreletricas y parques eólicos, los servicios de agua, el transporte
verde, el tratamiento de los desechos, la edificación de ciudades verdes y la
agricultura, los bosques sostenibles
y las redes de Áreas Protegidas para venta de creditos de carbono -también conocidos como permisos de contaminación.
Por otra parte, están los pueblos,
principalmente indígenas y campesinos, quienes desde siempre han tenido un
vinculo espiritual con la naturaleza. Pero desde las últimas dos décadas, principalmente
en países de Latinoamérica, han sido desplazados de sus territorios ancestrales
para dar paso a los megaproyectos de Desarrollo Sustentable o en nombre de la
conservación de la naturaleza. En muchos casos, se les ha criminalizado hasta
con leyes antiterroristas por intentar detener este tipo de desarrollo. En
Latinoamérica ha aumentado el índice de asesinatos de activistas ambientales,
en su mayoría indígenas, que han luchado por detener megaproyectos de energías
limpias, la agricultura industrial, la deforestación, la minería, entre otros.
<h4 align=""center""><b>Muchos de los muertos en estas luchas no
sólo han protegido su tierra ancestral y el agua. Al mantener el carbono en el
suelo y defender las prácticas de agricultura ecológica han mostrado al resto
del planeta una alternativa real y concreta para contrarrestar la catástrofe
climática, la cual ya se ha comenzado agudizar en diversas geografías.
Nuestro siguiente proyecto consiste en
investigar con rigurosidad el impacto real de este nuevo modelo de economía
verde. Así mismo, buscamos retomar otras alternativas como respuesta a la
crisis ambiental y climática.
Pedimos que seas parte de este
proyecto, con tus donaciones podremos realizar parte del viaje a México y Centroamérica.
En este recorrido visitaremos los principales lugares afectados y
criminalizados.
Objetivos:
1. Creación de un Observatorio de la
Economía Verde, una plataforma web donde se concentrarán los siguientes materiales
que evidenciarán las relaciones entre Economía Verde y violaciones de Derechos
Humanos:
<ul><li>
§  Entrevistas, análisis, artículos y reportajes realizados durante
el recorrido por México-Centroamérica
<ul><li>
§  Videos y foto-galería
<ul><li>
§  Mapas y documentos
<h4>Esta material estará libre para las
comunidades indígenas y campesinas, organizaciones no gubernamentales sin fines
de lucro, así como para medios libres e independientes.
2. Producción de un libro-reportaje a
partir de investigaciones y de entrevistas hechas en el recorrido, con el
objetivo de relacionar la economía verde y las violaciones de derechos humanos
hacia los pueblos indígenas, campesinos, negros, pescadores artesanales, con
especial atención al papel de las mujeres.
Este libro será impreso y producido en
un formato multimedia. La versión electrónica será acompañada por un mapa
interactivo y dinámico, que permita ubicar en cada uno de los países de México
y Centroamérica los principales proyectos de este modelo de economía verde.
Así mismo, en dicho mapa podremos
ubicar el nombre de las empresas y las principales líneas transnacionales de
financiamiento. Ubicaremos los principales pueblos indígenas o campesinos que
están siendo afectados y, geográficamente, podemos identificar los lugares a
donde han sido asesinados los activistas ambientales y lideres indígenas.
Nuestro compromiso es profundizar la
investigación y llegar a los lugares donde los medios comerciales o masivos no
llegan.
<h4 style=""text-align: center
column2: >Atrévete a ser parte de este proyecto y

column1: dale un empujón, apoya el periodismo independiente.
<b>                      Sobre
los integrantes:
Renata Bessi, brasileña,
es periodista independiente. Periodista freelancer<span>  de TruthOut, Programa de las Américas y colaboradora de la <i>Agencia
Autónoma de Comunicación Subversiones.
Finalista del premio “<i>Líbero Badaró de
Jornalismo”, 2014, en Brasil, con el reportaje “Transposição do Rio São Francisco ameaça
terras indígenas”. Ha
publicado en medios como Upside Down World, Agência Pública de Periodismo Investigativo y Repórter
Brasil.
Santiago Navarro F,
mexicano, periodista freelancer  y fotógrafo. Colaborador de la Agencia Autónoma de
Comunicación, Subversiones. Colaborador de Radio de la Universidad Autónoma
Chapingo. Ha publicado en medios como: Truthout , Americas
program , Upside Down World.
<span>La realización del documental <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jHNbfftjA4c"" rel=""noopener nofollow""><span>""Aquí estamos,
no estamos extintos (2015)"", de
Renata Bessi y Santiago Navarro F., fue reconocido, por el Jurado Internacional del Festival Internacional de Cine y Video de los Pueblos Indígenas – 2015,
como mejor documental en la categoría Proceso socio-organizativo de los Pueblos

Indígenas. El documental fue exhibido en Chile, Argentina y España.

Clayton
Conn, es fotógrafo y periodista
cuyo trabajo ha sido publicado en espacios como Free Speech Radio News, Upside
Down World, y NACLA. Anteriormente era miembro del equipo editorial de la
revista Desinformémonos. Desde el 2014 ha sido corresponsal de teleSUR English.
Versão Portugués
Mercantilização
da crise ambiental: conflitos da economia verde e os povos originários
A crise ambiental e climática tem sido uma
preocupação constante nas diversas geografias do planeta. Desde jovens e
anciões, mulheres e homens até instituições, empresas e governos, há um
consenso que demonstra preocupação sobre os custos ambientais provocados pelo
crescimento econômico e o consumo desenfreado.
Neste
sentido, as Nações Unidas propuseram um novo modelo econômico, a chamada
Economia Verde, cuja implementação foi intensificada na década de 1990 e que está
em pleno desenvolvimento em nossos dias. Tal economia foi desenhada para
assistir os governos nacionais no “reverdecimento” de suas economias mediante a
reestruturação e a reorientação de suas políticas, investimentos e gastos no
que diz respeito a uma séria de setores, como as tecnologias limpas, as
energias renováveis, hidrelétricas e parques eólicos, projetos de mineração, transporte
verde, a edificação de cidades verdes e bosques sustentáveis.
column3:
/>

Se por uma lado estão os governos, as

column1: empresas e as instituições internacionais de financiamento, impulsionando a
Economia Verde em todo o mundo, por outro lado, estão os povos, principalmente
indígenas e campesinos, que sempre tiveram vínculo espiritual com a natureza.
Nas últimas duas décadas, especialmente nos países da América Latina, estes
povos vêm sendo expulsos de seus territórios para dar lugar a megaprojetos
enquadrados no chamado ‘desenvolvimento sustentável’.
Em muitos casos eles estão sendo criminalizados
com leis antiterrorismo por tentar deter este tipo de desenvolvimento. Na
América Latina, há aumentado o índice de assassinatos e de ameaças a ativistas
ambientais que lutam contra<span>  megaprojetos
de energias limpas, agricultura industrial, o desmatamento, projetos de
mineração, hidrelétricas, entre outros, como revela o relatório intitulado “Quantos mais?”, da organização Global Witness. Segundo
o documento, de 2015, 75% dos assassinatos aconteceram na América Latina.
<h4>Nosso projeto consiste em investigar com
rigorosidade os impactos reais do novo modelo de Economia Verde e retomar as <span>alternativas destes povos à crise ambiental e climática, com
foco no México e América Central.
<h3><b>Objetivos:
1.Chegar até comunidades
indígenas e campesinas do México e América Central para reportar as situações
que estão enfrentando e seus modos de vida.
2.Criação de um Observatório da Economia
Verde, uma página web onde devem ser concentrados os seguintes materiais que
evidenciarão as relações entre Economia Verde e as violações de Direitos
Humanos:
Entrevistas, análises, artigos e reportagens realizados durante
viagens aos povos do México e América Central
Vídeos e galeria de fotos
Mapas e documentos
<span>Este material será livre para o uso das
comunidades indígenas, campesinas, organizações sem fins de lucro, movimentos
sociais, assim como para os meios livres e independentes.
3.Produção de um livro-reportagem a partir
das investigações e entrevistas feitas durante as viagens às comunidades, com o
objetivo de relacionar a Economia Verde e as violações de direitos humanos, com
especial atenção à situação das mulheres.
Este livro deve ser impresso e
produzido em formato multimídia. A versão eletrônica será acompanhada por um
mapa interativo e dinâmico que permita localizar cada um dos países, os
principais projetos do modelo de Economia Verde, os principais povos e os
assassinatos de ativistas ambientais.
<h4>Nosso compromisso é aprofundar a
investigação e chegar nos lugares em que os meios comerciais ou massivos não
chegam.
Atreva-se a fazer parte deste projeto.
Apoie o jornalismo independente.
<h3><b>                           Sobre
os integrantes:
Renata Bessi, brasileira,
é jornalista freelancer de TruthOut, Programa de las
Américas e colaboradora da Agencia Autónoma de Comunicación Subversiones, com trabalhos publicados em  Upside Down World, Agência Pública de Periodismo Investigativo e Repórter
Brasil. Finalista do prêmio “Líbero Badaró de Jornalismo”, 2014, no Brasil, com a reportagem “Transposição do
Rio São Francisco ameaça terras indígenas”.
Santiago Navarro F.,
mexicano, jornalista freelancer  e fotógrafo. Forma
parte da Agencia Autónoma de Comunicación, Subversiones. Colaborador da Radio da Universidade Autônoma Chapingo. Tem
publicado em veículos como: Truthout , Americas
program , Upside Down World.
<span>O
documentário ""Aquí estamos, no estamos extintos (2015)"", de Renata
Bessi e Santiago Navarro F., foi reconhecido pelo jurado do<i>Festival Internacional de
Cine y Video de los Pueblos Indígenas –
2015 como melhor trabalho na categoria “Proceso socio-organizativo

de los Pueblos Indígenas”. Foi exibido no Chile, Argentina e Espanha.

Clayton Conn é fotógrafo e jornalista, cujo trabalho tem
sido publicado em espaços comoFree
Speech Radio News, Upside Down World e NACLA. Foi membro da equipe editorial da
revista Desinformémonos. Desde 2014 é correspondente da teleSUR English, no
México.

Renata Bessi (Brazil) is a freelance journalist. She has written for : Truthout the Americas
programand collaborates with the Mexico
based Subversiones Communications Agency. Bessi was a finalist for the
Libero Badaro of Jornalismo"" award in 2014 in Brazil, with her
exhaustive report “Transposição do
Rio São Francisco ameaça terras indígenas”.  She has
also published in Upside Down World, Agência Pública de Periodismo Investigativoand Repórter
Brazil.
Santiago Navarro F. (Mexico) is a
freelance journalist and photographer. Navarro F is a member of the the SubversionesCommunications Agency and is a collaborator of the
community radio station of the Autonomous University of Chapingo. Navarro F has
also published in Truthout, the Americas
program, and Upside Down World.
The documentary ""Aquí estamos, no estamos
extintos (2015)"" (Here we
are, we are not extinct) of Renata Bessi and
Santiago Navarro F., was recognized by the jury of the International Film and
Video Festival of Indigenous Peoples - 2015 as best documentary in the category
of socio-organizational process of Indigenous Peoples. The documentary was
exhibited in Chile, Argentina and Spain.
Clayton Conn  is a photographer and journalist whose
work has been published in such outlets as Free Speech Radio News, Upside Down
World, and NACLA. He was formerly a member of the editorial group of
Desinformémonos. Since 2014 he has been the Mexico correspondent for TeleSUR
English.

VERSIÓN ESPAÑOL
La crisis ambiental y climática ha sido una preocupación constate en
las diversas geografías del planeta. Desde jóvenes y ancianos, mujeres y hombres,
hasta instituciones, empresas y gobiernos han mostrado su preocupación sobre
los costos ambientales que ha provocado el crecimiento económico y el consumo
desenfrenado.
Es en ese sentido que, las Naciones Unidas
propusieron un nuevo modelo económico, la Economía Verde, cuya implementación
fue intensificada desde la década de 1990, diseñada para asistir a los
gobiernos en el ""reverdecimiento"" de sus economías mediante la
reestructuración y la reorientación de sus políticas, inversiones y gastos
hacia una gama de sectores, tales como las tecnologías limpias, las energías renovables,
como hidreletricas y parques eólicos, los servicios de agua, el transporte
verde, el tratamiento de los desechos, la edificación de ciudades verdes y la
agricultura, los bosques sostenibles
y las redes de Áreas Protegidas para venta de creditos de carbono -también conocidos como permisos de contaminación.
Por otra parte, están los pueblos,
principalmente indígenas y campesinos, quienes desde siempre han tenido un
vinculo espiritual con la naturaleza. Pero desde las últimas dos décadas, principalmente
en países de Latinoamérica, han sido desplazados de sus territorios ancestrales
para dar paso a los megaproyectos de Desarrollo Sustentable o en nombre de la
conservación de la naturaleza. En muchos casos, se les ha criminalizado hasta
con leyes antiterroristas por intentar detener este tipo de desarrollo. En
Latinoamérica ha aumentado el índice de asesinatos de activistas ambientales,
en su mayoría indígenas, que han luchado por detener megaproyectos de energías
limpias, la agricultura industrial, la deforestación, la minería, entre otros.
Muchos de los muertos en estas luchas no
sólo han protegido su tierra ancestral y el agua. Al mantener el carbono en el
suelo y defender las prácticas de agricultura ecológica han mostrado al resto
del planeta una alternativa real y concreta para contrarrestar la catástrofe
climática, la cual ya se ha comenzado agudizar en diversas geografías.
Nuestro siguiente proyecto consiste en
investigar con rigurosidad el impacto real de este nuevo modelo de economía
verde. Así mismo, buscamos retomar otras alternativas como respuesta a la
crisis ambiental y climática.
Pedimos que seas parte de este
proyecto, con tus donaciones podremos realizar parte del viaje a México y Centroamérica.
En este recorrido visitaremos los principales lugares afectados y
criminalizados.
Objetivos:
1. Creación de un Observatorio de la
Economía Verde, una plataforma web donde se concentrarán los siguientes materiales
que evidenciarán las relaciones entre Economía Verde y violaciones de Derechos
Humanos:
§  Entrevistas, análisis, artículos y reportajes realizados durante
el recorrido por México-Centroamérica
§  Videos y foto-galería
§  Mapas y documentos
Esta material estará libre para las
comunidades indígenas y campesinas, organizaciones no gubernamentales sin fines
de lucro, así como para medios libres e independientes.
2. Producción de un libro-reportaje a
partir de investigaciones y de entrevistas hechas en el recorrido, con el
objetivo de relacionar la economía verde y las violaciones de derechos humanos
hacia los pueblos indígenas, campesinos, negros, pescadores artesanales, con
especial atención al papel de las mujeres.
Este libro será impreso y producido en
un formato multimedia. La versión electrónica será acompañada por un mapa
interactivo y dinámico, que permita ubicar en cada uno de los países de México
y Centroamérica los principales proyectos de este modelo de economía verde.
Así mismo, en dicho mapa podremos
ubicar el nombre de las empresas y las principales líneas transnacionales de
financiamiento. Ubicaremos los principales pueblos indígenas o campesinos que
están siendo afectados y, geográficamente, podemos identificar los lugares a
donde han sido asesinados los activistas ambientales y lideres indígenas.
Nuestro compromiso es profundizar la
investigación y llegar a los lugares donde los medios comerciales o masivos no
llegan.
Atrévete a ser parte de este proyecto y
dale un empujón, apoya el periodismo independiente.
Sobre
los integrantes:
Renata Bessi, brasileña,
es periodista independiente. Periodista freelancer  de TruthOut, Programa de las Américas y colaboradora de la Agencia
Autónoma de Comunicación Subversiones.
Finalista del premio “Líbero Badaró de
Jornalismo”, 2014, en Brasil, con el reportaje “Transposição do Rio São Francisco ameaça
terras indígenas”. Ha
publicado en medios como Upside Down World, Agência Pública de Periodismo Investigativo y Repórter
Brasil.
Santiago Navarro F,
mexicano, periodista freelancer  y fotógrafo. Colaborador de la Agencia Autónoma de
Comunicación, Subversiones. Colaborador de Radio de la Universidad Autónoma
Chapingo. Ha publicado en medios como: Truthout , Americas
program , Upside Down World.
La realización del documental ""Aquí estamos,
no estamos extintos (2015)"", de
Renata Bessi y Santiago Navarro F., fue reconocido, por el Jurado Internacional del Festival Internacional de Cine y Video de los Pueblos Indígenas – 2015,
como mejor documental en la categoría Proceso socio-organizativo de los Pueblos
Indígenas. El documental fue exhibido en Chile, Argentina y España.Clayton
Conn, es fotógrafo y periodista
cuyo trabajo ha sido publicado en espacios como Free Speech Radio News, Upside
Down World, y NACLA. Anteriormente era miembro del equipo editorial de la
revista Desinformémonos. Desde el 2014 ha sido corresponsal de teleSUR English.
Versão Portugués
Mercantilização
da crise ambiental: conflitos da economia verde e os povos originários
A crise ambiental e climática tem sido uma
preocupação constante nas diversas geografias do planeta. Desde jovens e
anciões, mulheres e homens até instituições, empresas e governos, há um
consenso que demonstra preocupação sobre os custos ambientais provocados pelo
crescimento econômico e o consumo desenfreado.
Neste
sentido, as Nações Unidas propuseram um novo modelo econômico, a chamada
Economia Verde, cuja implementação foi intensificada na década de 1990 e que está
em pleno desenvolvimento em nossos dias. Tal economia foi desenhada para
assistir os governos nacionais no “reverdecimento” de suas economias mediante a
reestruturação e a reorientação de suas políticas, investimentos e gastos no
que diz respeito a uma séria de setores, como as tecnologias limpas, as
energias renováveis, hidrelétricas e parques eólicos, projetos de mineração, transporte
verde, a edificação de cidades verdes e bosques sustentáveis. Se por uma lado estão os governos, as
empresas e as instituições internacionais de financiamento, impulsionando a
Economia Verde em todo o mundo, por outro lado, estão os povos, principalmente
indígenas e campesinos, que sempre tiveram vínculo espiritual com a natureza.
Nas últimas duas décadas, especialmente nos países da América Latina, estes
povos vêm sendo expulsos de seus territórios para dar lugar a megaprojetos
enquadrados no chamado ‘desenvolvimento sustentável’.
Em muitos casos eles estão sendo criminalizados
com leis antiterrorismo por tentar deter este tipo de desenvolvimento. Na
América Latina, há aumentado o índice de assassinatos e de ameaças a ativistas
ambientais que lutam contra  megaprojetos
de energias limpas, agricultura industrial, o desmatamento, projetos de
mineração, hidrelétricas, entre outros, como revela o relatório intitulado “Quantos mais?”, da organização Global Witness. Segundo
o documento, de 2015, 75% dos assassinatos aconteceram na América Latina.
Nosso projeto consiste em investigar com
rigorosidade os impactos reais do novo modelo de Economia Verde e retomar as alternativas destes povos à crise ambiental e climática, com
foco no México e América Central.
Objetivos:
1.Chegar até comunidades
indígenas e campesinas do México e América Central para reportar as situações
que estão enfrentando e seus modos de vida.
2.Criação de um Observatório da Economia
Verde, uma página web onde devem ser concentrados os seguintes materiais que
evidenciarão as relações entre Economia Verde e as violações de Direitos
Humanos:
Entrevistas, análises, artigos e reportagens realizados durante
viagens aos povos do México e América Central
Vídeos e galeria de fotos
Mapas e documentos
Este material será livre para o uso das
comunidades indígenas, campesinas, organizações sem fins de lucro, movimentos
sociais, assim como para os meios livres e independentes.
3.Produção de um livro-reportagem a partir
das investigações e entrevistas feitas durante as viagens às comunidades, com o
objetivo de relacionar a Economia Verde e as violações de direitos humanos, com
especial atenção à situação das mulheres.
Este livro deve ser impresso e
produzido em formato multimídia. A versão eletrônica será acompanhada por um
mapa interativo e dinâmico que permita localizar cada um dos países, os
principais projetos do modelo de Economia Verde, os principais povos e os
assassinatos de ativistas ambientais.
Nosso compromisso é aprofundar a
investigação e chegar nos lugares em que os meios comerciais ou massivos não
chegam.
Atreva-se a fazer parte deste projeto.
Apoie o jornalismo independente.

program , Upside Down World.

Tell your Mom you love her by saving a butterfly

Pelee Island Bird Observatory (PIBO) is raising $1000 to plant milkweed and indigenous wildflowers for nectar on its land on Pelee Island. These funds will create habitat for Monarchs to feed and or lay their eggs as they start the annual migration to Mexico.
Surplus funds will be applied to PIBO's educational outreach program to students in Essex County/Windsor area.

Work plan:  (1) Providing a quality habitat for Monarch Butterflies by planting and maintaining various species of Milkweed and other nectar plants for all life stages of the Monarch.  (2) To educate others about the threats to Monarch butterflies and possibly to connect with the Monarch Trail in Leamington. (3) By growing wildflowers that are carefully selected to match Pelee Island’s unique ecosystem, we hope to provide a healthy stop over site for the Monarchs to rest and refuel for their flight over Lake Erie.

Benefits: A long-term healthy habitat with a variety of native plant species means that Monarch Butterflies will be supported in all their life stages.  Through this program, we will educate others about the threats to Monarch butterflies and possibly to connect with the Monarch Trail in Leamington to create a connection between the mainland and the island. By growing wildflowers that are carefully selected to match Pelee Island’s unique ecosystem, we hope to provide a healthy stop over site for the Monarchs to rest and refuel to continue their migration over Lake Erie. Of course, not only Monarch butterflies will benefit from our efforts, but also other species of butterflies that rely on native plants will also find refuge.

Why us and what we can do? PIBO owns a small piece of property on McCormick Road on Pelee Island. Zoned agricultural, it can be used for conservation purposes and public use. Originally intended for an educational centre/staff housing, the plot is an ideal spot for a conservation initiative such as a Monarch Butterfly garden, as it is located adjacent to Fish Point Nature Reserve, a designated IBA (Important Bird Area) location.

Who we are: Pelee Island Bird Observatory is a non-profit charitable organisation devoted to the study and conservation of birds. Our mandate includes long-term migration monitoring as a member of the Canadian Migration Monitoring Network
column2: long –term studies of Pelee’s breeding bird communities
column3: to serve as an educational centre for the public and local schools and to highlight the importance of Pelee’s unique natural heritage. It is because of this last point that this new initiative was formed.

column1: Why Monarchs? Each fall, North American Monarchs travel from their summer breeding grounds to overwintering locations travelling between 2-5,000 kms. Monarchs, like other butterflies and moths, undergo complete metamorphosis, meaning they have an egg, larva, pupa and adult stage. The egg and caterpillar stages occur only on species of milkweed (genus Asclepias) whereas adults survive by drawing nectar from a variety of flowering plants. As is the case with migratory birds, monarchs use Pelee Island as a stopover site. Moreover, the staff of PIBO have been conducting a Monarch migration count for over a decade. As with the general trend elsewhere, we have noticed a considerable reduction in their numbers over the years.
Threats to Monarchs: The major risks in Canada include: The use of pesticides and herbicides
column2: the loss of native plant species
column3: the propagation of non-native plant species and the escape of these species into natural areas
column5: Damage to Milkweed from ground level ozone (smog) and drought. (David Suzuki Foundation)

column1:
Site Preparation: Recently a flora and fauna survey was performed on the site, and unfortunately some invasive species were discovered. Phragmites, garlic mustard and English ivy were found growing in the plot. These invasive species will need to be removed as soon as possible. The garlic mustard is located mostly in one area of the site, and a pulling is planned for the end of May. The Ontario Invasive Plant Council suggests that the removal of Garlic Mustard be done in early spring before the plants have set seed. They also suggest simultaneously planting the native plants, such as Milkweed as the seed bank will be depleted and this will stimulate germination and increase the likelihood of removal success.
PIBO has researched some potential sources for Milkweed seeds and plants. There are six Milkweed species native to southwestern Ontario- Asclepias exaltata
Budget:
15 packets of Milkweed seeds from North American Native Plant Society: $16.50
Various wildflower seeds from Wildflower Farm (www.wildflowerfarm) : Red Milkweed
Four shovels ($111.92 Home Depot), 6 pairs work gloves ($29.96) garbage bags ($13.84 Home Depot)
Yearly taxes for the property: $ 680.00
Total for supplies and taxes $931.81
To supply snacks and drinks to volunteers for the removal of invasives and planting of natives: $68.19
Total: $1000.00
Photos provided by Sumiko Onishi

Who we are

We are a group of doers. When in 2003 Rick received a call from a farmer about a 766 hectare forest that was about to turn ashes, he acted. He took his money and purchased the whole piece. He's not a billionaire or a Hollywood actor. Just a guy that loves nature and hates waste.

17 years since then. Two world economic downturns, lost apartment and even a sold refrigerator away, Rick is still keeping the forest standing, paying property taxes and sustaining local community - people that chose not to sell their land to soy farmers but keep their living the way it has always been. (watch Big Tree Story trailer - a project of a documentary that was going to tell the story of Rick's company, his 3D program and environmental effort).
<div style=""text-align: center

Then, we created Big Tree Adventure Tours. Because so many people have visited that forewst and then asked ""Why don't you ever take tourists here"". Big Tree Adventure Tours became one of the ways to fund this forest when times were hard. Today, our tours are among the best offered in the whole Amazon. And they are the perks we're offering you for supporting this initiative.
Big Tree Adventure Tour #1 - with Gary Chandler from the Lonely Planet Brazil. This is how we got to be the highlight of 2013 edition!
Our operation is not big but we are always ready to give - this is one of our non-profit tours with a group of volunteers from AIESEC.
Young enthusiasts are among our favorite visitors. Gabriela Tessitore was at 766 in 2014 during the World Cup in Brazil with her project ""Fora da Copa"".

Part of the original team at the dawn of Big Tree Adventure Tours. Rodrigo is a young talent from Santarém who produced most of our early videos. Today he's about to graduate as an architect. With Karim and Naldo he explored most of 766 for 2 years, ended up becoming a great guide and a super-multi-functional professional. We do our best to involve as many local people as possible in our activities.

Monkeys playing in the back porch of our friend Raul, 5 miles South of Santarém. Raul's little piece of land has been a shelter for lots of wild monkeys that couldn't return to Maicá floodplain after Curua-Una highway was built. We've been supporting Raul for years and we hope to expand this help. Around our area there's so much more to get done.

National Geographic came to Santarem in 2014 to make a reportage about Rubber Age in the Amazon. Our team was there to support photographer Richard Barnes and after that we produced a mini-documentary with Jose Otavio Junges about a roadtrip to Fordlandia that won an award on the Amazonian Film Festival.

766 is a forest preserve in Tapajos River region - ""Brazilian Caribbean"", as they call it here. Tapajos river is probably the most beautiful tributary of the Amazon with hundreds of miles of desert white sandy beaches. Rick is a kitesurfer and, yes, you can do kitesurfing in the Amazon. Big Tree Adventure Tours was a pioneer in organizing Kitesurfing tours and among our guests we had Chris Bobryk - Best pro-rider.

The Amazon is not only about the jungle, wildlife and indigenous culture. Santarem was the epicenter of economic development through the rubber boom, cocoa and mor for over 200 years. We are fascinated by the hidden stories of this place and share them through our tours. The Rubber Path cruise features most of them - from archaeological sights with 6000-year-old artefacts to american-made houses turning into brazilian villages like Belterra (on the photo).

Today we want to take more action. On March 29th, 2020, we rode out there and saw huge machines harvesting soy. Nothing wrong about it, except where they were doing this was once standing a millennial forest. There must be another way to feed people, empower communities and NOT to destroy Amazon Rain Forest.
And there is. Eco-tourism, sustainable logging, collecting organic materials, family non-toxic agriculture - it all can put together environmental and economic sustainability.

For over 30 years Rick lead the project of his life - using leftover or otherwise burnt hardwoods from the amazon rain forest to make timber frames. He created the 3D project - Dying, Dead and Down - the idea of harvesting only fallen and dead trees for wood. He supported organic plantations around São Benedito - the village that borders with his land. Before 2003 this village was full of people that had a hard yet happy life in the nature: collecting Brazil Nuts, Cumaru seeds and Breu Sap, planting manioc and fishing. A big farmer came in and people sold their land moving to the city. a couple of years later they would have no money and no land. And the forest? Well, in 2010, a journalist from New York, Andrew Blackwell, published the book ""Visit Sunny Chernobyl"" where he called the land Rick had purchased before the farmers ""An island of forest in the ocean of soy"".

So, we got tired of helplessly watching the devastation. We want to preserve and expand the rain forest. We want to buy nearby properties, conserve, replant, teach people how to make organic plantations and find a good use for them. We want to study this forest that has more mysteries than we ever imagined. We want canopy platforms, walks, river expeditions. We want the forest to stand and people around it to be happy. That's why we need your help.
[UPDATE]
Here goes a fresh reason why we need your help. Watch the video by Rare Earth Hardwoods and find out why Amazon Rainforest fires will hit us harder in 2020/2021 dry season:
<div><div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/keLYICYNEmA?autohide=1&amp
Stage 1
This campaign is launched to help us fund 2 achievements:

1) make a full study of the 766 hectares of the forest: tree species, plants, wildlife and river fauna. That includes hiring biologists, environmental engineers, people to clear the river path, install trail cameras and build canopy platforms. And, yes, this forest will be open for visits - it will actually become the biggest outdoor adventure park in the world with the lowest impact on the nature. From getting to tree tops to tubing in a narrow creek in the middle of the jungle - you'll be able to enjoy it all.

2) secure the property. For 17 years Rick Paid and Zero Impact Brazil have been paying property taxes, surveys, local employees that keep hunters, loggers and forest fires away with ZERO governmental support. And Rick wants to make sure that after he's gone, there's a conservation program rolling that guarantees the preservation and expansion of this forest. When we say expansion, we mean that we are ready to purchase more land around 766 to preserve and replant rain forest. Hollywood stars could do it, but they don't. So, we'll do.

766 is one of the rare pieces of land that has all legal documents with a land title. Zero Impact Brazil worked hard to secure the property. It's 100% legal and private with zero support from the government or NGOs. As a result, nothing can threaten this forest as long as we keep all the taxes up to date!
Our record

column1: 2013 edition of Lonely Planet Brazil highligted Zero Impact Brazil and Big Tree Adventure Tours for both - eco-tour operation and low-impact wood business.
Get in touch to know more
We have much more going on than we're telling here. If you want to know more, schedule a visit or find out how else you can help - get in touch >
","Who we are

We are a group of doers. When in 2003 Rick received a call from a farmer about a 766 hectare forest that was about to turn ashes, he acted. He took his money and purchased the whole piece. He's not a billionaire or a Hollywood actor. Just a guy that loves nature and hates waste.

17 years since then. Two world economic downturns, lost apartment and even a sold refrigerator away, Rick is still keeping the forest standing, paying property taxes and sustaining local community - people that chose not to sell their land to soy farmers but keep their living the way it has always been. (watch Big Tree Story trailer - a project of a documentary that was going to tell the story of Rick's company, his 3D program and environmental effort).

Then, we created Big Tree Adventure Tours. Because so many people have visited that forewst and then asked ""Why don't you ever take tourists here"". Big Tree Adventure Tours became one of the ways to fund this forest when times were hard. Today, our tours are among the best offered in the whole Amazon. And they are the perks we're offering you for supporting this initiative.
Big Tree Adventure Tour #1 - with Gary Chandler from the Lonely Planet Brazil. This is how we got to be the highlight of 2013 edition!
Our operation is not big but we are always ready to give - this is one of our non-profit tours with a group of volunteers from AIESEC.
Young enthusiasts are among our favorite visitors. Gabriela Tessitore was at 766 in 2014 during the World Cup in Brazil with her project ""Fora da Copa"".

Part of the original team at the dawn of Big Tree Adventure Tours. Rodrigo is a young talent from Santarém who produced most of our early videos. Today he's about to graduate as an architect. With Karim and Naldo he explored most of 766 for 2 years, ended up becoming a great guide and a super-multi-functional professional. We do our best to involve as many local people as possible in our activities.

Monkeys playing in the back porch of our friend Raul, 5 miles South of Santarém. Raul's little piece of land has been a shelter for lots of wild monkeys that couldn't return to Maicá floodplain after Curua-Una highway was built. We've been supporting Raul for years and we hope to expand this help. Around our area there's so much more to get done.

National Geographic came to Santarem in 2014 to make a reportage about Rubber Age in the Amazon. Our team was there to support photographer Richard Barnes and after that we produced a mini-documentary with Jose Otavio Junges about a roadtrip to Fordlandia that won an award on the Amazonian Film Festival.

766 is a forest preserve in Tapajos River region - ""Brazilian Caribbean"", as they call it here. Tapajos river is probably the most beautiful tributary of the Amazon with hundreds of miles of desert white sandy beaches. Rick is a kitesurfer and, yes, you can do kitesurfing in the Amazon. Big Tree Adventure Tours was a pioneer in organizing Kitesurfing tours and among our guests we had Chris Bobryk - Best pro-rider.

The Amazon is not only about the jungle, wildlife and indigenous culture. Santarem was the epicenter of economic development through the rubber boom, cocoa and mor for over 200 years. We are fascinated by the hidden stories of this place and share them through our tours. The Rubber Path cruise features most of them - from archaeological sights with 6000-year-old artefacts to american-made houses turning into brazilian villages like Belterra (on the photo).

Today we want to take more action. On March 29th, 2020, we rode out there and saw huge machines harvesting soy. Nothing wrong about it, except where they were doing this was once standing a millennial forest. There must be another way to feed people, empower communities and NOT to destroy Amazon Rain Forest.
And there is. Eco-tourism, sustainable logging, collecting organic materials, family non-toxic agriculture - it all can put together environmental and economic sustainability.

For over 30 years Rick lead the project of his life - using leftover or otherwise burnt hardwoods from the amazon rain forest to make timber frames. He created the 3D project - Dying, Dead and Down - the idea of harvesting only fallen and dead trees for wood. He supported organic plantations around São Benedito - the village that borders with his land. Before 2003 this village was full of people that had a hard yet happy life in the nature: collecting Brazil Nuts, Cumaru seeds and Breu Sap, planting manioc and fishing. A big farmer came in and people sold their land moving to the city. a couple of years later they would have no money and no land. And the forest? Well, in 2010, a journalist from New York, Andrew Blackwell, published the book ""Visit Sunny Chernobyl"" where he called the land Rick had purchased before the farmers ""An island of forest in the ocean of soy"".

So, we got tired of helplessly watching the devastation. We want to preserve and expand the rain forest. We want to buy nearby properties, conserve, replant, teach people how to make organic plantations and find a good use for them. We want to study this forest that has more mysteries than we ever imagined. We want canopy platforms, walks, river expeditions. We want the forest to stand and people around it to be happy. That's why we need your help.
[UPDATE]
Here goes a fresh reason why we need your help. Watch the video by Rare Earth Hardwoods and find out why Amazon Rainforest fires will hit us harder in 2020/2021 dry season:
Stage 1
This campaign is launched to help us fund 2 achievements:

1) make a full study of the 766 hectares of the forest: tree species, plants, wildlife and river fauna. That includes hiring biologists, environmental engineers, people to clear the river path, install trail cameras and build canopy platforms. And, yes, this forest will be open for visits - it will actually become the biggest outdoor adventure park in the world with the lowest impact on the nature. From getting to tree tops to tubing in a narrow creek in the middle of the jungle - you'll be able to enjoy it all.

2) secure the property. For 17 years Rick Paid and Zero Impact Brazil have been paying property taxes, surveys, local employees that keep hunters, loggers and forest fires away with ZERO governmental support. And Rick wants to make sure that after he's gone, there's a conservation program rolling that guarantees the preservation and expansion of this forest. When we say expansion, we mean that we are ready to purchase more land around 766 to preserve and replant rain forest. Hollywood stars could do it, but they don't. So, we'll do.

766 is one of the rare pieces of land that has all legal documents with a land title. Zero Impact Brazil worked hard to secure the property. It's 100% legal and private with zero support from the government or NGOs. As a result, nothing can threaten this forest as long as we keep all the taxes up to date!
Our record

We're not first-timers in this. We have people, tools, ideas and blueprints lined up. 766 has been visited by Lonely Planet, National Geographic, numerous documentary teams, journalists and regular travelers. We created Big Tree Adventure Tours. We know that people enjoy that piece of forest even more than governmental Tapajos National Forest which is right across the road. All we need is to boost it up!
2013 edition of Lonely Planet Brazil highligted Zero Impact Brazil and Big Tree Adventure Tours for both - eco-tour operation and low-impact wood business.
Get in touch to know more
We have much more going on than we're telling here. If you want to know more, schedule a visit or find out how else you can help - get in touch >>> rainforestexpanding@gmail.com",10.0,2,"2 Campaigns
