Mission statement

   The hyena, one of the worlds most misunderstood and misrepresented animals, it’s my mission to dispel all of the myths behind these wonderful creatures and give you a glimpse into their extraordinary lives!

   It seems most of us are guilty of forming an opinion of hyenas based on Disney’s The Lion King. These villains are shown to be sneaky, cackling and conniving creatures that do not seem all too clever. However, this couldn’t be further from the truth!

 

Introduction

   My name is Alex Cooper I’m a wildlife ecologist, conservationist and above all a lover of hyenas. Since starting my research on these amazing creatures in 2014 it has been my passion to show the world that in fact, hyenas are remarkably smart animals whose social organisation and intelligence is akin to that of chimpanzees. I have been dedicating my time to African conservation for the past 10 years and have been learning the ins and outs of all the problems faced with shrinking tracts of land, population declines and human-wildlife conflict.

My goal is simple:
• To collect valuable data to inform the decision-making process with regard to hyena conservation.
• To bring the plight of hyenas to the forefront of the conservation discussion.
• Through public engagement, dispelling all the myths about hyenas and showing what incredible animals they are.

The study I propose is to assess the ecology of 2 competing hyena species, the spotted hyena and the lesser known brown hyena (yes! There are 4 different species of hyena). By collecting this baseline data we can assess what the greatest impacts to these hyena populations are and we can propose strategies to mitigate these issues.

 

   The Savé Valley Conservancy in South-east Zimbabwe is where I call home and this is where our hyenas freely roam the untamed wilderness!

   This is where I will study all aspects of their ecology over the coming years, looking at how individuals interact within and between species, how they forage for food, how and if they hunt, what they’re hunting, den use, movement patterns and spatial utilisation. This will form the basis for the plan to conserve hyenas long into the future. With this key information we can combat habitat loss through a better understanding of home range and territory size, we can limit and mitigate human-wildlife conflict through education programs, awareness campaigns and together we can take a huge step towards changing perceptions of these remarkable animals.

 

   Everyone is vastly concerned with the low populations of African lions and their continuing decline, however spotted hyena numbers are estimated to be 27,000 worldwide and the brown hyena population is estimate to be no more than 10,000 worldwide.

 

   The primary source of data and the most important aspect of understanding the hyena’s ecology, will be for us to affix GPS satellite collars. We will select 10-12 individuals (half brown hyenas half spotted hyenas) as our study subjects and they will form the basis of the study. Once these individuals are collared it will allow us to collect large-scale spatial data and more importantly will allow us to easily follow the individuals throughout their daily lives. Collection of direct observations will be essential in understanding their specific behaviour and filling in large pieces of the puzzle.

 

Funding Status

   The COVID-19 pandemic has severely reduced my ability to raise funds, however despite travel restrictions and having had no tourism I have managed so far to raise $23,000 USD (£17,000 GBP). I’m hoping fund raising in 2021 will be somewhat easier if things normalise, however this campaign will be a huge help in getting to the target. The only costs needed upfront for the project are for the satellite collars and the veterinary fees, once these elements of the research are covered the additional costs necessary can and will be spread over the following years. Another important funding source will be to apply for small grants to sustain the project throughout the next 3 years.  

   Therefore, my aim is to raise $51,500 USD (£38,600 GBP) by the end of 2020 so the order for satellite collars can be processed and we can have them on standby ready for the collaring operation.

 

Perks

Now for the exciting part!

   All contributions are much appreciated whether financial or otherwise, if you are unable to make a monetary contribution please consider sharing this campaign and get the word out there. If you are interested in the project and would like to know more or get involved please feel free to contact me, the more people that care, the better!

 

Social media

This is an exciting opportunity to get involved, contribute to the social media perk and head over to my social media outlets to help me help you:

To enter please follow the instructions for each social media platform:

Facebook-         Contribute to the perk

                              Share the video to your feed

                                Tag 3 friends

Instagram-          Contribute to the perk

                                Follow Alex.In.Africa

                                https://www.instagram.com/alex.in.africa/

                                Tag 3 friends in the video post

                                Post the video in your story

Twitter:                Contribute to the perk

                                Follow @theallycoops13

                                Tag 3 friends

Corporate sponsor

   Rather a unique perk, this is your chance to purchase advertising space on our research vehicle. Have your company logo as big as you like printed for all of our high end clients to see.

Mask

As a thank you for your contribution you will receive a mask with the print of a female lioness from the reserve!

 

Photo prints

20x20cm photo from a trail camera of a brown hyena

20x30cm Photo printed onto canvas, photo taken by award winning wildlife film maker and photographer Kim Wolhuter.

Name a Hyena!

This is your opportunity to name one of our study subjects! Not only will you get to name the hyena you will also receive regular updates and pictures of your hyena so don’t miss out and get in quickly!

 

Painting

An amazing chance to get your hands on a custom painting from wildlife artist Lin Barrie.

 

Jewellery

Generously donated by Patrick Mavros, don’t miss this great deal to pick up a wonderful Christmas gift for your respective partner.

THE ULTIMATE

For your amazing contribution you will get a once in a lifetime trip to the conservancy, you will be accommodated in our luxury lodge for 3 nights, all expenses paid. Whilst out here you will be invited to attend an exclusive tour with wildlife film maker Kim Wolhuter, in addition to being exposed to a pristine environment with the big 5.

Terms and Conditions – Trip subject to availability and travel restrictions, excludes flights, visas and transfers (however transfer can be arranged).

Reconciliation by Sublime

Sublime is the first international lifestyle magazine pioneering sustainability since 2006. Our mission is to unify, empower, and amplify the voices that are creating the just society we want for us and our future generations.

We run initiatives such as the Good Brand Awards, to reward organisations that don’t do ‘business as usual’, recognising their efforts to build a new economic model based on social and environmental respect.

The Reconciliation Candle campaign is aimed at supporting the work of organisations, entrepreneurs and initiatives creating positive change, whether working on personal, environmental or social transformation, at a local or global scale.

Why do we need this?

Shining the light on stories that restore dignity and hope.

We are surrounded by so many stories of violence, economic crises, inequality, persecution, leadership crises, and scepticism that can make us feel the world is a ruthless and unsafe place. This negative overload polarises our views, driving us farther and farther apart. However, there is another side of the coin: the incredible work of many who are bringing about societal transformation, and bringing borders. Yet, we hardly hear these stories of hope, and celebrate our triumphs against all odds.

We believe in promoting and celebrating the restorative stories of love, forgiveness, and common vision that bring people together.

By supporting the campaign, you help in giving visibility to stories that don't get covered due to budget restrictions or conflict of interests, but which are essential to restore our faith in the future of humanity. We know that many of you share this belief, and we very much hope you will join us.

 

What you are supporting

We believe that promoting a reconciliation mindset is key to overcome crisis.

We are looking to raise £8,000 to sponsor pro-bono coverage of positive stories. To make it simple for everyone to support this initiative, we have produced a limited edition of beautifully crafted signature candles.

The funds will go to develop a dedicated section on our website to feature successful reconciliation stories collected from around the world. Beyond creating awareness, we also want to inspire everyone to write their own success story, find out about opportunities to use their talent, or get involved with initiatives, social enterprises and causes they believe in.

About our limited edition candles

Our luxury scented candles are handmade in Italy by a small family-owned business based on sustainability values. They are 100% vegan, use unleaded cotton wicks, and natural fragrances. The candles are made using an ancient formula and purely vegetable waxes, respecting the local artisan tradition and zero-carbon production.

 

Other ways you can help

Supporting this campaign will help us give voice to those less heard, but also make everyone aware of opportunities to engage. We are a platform for all. Be part of it.
• Share your reconciliation story #sublimemagazine
• Spread the word by sharing the campaign
• Follow us on social media
• Refer to us writers and creative collaborators who share our values
• Sign up to our newsletter
More about Sublime

Our Manifesto

Now that people are the most important thing for people,
Now that we know that the greatest risk is not to risk,
Now that we don’t need to be asleep to dream,
Now it’s time to start again.

Our Story

Sublime started in March 2004 as a group of 30 media people gathered to discuss what a contemporary magazine should be all about. In a year’s time, the group devoted to Sublime grew to 300 influencers from around the world, making Sublime the first magazine movement with such wide collaboration and following before its launch.

Urban, entertaining, informative, and thought-provoking, Sublime captures the spirit of our time, championing the values of a new economic paradigm based on sustainable entrepreneurship, community, and interdependence.

As independent publishers, we have over 15-year’s experience in tackling entrepreneurial challenges. We have learned to keep possibilities and wider routes of action through our extensive network of partners and collaborators, who have always been key in this process of support and invigorating energy.

<h3 style=""text-align: center

column2: >Project Vesta is proud to announce that mid-way through our campaign, we received a few large donations that helped us to surpass our fundraising goal for Phase 1 Experiments - bringing us to more than $2.6M raised to date!
>We couldn't have gotten here without all of our amazing supporters. Thank you, and stay tuned!

column1: <h3><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px

column3: >To continue thriving on planet Earth, we must remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere - fast, permanently, and at scale. Project Vesta wants to reverse climate change by turning a trillion tonnes of CO₂ into rock and we need YOUR help.  Our chance to bring 30 years of research in a lab into the real world is finally here.  Be part of the solution with us and one day you’ll look back knowing you showed up for the Planet.

column1: How it Works

Through the natural process of weathering, rocks are transported through waterways and into the ocean, where, as part of the carbon cycle, trillions of tonnes of CO₂ are permanently stored in rock. The problem is, humanity is releasing CO₂ far faster than the Earth can re-absorb it.
Project Vesta’s approach, called Coastal Enhanced Weathering, dramatically accelerates Earth's natural longterm CO₂ removal process.

We acquire olivine and transport it to beaches, where the free energy of wave action is harnessed to crush the rock and speed up the natural carbon dioxide capture process. This process also de-acidifies the local ocean environment.

Building on 30 years of lab research, we're deploying the first-ever olivine green sand beaches. We'll be testing the safety and speed of Coastal Enhanced Weathering, so that it can scale globally as a CO₂ removal solution.
A nature-based, permanent, scalable, and affordable solution to climate change.
Coastal Enhanced Weathering could capture 100% of humanity's annual C0₂ emissions, utilizing only 2% of shelf sea areas.
Olivine is globally abundant and accessible: it's available on every continent, and makes up over 50% of the upper mantle.
It's cost-effective: At scale, we can sequester carbon dioxide for less than $25/tonne - making this solution 10% of the cost of some CO₂ removal technologies
Where We Are Today

Project Vesta exists to enable critical CEW research to proceed, by combining the necessary funding and supporting logistics to the multidisciplinary scientific community with expertise in this field. 

We are a team of scientists and entrepreneurs. You can meet our team here! We know any human intervention in the ocean carries risk. Our goal is to demonstrate the effects of CEW as robustly as possible, presenting our raw data for peer review and enabling the broader community to make a science-based judgment, as to whether the benefits of CEW in removing carbon dioxide outweigh the costs and risks.

To date, we've raised $753,600 in donations, and brought in $250,000 through a purchase of negative-emissions credits from Stripe - for a total of $1,003,600 funds into our project to date. There's been an amazing swell of support has been enough to get us started, but we haven't raised our goal to complete the first experiments - so we need your help reaching our goal for this year!

This Indiegogo Campaign exists to help fund our first Pilot Beach Experiments - the ones that will assess safety, explore potential benefits in marine ecosystems and demonstrate the real-world weathering of olivine on actual beaches.
We have selected our first experimental beach site, and are currently in Phase 1, “Initial Experiments” (2020 to 2021). We've initiated sampling at this pilot site (pictured).
How We'll Use These Funds

The funds we raise through this campaign are all going to run our pilot projects, publish key science reviews, and create a model and process that will be used to create green-sand beaches around the world, thereby scaling a global effort.
Help us remove gigatonnes of excess carbon dioxide out of our atmosphere, so that we and our descendants can enjoy a thriving planet for generations to come.
Other Ways You Can Help
Just because you can't contribute financially, doesn't mean you can't help! We need all the support we can get.
<ul>
• Please share about Project Vesta on your social channels, and tell your community about our work!
• Use the Indiegogo share tools to share today!

Thank you!

","THANK YOU!!!
We've Surpassed Our Fundraising Goal!

Project Vesta is proud to announce that mid-way through our campaign, we received a few large donations that helped us to surpass our fundraising goal for Phase 1 Experiments - bringing us to more than $2.6M raised to date!
We couldn't have gotten here without all of our amazing supporters. Thank you, and stay tuned!
Project Vesta

To continue thriving on planet Earth, we must remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere - fast, permanently, and at scale. Project Vesta wants to reverse climate change by turning a trillion tonnes of CO₂ into rock and we need YOUR help.  Our chance to bring 30 years of research in a lab into the real world is finally here.  Be part of the solution with us and one day you’ll look back knowing you showed up for the Planet.
How it Works

Through the natural process of weathering, rocks are transported through waterways and into the ocean, where, as part of the carbon cycle, trillions of tonnes of CO₂ are permanently stored in rock. The problem is, humanity is releasing CO₂ far faster than the Earth can re-absorb it.
Project Vesta’s approach, called Coastal Enhanced Weathering, dramatically accelerates Earth's natural longterm CO₂ removal process.

We acquire olivine and transport it to beaches, where the free energy of wave action is harnessed to crush the rock and speed up the natural carbon dioxide capture process. This process also de-acidifies the local ocean environment.

Building on 30 years of lab research, we're deploying the first-ever olivine green sand beaches. We'll be testing the safety and speed of Coastal Enhanced Weathering, so that it can scale globally as a CO₂ removal solution.
A nature-based, permanent, scalable, and affordable solution to climate change.
Coastal Enhanced Weathering could capture 100% of humanity's annual C0₂ emissions, utilizing only 2% of shelf sea areas.
Olivine is globally abundant and accessible: it's available on every continent, and makes up over 50% of the upper mantle.
It's cost-effective: At scale, we can sequester carbon dioxide for less than $25/tonne - making this solution 10% of the cost of some CO₂ removal technologies
Where We Are Today

Project Vesta exists to enable critical CEW research to proceed, by combining the necessary funding and supporting logistics to the multidisciplinary scientific community with expertise in this field. We are a team of scientists and entrepreneurs. You can meet our team here! We know any human intervention in the ocean carries risk. Our goal is to demonstrate the effects of CEW as robustly as possible, presenting our raw data for peer review and enabling the broader community to make a science-based judgment, as to whether the benefits of CEW in removing carbon dioxide outweigh the costs and risks.

To date, we've raised $753,600 in donations, and brought in $250,000 through a purchase of negative-emissions credits from Stripe - for a total of $1,003,600 funds into our project to date. There's been an amazing swell of support has been enough to get us started, but we haven't raised our goal to complete the first experiments - so we need your help reaching our goal for this year!

This Indiegogo Campaign exists to help fund our first Pilot Beach Experiments - the ones that will assess safety, explore potential benefits in marine ecosystems and demonstrate the real-world weathering of olivine on actual beaches.
We have selected our first experimental beach site, and are currently in Phase 1, “Initial Experiments” (2020 to 2021). We've initiated sampling at this pilot site (pictured).
How We'll Use These Funds

The funds we raise through this campaign are all going to run our pilot projects, publish key science reviews, and create a model and process that will be used to create green-sand beaches around the world, thereby scaling a global effort.
Help us remove gigatonnes of excess carbon dioxide out of our atmosphere, so that we and our descendants can enjoy a thriving planet for generations to come.
Other Ways You Can Help
Just because you can't contribute financially, doesn't mean you can't help! We need all the support we can get.

<div>
'50 Ways to Help the Planet' is a global and educational initiative based on the urgency to explore, learn, adopt, and apply ways to help make a difference NOW.
By changing our mindset, our habits, and the products we use and how we use them, we can  have an impact and regenerate the earth.
The 50 Educational Video-Series is divided as follows:
<ul>
• 25 educational videos for us, global citizens, and for schools
• 25 educational videos for businesses, and for optimal operation
'50 Ways to Help the Planet' will also be converted into:
<ul>
<li>

50 educational 'micro-learning' interactive classes with multiple segments
and
<li>
An animated storybook for children. Empowering our children for the future!
<div>

Our goal with this campaign is to raise $50,000.

Creating the 50 videos for global citizenship, 50 interactive online classes for individuals and businesses, and the animate storybook for children involves the overall configuration of the content, the writing of multiple scripts and voice-overs, and the purchase of stock photography and footage, as well as music files. Editing crowns the entire project. 

Our entire team is in place, and we are excited to start!

In return, all of our supporters will be acknowledged and recognized as Social Investors &
column2:
Change-Makers on our IGNYTE IMPACT wall  [a special area on our upcoming website].
Your social investment creates change and impact, by allowing us to create, educate, and distribute.

column1: Our objective is to start immediately after this campaign ends, and deliver as follows:
<div>
Here is an example of what we will develop, create, share:
<div>
<div><div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/mdNK8G3mPr8?autohide=1&amp

Please be sure to explore the perks! They are limited.
We are delighted to introduce you to some of the companies and organizations that are making an impact in this world!

Developing this project are also involves building solid partnerships with companies and organizations. Some will help us distribute in schools and for after-school projects, as well as online schools, in US, UK, and Canada.

In addition, several countries in Africa (already Cameroon, Ghana, Togo and Kenya have offered the distribution) - which also means we are poised to have a important impact.
We are proud to have WokenUp as our Marketing &
column2:
Communications Partner.
We are making a difference by using WokenUp to champion the social and environmental causes that matter to us.

column1:
We are honored to have such organizations as Supporting Partners for our efforts.
Thank you so very much!

There is a sense of responsibility and urgency within me. 
I am relentless about education, advocacy and activism and this project covers all that I am passionate about. People, kids, education, planet, impact, land, soil, water, air...  and so much more.

For the past 19 years, my involvements with human rights and refugee resettlement, ocean conservancy, international adoption, human trafficking, land and wildlife conservation, have shaped the core of who I am have helped accelerate the beat of my heart. 

Today, I am mainly focusing on sustainability. Sustainability is no longer an option, but a necessity.
Sustainability starts with us, understanding nature, and what can be done achieve drawdown.

My goal is always to empower citizens and to share the tools to engage. 
Changing our light bulbs might be cliché, however it is still at the top of the list.
Let’s do this. Now.
“Brigitte Perreault is a force and a beacon, she tirelessly raises awareness on urgent global issues. This educational project is needed and urgent.""
– A.J. Ali, Producer of Walking While Black

My team and I hope you will join us and support this project.
Please help us get the word out! Let's make some noise!
And share this campaign, it's easy to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much!
Brigitte Perreault

Hello! We are DYCLE – Diaper Cycle, a non profit initiative to support parents who want to dispose of baby diapers in a sustainable way. 

We turn diapers into black soil and nutrients
for millions of trees that will provide fruit and nuts back to the community for many years to come.
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >DYCLE creates black soil out of baby diapers helping to close the nutrients and materials cycle for diapers. We do this by collecting used compostable diapers and mixing them with charcoal and kitchen waste. As a diaper is full of baby waste, it contains excellent nutrients and degrades into hygienic and fertile black earth.

column1: <div><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >DYCLE has already successfully tested the diapers collection and composting process with a pilot project in May 2015, and a week's supply of diapers from 20 babies is almost fully degraded as of November 2015.

column1: <div><b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>
<b style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >What do we want to do with the funds?

column1: The funds are being raised to establish our operations in Berlin. Meanwhile, spreading our network to 5 other cities is in the plans for 2016. The largest part of the budget will go to compostable diapers for our first community of parents and to upscaling our operations.
Should you contribute if you are not in Berlin?
Yes. After the first community is established in Berlin, we will teach people in other locations how to do it, and so the movement grows.
Business model story  as proposed by Gunter Pauli, The Blue Economy
The problem we are solving?
Disposable diapers take up to 10% of household waste and have a large CO2 and methane gas footprint. Each baby produces an average of 500 kg of diaper waste during their first 3 years.

A multitude of benefits will be created from closing the diapers cycle. Less waste in landfills and incinerators, reduced carbon footprint, support of organic food production for healthier mothers and babies are just the tip of an iceberg.
Who are we?

column5: >DYCLE in Berlin was founded by
column13: >, an artist most well known for the ""All My Cycle"" project. It is supported by the ZERI Foundation (v.z.w), a Belgian-based organization committed to implement ""The Blue Economy"" as described in the book by Gunter Pauli that was first presented as a report to the Club of Rome in 2009. Ayumi demonstrated that human waste can be transformed to nutrients. For more about her please visit her web page:

column1: http://ayumi-matsuzaka.com/

column9: >Systemic Designer in Berlin, graduated under Luigi Bistagnino at the Politecnico di Torino, developed the systemic flow of the nutrients and material cycle of the idea and compared with linear production of disposable diapers.

column1:
Alexander Prinsen, from the Netherlands, researcher at Masters of Beautiful Achievements and sustainable business model expert gave the structure of diapers trail in Berlin, added financial, strategy development and recruitment to the Berlin
initiative.

Christian Schloh, Web Developer and supported the logistic and planning part of Ayumi’s experiments and trials.

Other supporters:  Caren Müller, Christian Markwart, Veronica Carli, Maaike Reynaert, Valentina Karga,  Evelyn Echeverria, Julia Both, David Burkert, Marie Gasser, Yulia Steseva.
And the PARENTS! with whom we work intensively and who have given us many valuable lessons of how DYCLE can improve.
Collaborating Universities

Scientific Team Berlin

Prof. Dr. Ing. Günther Seliger, chair of Sustainable Manufacturing at the Science University of Berlin (TU-Berlin) who has accompanied the thinking process throughout the years and who is, with his students from around the world, committed to make the local machines work. The team consists of Dipl.-Ing. Bernd Muschard, Dr.-Ing. Peter Stamnitz and Verdiana Kamala.

Dr. Haiko Pieplow, from the German Ministry of Environment has for a decade now advocated the use of Terra Preta (the Brazilian name for black earth). He has taught many the technique and has been generous in sharing the application applying of open source logic.

Dr. Jürgen Reckin, Terra Preta expert from Finowfurt, Ayumi’s first scientist who experimented with the Terra Preta method in diapers inlay, aside from Ayumi’s original experiments. He  advised us on the humification process.

Dipl. Geogr, Kathrin Rößler and the team from TerraBoGa, at the Botanic Garden Berlin, who supported the materials' trial and experimented with different inlays with Ayumi.

Rainer Buchholz from Terra Preta earth company, Wandlitzer Erden in Klosterfelde, who supported the soil material and humification process for the trial.

Prof. Dr. Michael Weiss, microbiologist of Steinbeis-Innovationszentrum Organismische Mykologie und Mikrobiologie, in Tübingen analyzed micro-organisms in fermented diapers inlays and proposed to find specific fungal agents that can break down the cellulose.

Angela Clinkscales, Marta Depta, Susanna Viehmann from hybrid diapers company PURAPUR shared insights and experiences of material cycle, shared the information of diapers industry and component of diapers inlay. The team supported the trials with their handmade compostable diapers inlay (prototype) in Berlin in 2015.

Marko Heckel, effective micro-organism company, triaterra in Groß Pankow, gave practical advice to Ayumi’s sanitation art projects since 2012 and supported almost all implementation materials to create Terra Preta substrate.

Peter Thomas who for a few years ran tests on black earth production at the Botanical Gardens of Berlin, mobilizing the interest of scientists and citizens alike. He showed that it was practical.

Sources of Inspiration
Anders Nyquist, the Swedish architect, was a pioneer in changing the habit of wasting water and excrement into producing nutrients. He was the first one to enlighten us on this.

Hao Dang, bamboo entrepreneur from Vietnam, who encourages the thousands of workers who work at his factory to use the ablution facilities there and leave their biological waste behind so that he can apply the nutrients to the bamboo plantations and produce methane in the process, offered great inspiration.

Joseph Jenkins wrote the eye-opening book Humanure Handbook that has been highly recommended by the Permaculture Network and which many of us have, of course, read. This book inspired us to go over to action.
<div>
","Hello! We are DYCLE – Diaper Cycle, a non profit initiative to support parents who want to dispose of baby diapers in a sustainable way. We turn diapers into black soil and nutrients
for millions of trees that will provide fruit and nuts back to the community for many years to come.

What is Diaper Cycle? DYCLE creates black soil out of baby diapers helping to close the nutrients and materials cycle for diapers. We do this by collecting used compostable diapers and mixing them with charcoal and kitchen waste. As a diaper is full of baby waste, it contains excellent nutrients and degrades into hygienic and fertile black earth.

DYCLE has already successfully tested the diapers collection and composting process with a pilot project in May 2015, and a week's supply of diapers from 20 babies is almost fully degraded as of November 2015.
What do we want to do with the funds?

The funds are being raised to establish our operations in Berlin. Meanwhile, spreading our network to 5 other cities is in the plans for 2016. The largest part of the budget will go to compostable diapers for our first community of parents and to upscaling our operations.
Should you contribute if you are not in Berlin?
Yes. After the first community is established in Berlin, we will teach people in other locations how to do it, and so the movement grows.
Business model story  as proposed by Gunter Pauli, The Blue Economy
The problem we are solving?
Disposable diapers take up to 10% of household waste and have a large CO2 and methane gas footprint. Each baby produces an average of 500 kg of diaper waste during their first 3 years.

A multitude of benefits will be created from closing the diapers cycle. Less waste in landfills and incinerators, reduced carbon footprint, support of organic food production for healthier mothers and babies are just the tip of an iceberg.
Who are we?

DYCLE in Berlin was founded by Ayumi Matsuzaka, an artist most well known for the ""All My Cycle"" project. It is supported by the ZERI Foundation (v.z.w), a Belgian-based organization committed to implement ""The Blue Economy"" as described in the book by Gunter Pauli that was first presented as a report to the Club of Rome in 2009. Ayumi demonstrated that human waste can be transformed to nutrients. For more about her please visit her web page:
http://ayumi-matsuzaka.com/

Eliana López Gherardi, Systemic Designer in Berlin, graduated under Luigi Bistagnino at the Politecnico di Torino, developed the systemic flow of the nutrients and material cycle of the idea and compared with linear production of disposable diapers.

Alexander Prinsen, from the Netherlands, researcher at Masters of Beautiful Achievements and sustainable business model expert gave the structure of diapers trail in Berlin, added financial, strategy development and recruitment to the Berlininitiative.Christian Schloh, Web Developer and supported the logistic and planning part of Ayumi’s experiments and trials.Other supporters:  Caren Müller, Christian Markwart, Veronica Carli, Maaike Reynaert, Valentina Karga,  Evelyn Echeverria, Julia Both, David Burkert, Marie Gasser, Yulia Steseva.
And the PARENTS! with whom we work intensively and who have given us many valuable lessons of how DYCLE can improve.
Collaborating Universities

Scientific Team BerlinProf. Dr. Ing. Günther Seliger, chair of Sustainable Manufacturing at the Science University of Berlin (TU-Berlin) who has accompanied the thinking process throughout the years and who is, with his students from around the world, committed to make the local machines work. The team consists of Dipl.-Ing. Bernd Muschard, Dr.-Ing. Peter Stamnitz and Verdiana Kamala.Dr. Haiko Pieplow, from the German Ministry of Environment has for a decade now advocated the use of Terra Preta (the Brazilian name for black earth). He has taught many the technique and has been generous in sharing the application applying of open source logic.Dr. Jürgen Reckin, Terra Preta expert from Finowfurt, Ayumi’s first scientist who experimented with the Terra Preta method in diapers inlay, aside from Ayumi’s original experiments. He  advised us on the humification process.Dipl. Geogr, Kathrin Rößler and the team from TerraBoGa, at the Botanic Garden Berlin, who supported the materials' trial and experimented with different inlays with Ayumi.Rainer Buchholz from Terra Preta earth company, Wandlitzer Erden in Klosterfelde, who supported the soil material and humification process for the trial.Prof. Dr. Michael Weiss, microbiologist of Steinbeis-Innovationszentrum Organismische Mykologie und Mikrobiologie, in Tübingen analyzed micro-organisms in fermented diapers inlays and proposed to find specific fungal agents that can break down the cellulose.

Angela Clinkscales, Marta Depta, Susanna Viehmann from hybrid diapers company PURAPUR shared insights and experiences of material cycle, shared the information of diapers industry and component of diapers inlay. The team supported the trials with their handmade compostable diapers inlay (prototype) in Berlin in 2015.

Marko Heckel, effective micro-organism company, triaterra in Groß Pankow, gave practical advice to Ayumi’s sanitation art projects since 2012 and supported almost all implementation materials to create Terra Preta substrate.Peter Thomas who for a few years ran tests on black earth production at the Botanical Gardens of Berlin, mobilizing the interest of scientists and citizens alike. He showed that it was practical.Sources of Inspiration
Anders Nyquist, the Swedish architect, was a pioneer in changing the habit of wasting water and excrement into producing nutrients. He was the first one to enlighten us on this.

Hao Dang, bamboo entrepreneur from Vietnam, who encourages the thousands of workers who work at his factory to use the ablution facilities there and leave their biological waste behind so that he can apply the nutrients to the bamboo plantations and produce methane in the process, offered great inspiration.

Joseph Jenkins wrote the eye-opening book Humanure Handbook that has been highly recommended by the Permaculture Network and which many of us have, of course, read. This book inspired us to go over to action.",8.0,1,"1 Campaign

The rising global temperature is melting the ice that surrounds the North Pole, and WWF predicts that if things don't start to cool down, it may disappear within the next generation, rendering Santa homeless and at risk of drowning! 
So the time has come to give back to Santa and make sure he can continue

to call the North Pole home! To help save Santa, Wrapt Collective has created an easy way to wrap your gifts more sustainably this Christmas. Every gift wrapped with Wrapt Collective materials helps to preserve and regenerate forests, and keep Santa afloat.

To give back to the environment, Wrapt Collective wrapping paper and gift tags are printed on 100% recycled paper, the ribbon and sticky tape are 100% biodegradable, plus 50% of profits go to reforestation. If enough people wrap this way, we could eventually have more trees planted than cut down every Christmas!
Our aim is to transform Christmas one gift at a time, from the most wasteful time of year, into the most environmentally prosperous holiday (and save Santa from the sharks in the process).
Not every gift bought this year will be sustainable, but every gift wrapped can be!
Introducing...

Potato Print Designs
All designs are hand crafted from Australian potatoes.
100% Recycled Paper
Our potato print designs are reproduced on 100% post consumer waste recycled paper using soy based ink. Our printing partner, along with our paper are also FSC certified and Carbon Neutral.

100% Biodegradable

All our wrapping materials including the wrapping paper, gift tags, curling ribbon and sticky tape are biodegradable. So you can just pop everything in the compost after the fun of unwrapping is over. Or, of course, reuse the paper on another gift.
50% of profits go to forest conservation

We have partnered with the Carbon Neutral Charitable Fund to donate 50% of our operation profits after tax to forest conservation. This means we not only fund the planting of trees, but we make sure they're looked after!
Packaging

We are committed to making our business as environmentally friendly as possible, so our gift tag ties are made from biodegradable hemp and we ship our wrapping in recycled envelopes, boxes and tubes where possible.
What's going on at the North Pole?

Santa and his elves are in a bit of a tizz because the Arctic sea ice that surrounds the North Pole has decreased by 14% since the 1970's and WWF predicts that it may disappear in summer within the next generation. Which means, Santa and his elves may find themselves in a spot of bother and in need of some floaties!

Why Christmas?

Christmas is when we are our most generous but also our most wasteful.
<li>
60% of Australians spend more than they earn at Christmas.
• Globally it is estimated that around 23 million trees are cut down each Christmas to produce greeting cards and gift wrap.
• But over 60% choose not to purchase more sustainable products because they are 'too expensive'.
What's in it for you?

Design tested
There's no way you can make a present wrapped in Wrapt Collective look bad! We've made sure all our designs look fabo together so you can mix and match till your heart's content. Plus the ribbon and paper are super easy to work with and we have tips on YouTube for inspiration.

Affordable
Understanding that the biggest barrier to purchasing sustainable products is price, we've done our best to make the Wrapt Collective range as affordable as possible, and included ways for everyone to get involved. Only with your support will we be able to reach the scale required to make our range even more affordable. Why not team up with your friends and family to get the best deal on a bulk perk!

Shipping
The perks will be shipped during the first week of December to ensure arrival before Christmas.

Wrapping
Wrapping tools

Gift Tags
90x40mm, 200gsm, hemp chord
Comes in four designs: Reindeer, Candy Cane, Gingerbread Man, &
column2:
Santa's Hat
All designs are crafted using hand cut, Australian-grown potatoes and reproduced on 100% recycled paper using soy inks. Both the paper and the printing process are FSC certified and carbon neutral. 

Wrapping Paper
690x490mm
Comes in four designs: Christmas Tree, Reindeer, Gingerbread Man, &
column3:
Present
All designs are crafted using hand cut,

column1: Australian-grown potatoes and reproduced on 100% recycled paper using
soy inks. Both the paper and the printing process are FSC certified and

carbon neutral.

Curling Ribbon
5/8"", 100% cotton
Comes in three candy stripe designs: Red &
column5:
Light Green
Dyed using soy based dyes, the ribbon not only great to work with and very versatile, but is also biodegradable.

Envirotape
10x12mm, biodegradable
The tape that holds everything together, all your environmentally friendly efforts may come undone the sticky tape has to be removed from the paper before it can be recycled. 100% biodegradable, this tape allows you to pop all the Christmas unwrapping straight in the compost!

column1: What can I do?
The average Australian spends $374 on
Christmas gifts each year, equating to a National total of $8 billion!
We're hoping to attract at least a small portion of this to help our
Christmas spending have a more positive impact without giving up gift
wrapping.
We've set our campaign goal on $100,000 and Santa's helpers will be
delivering perks regardless of how much we raise. But if you help us
smash our goal (and Santa) out of the water, everyone who contributed
will get an extra special gift!
Why can't I just buy it from Wrapt Collective directly?

This is our first ever Wrapt Collective Christmas, and we wanted to make sure we only produce what we need. By pre-ordering your gift wrap, you're helping ensure we actually have profits to contribute to forest conservation and not wasting paper!

Our aim

To save Santa from drowning &
column2:
help transform Christmas from the most wasteful time of year into the most environmentally generous holiday.

We wanted to use the much-loved tradition of gift wrapping to really make an impact. If everyone makes one small change to their Christmas shopping this year and chooses to wrap their gifts more sustainably, we could really start to have a positive effect on the environment. Eventually we hope that this will inspire other businesses to invest in more sustainable products.

Our main challenge this Christmas, is to reach our $100,000 goal to ensure we can continue Wrapt Collective's efforts throughout the year, covering Birthdays, Weddings, Christenings and just because presents.

50% of any profits remaining after the perks have been distributed will go to the Carbon Neutral Charitable Fund, with the other 50% going back into the business to  create new designs for a wider range of occasions, expansion of range (e.g into wine bags), and product innovation.

Impact

The money we spend at Christmas has a big impact! It's up to us to choose whether it's positive or negative.

At the moment, more trees are cut down than planted at Christmas. If enough people start wrapping their gifts using Wrapt Collective's 100% post-consumer waste recycled paper, with 50% of profits going to reforestation, we could eventually have more trees planted

column1:
than cut down every Christmas!

Help us transform Christmas from the most wasteful season into the most environmentally generous holiday (and avoid killing Santa in the process) by wrapping your gifts this Christmas in Wrapt Collective designs.

With no new trees cut down to produce Wrapt Collective paper and 50% of
profits going to the Carbon Neutral Charitable fund to plant new

Australian native trees and shrubs and conserve existing forests.

While we can't guarantee that wrapping your gifts with Wrapt Collective alone will save Santa, at least you'll be able to sleep easy knowing you weren't the one who accidentally killed him!

In the Workshop...

It's a bit quiet in the Wrapt Collective workshop at this time of year as Santa needs most of his helpers at the North Pole. We're hoping to hire some more helpers as a result of this campaign.

Stephanta is one pretty capable little helper though, she's earned a marketing and accounting hat, which she switches between frequently. Mac also helps out where he can, but let's be honest, he's more moral support more than anything else.
Please note: Just like Global Warming, Santa may or may

not exist. But one thing’s for sure, you definitely don’t want to be the one  accidentally responsible for killing the guy, and surely it can't hurt to spend your money funding tree planting instead of tree felling!
Please don't forget to share our campaign with your friends and family!
Happy Wrapting! x

","The rising global temperature is melting the ice that surrounds the North Pole, and WWF predicts that if things don't start to cool down, it may disappear within the next generation, rendering Santa homeless and at risk of drowning! So the time has come to give back to Santa and make sure he can continue

to call the North Pole home! To help save Santa, Wrapt Collective has created an easy way to wrap your gifts more sustainably this Christmas. Every gift wrapped with  Wrapt Collective materials helps to preserve and regenerate forests, and keep Santa afloat. To give back to the environment, Wrapt Collective wrapping paper and gift tags are printed on 100% recycled paper, the ribbon and sticky tape are 100% biodegradable, plus 50% of profits go to reforestation. If enough people wrap this way, we could eventually have more trees planted than cut down every Christmas!
Our aim is to transform Christmas one gift at a time, from the most wasteful time of year, into the most environmentally prosperous holiday (and save Santa from the sharks in the process).
Not every gift bought this year will be sustainable, but every gift wrapped can be!
Introducing...
Potato Print DesignsAll designs are hand crafted from Australian potatoes.
100% Recycled Paper
Our potato print designs are reproduced on 100% post consumer waste recycled paper using soy based ink. Our printing partner, along with our paper are also FSC certified and Carbon Neutral.

100% BiodegradableAll our wrapping materials including the wrapping paper, gift tags, curling ribbon and sticky tape are biodegradable. So you can just pop everything in the compost after the fun of unwrapping is over. Or, of course, reuse the paper on another gift.
50% of profits go to forest conservation

We have partnered with the Carbon Neutral Charitable Fund to donate 50% of our operation profits after tax to forest conservation. This means we not only fund the planting of trees, but we make sure they're looked after!
Packaging

We are committed to making our business as environmentally friendly as possible, so our gift tag ties are made from biodegradable hemp and we ship our wrapping in recycled envelopes, boxes and tubes where possible.
What's going on at the North Pole?

Santa and his elves are in a bit of a tizz because the Arctic sea ice that surrounds the North Pole has decreased by 14% since the 1970's and WWF predicts that it may disappear in summer within the next generation. Which means, Santa and his elves may find themselves in a spot of bother and in need of some floaties!
Why Christmas?Christmas is when we are our most generous but also our most wasteful.
60% of Australians spend more than they earn at Christmas.
Globally it is estimated that around 23 million trees are cut down each Christmas to produce greeting cards and gift wrap.
But over 60% choose not to purchase more sustainable products because they are 'too expensive'.
What's in it for you?

Design testedThere's no way you can make a present wrapped in Wrapt Collective look bad! We've made sure all our designs look fabo together so you can mix and match till your heart's content. Plus the ribbon and paper are super easy to work with and we have tips on YouTube for inspiration. AffordableUnderstanding that the biggest barrier to purchasing sustainable products is price, we've done our best to make the Wrapt Collective range as affordable as possible, and included ways for everyone to get involved. Only with your support will we be able to reach the scale required to make our range even more affordable. Why not team up with your friends and family to get the best deal on a bulk perk! ShippingThe perks will be shipped during the first week of December to ensure arrival before Christmas. Wrapping
Wrapping tools

Gift Tags90x40mm, 200gsm, hemp chordComes in four designs: Reindeer, Candy Cane, Gingerbread Man, & Santa's HatAll designs are crafted using hand cut, Australian-grown potatoes and reproduced on 100% recycled paper using soy inks. Both the paper and the printing process are FSC certified and carbon neutral.  Wrapping Paper690x490mmComes in four designs: Christmas Tree, Reindeer, Gingerbread Man, & PresentAll designs are crafted using hand cut,
Australian-grown potatoes and reproduced on 100% recycled paper using
soy inks. Both the paper and the printing process are FSC certified and

carbon neutral. Curling Ribbon5/8"", 100% cotton Comes in three candy stripe designs: Red & White, Green & White, & Dark Green & Light GreenDyed using soy based dyes, the ribbon not only great to work with and very versatile, but is also biodegradable.Envirotape10x12mm, biodegradableThe tape that holds everything together, all your environmentally friendly efforts may come undone the sticky tape has to be removed from the paper before it can be recycled. 100% biodegradable, this tape allows you to pop all the Christmas unwrapping straight in the compost!
What can I do?
The average Australian spends $374 on
Christmas gifts each year, equating to a National total of $8 billion!
We're hoping to attract at least a small portion of this to help our
Christmas spending have a more positive impact without giving up gift
wrapping.

25 child’s bee veils: bee conservation from preschool age:

Kids must be properly informed about bees from their yearly years so they will be able to make the right choices in future.

Teachers and especially students of our local elementary school and preschool in Klettgau, Germany, are very interested in field studies and lessons about bees (including proper bee handling, bee behavior, bee biology, etc.) at the place where bees are kept – i.e., at the apiary.

As a member of our local kindergarten’s parental committee and a passionate beekeeper, I would like to offer free field studies at my apiary whenever our preschool or school students and teachers would like.

My bees are peaceful
column2:
however they are flying and impulsive animals, and anything can happen near the beehives. Therefore I’d like to offer maximum head and face protection for the children and teachers. 

A child’s bee veil costs 25€, and a maximum of 25 bee veils are needed.

Dear CrowdFunding Community, please donate for the head and face protection of these schoolchildren.

 25 bee veils x 25€ = 625€

Children in elementary schools and preschools today are our decision-makers tomorrow. Therefore, I’d like to install a wild bee shelter and bumblebee hive in each kindergarten and preschool yard.

A lifelong wild bee shelter =  100€

A weatherproof bumblebee house =  150€

25 child’s bee veils + 2 wild bee shelters + 2 bumblebee houses

 

Total funds = 1125€


(A crash course about bees: before humans, bees had to deal with wild animals like bears and honey badgers. Those animals had thick skins and fur, so bees soon learned to sting in to their weakest body parts: their mouths, eyes and noses!)

Please, help us to involve schoolchildren in beekeeping and bee conservation.

Giving children the correct knowledge about bees – that, that they are actually fragile and sensitive animals – is an essential first step towards bee conservation! Let’s make it together!

                                     Please help!

column6:
>Overview

No one can deny that modern energy services are critical enablers for human development. People need and use energy to carry out all manner of tasks, from basic lighting to transportation, to powering industries. Modern energy - and clean technologies like solar and wind power - are necessary requirements for sustainable development and safeguarding the environment.

column1: Here at Energy Action Partners, we believe that energy technology is one part of a broader development story. Energy access programs can have a much greater impact when communities are deeply involved in the process of energy system design and management. Our goal at ENACT is to develop and promote new approaches to building community energy systems that prioritize capacity building, strengthen local institutions and create thriving communities.

To do this, we approach community energy system design and planning a little differently. Instead of planning a community energy system the conventional way through project developer-led surveys and assessments, we enable communities to lead and own the planning process by playing a fun and interactive game we call, The Minigrid Game.

column4: >In the Minigrid Game, players come together to play out household consumption and make important energy choices, like purchasing appliances, setting energy tariffs, and managing finances to pay their bills on time. Players' individual behavior, like switching appliances on and off, or failing to make a payment, are immediately visible to everyone else.

column1: The game is cooperative, and can only be won when the community decides on an appropriately sized system, sets a tariff that pays for its cost, and consumes just the right amount of energy to stay within the limited capacity. A few surprises along the way, like hurricanes, lost income or unexpected inheritances add to the fun and challenges that they must overcome.

The Minigrid Game is a completely novel way for communities to develop workable solutions to the unique challenges of managing a community minigrid, such as system sizing, tariff-setting, and demand-side management. By playing as a group, the players can also improve their understanding of energy technology, practice negotiation and consensus-building skills, and most importantly, have fun.
How The Game Is Played

We have developed a basic software version of the game, played on wirelessly connected computers. We are currently working on further software development and prototyping a robust, physical console to be used as an optional user interface. Players will have the option of playing The Minigrid Game on a computer or electronic device using the game's digital dashboard screen, or using the physical console, an electronic board resembling a house with miniature appliances that can be 'plugged' in and turned 'on' or 'off'.
<h3>What We Need &amp
column2:
What You Get

We need your help in raising the funds for a field-ready version of The Minigrid Game, and for testing it in rural and remote communities with a direct need.

column1:
We are hoping to raise $35,000 that covers:
1. Further software development 
2. Prototyping a robust physical console
3. Field testing in remote communities
We previously tested our software version of The Minigrid Game in Ladakh, India
column3: and Sabah, Malaysia. We've received tremendous interest from villagers, project developers and energy planners in The Minigrid Game's potential to change the way we co-design and co-plan community energy systems.

column1: Please help us reach our goal by contributing funds. If you aren't able to, please help show your support by spreading the word and helping us make some noise about The Minigrid Game!

Help us share this link: www.enactpartners.org/the-minigrid-game
Or our campaign link: https://igg.me/at/the-minigrid-game/

Connect with us at:
LinkedIn: www.linkedin.com/company/energy-action-partners
Instagram: www.instagram.com/ENACT_Partners
Google+: http://google.com/+enactpartnersorg
Or using the links below.

","Overview No one can deny that modern energy services are critical enablers for human development. People need and use energy to carry out all manner of tasks, from basic lighting to transportation, to powering industries. Modern energy - and clean technologies like solar and wind power - are necessary requirements for sustainable development and safeguarding the environment.

Here at Energy Action Partners, we believe that energy technology is one part of a broader development story. Energy access programs can have a much greater impact when communities are deeply involved in the process of energy system design and management. Our goal at ENACT is to develop and promote new approaches to building community energy systems that prioritize capacity building, strengthen local institutions and create thriving communities.

To do this, we approach community energy system design and planning a little differently. Instead of planning a community energy system the conventional way through project developer-led surveys and assessments, we enable communities to lead and own the planning process by playing a fun and interactive game we call, The Minigrid Game.
The Minigrid Game

In the Minigrid Game, players come together to play out household consumption and make important energy choices, like purchasing appliances, setting energy tariffs, and managing finances to pay their bills on time. Players' individual behavior, like switching appliances on and off, or failing to make a payment, are immediately visible to everyone else.

The game is cooperative, and can only be won when the community decides on an appropriately sized system, sets a tariff that pays for its cost, and consumes just the right amount of energy to stay within the limited capacity. A few surprises along the way, like hurricanes, lost income or unexpected inheritances add to the fun and challenges that they must overcome.

The Minigrid Game is a completely novel way for communities to develop workable solutions to the unique challenges of managing a community minigrid, such as system sizing, tariff-setting, and demand-side management. By playing as a group, the players can also improve their understanding of energy technology, practice negotiation and consensus-building skills, and most importantly, have fun.
How The Game Is Played

We have developed a basic software version of the game, played on wirelessly connected computers. We are currently working on further software development and prototyping a robust, physical console to be used as an optional user interface. Players will have the option of playing The Minigrid Game on a computer or electronic device using the game's digital dashboard screen, or using the physical console, an electronic board resembling a house with miniature appliances that can be 'plugged' in and turned 'on' or 'off'.
