English (Spanish translation at the bottom):

Our campaign aims to protect and document our local river, El Rio de Aguas by raising public awareness of its amazing wildlife and limited underground water resources.The ancient fossil water aquifer located in the Sorbas-Tabernas basin (Andalucia, Spain) that feeds our river has been over exploited to a point that it is about to disappear. The flow rate of the river has decreased from 40 litres per second to 10 litres per second, a drop in flow of 75%. As a result this unique river ecosystem is now facing Ecocide.
<h4>Our
Project
Our
project aims to document as many of the current species as possible,
starting with the ones most in danger of extinction, while also
documenting all the green areas on the river through a combination of
aerial filming, landscape photography and underwater filming. We hope
to inspire more people to actively get involved in the conservation
of this unique river, its water resources and surrounding national
park. Our photos and videos were recently featured on Spanish RTVE's
documentary ""El Ultimo Oasis"":
http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/videos/el-escarabajo-verde/escarabajo-verde-ultimo-oasis/3383219/

But our financial resources are limited and here is where we need your help. Our project started in November 2014 and so far, the results have been beyond our expectations in terms of biodiversity: we have documented over 100 species, including over a dozen protected species and many rare species. We have also started an archive of river locations to include all the areas that still have water within the river basin. All together we have gathered a database of over 20,000 photos of both wildlife and landscapes. Some of these photos will be included in our upcoming pocket guide on ""Protected, endemic and rare species of Rio de Aguas"". Other photos are already exhibited in local markets and town halls:

column5:
>

Our river is in danger of extinction!

column1: The most serious threat to our river is the increased pumping of underground water for industrial irrigation. 6000 hectares of olive plantations have been given permissions to extract water from the aquifer that feeds our river. These trees are planted at a density of 1,800 trees per hectare, using approximately 5,000 tons of water per year per hectare. Over 2 million trees have already been planted.

In 2010 an agreement between Junta De Andalucia and the European Commission stipulated that by 2015 the over exploitation would be reduced by 200%, as the withdrawals of water in 2010 were already exceeding available resources by 330%. Not only has this directive been totally ignored, but we estimate that with the new plantations, the over exploitation is now at 500%. To this day Medio Ambiente and Junta de Andalucia remain indifferent and unresponsive to our requests for information relating to the condition of the aquifer, as well as evading responsibility for their non-compliance with their 2010 EC agreements. Intensive planting is continuing and extraction of water is increasing despite all signs of this resource depleting.
Photo: Intensive olive plantations outside Tabernas
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
Why is Rio de Aguas unique?
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5:
>

El Rio de Aguas is the last oasis of abundant life in the fragile ecosystems of Paraje Natural Karst en Yesos of Sorbas and one of the few rivers in South of Spain that still flows all year round.

column1: The river is a remarkable example of a oasis effect in the only semi-arid zone in Western Europe with an average rainfall of around 200 mm of water/year, that's both a sanctuary for local species and a refuelling temporary home for migratory species. The presence of water has resulted in a corridor of green vegetation, that supports a large number of plant and insect species. This abundance of plants and insects attracts species that are normally rare in this part of Spain, such as endangered Mediterranean tortoises and pond turtles, countless species of birds, big herbivores and omnivores such as the Southern Spanish Ibex, badgers, wild boar and ultimately carnivores such as foxes, stone martens, genets, eagles, vultures and owls.

Parque Natural Karst en Yesos de Sorbas is Spain's most important karst landscape composed of gypsum (yeso), and one of the best examples of its kind in the world. Although the park is fairly small in size (2,375ha) its gypsophyte flora is of exceptional botanical interest, with many endemic, rare or endangered species. Gypsum is highly toxic for most plants, but gypsophyte species thrive in this type of soil and are abundant in this area. The park has only around 5% of Spain's total gypsum territory, but it harbors about  50% of its gypsophyte plant species, several of which are now at risk  of extinction.

Our budget

With your donations we hope to have a permanent presence on the river, as follows:

- a £2000 budget will buy more wildlife monitoring cameras, pay for printing of some campaign materials and ensure that we can continue running our project until the end of spring 2016

- a £3000 budget will buy 10 extra monitoring cameras, cover our costs for printing and organizing additional exhibitions of our photos and videos locally, and keep our project running until the summer of 2016

- a £4000 budget will buy us all the equipment needed such as monitoring cameras, lenses, gps devices, allow for printing and exhibiting photos, assist with talks and campaigns on the river, finalize our pocket guide on ""Protected, endemic and rare species of Rio de Aguas""  and keep the project running until the end of 2016.

Thank you from everyone at Save El Rio de Aguas! If you wish to volunteer with us or require additional information, please contact us at:  https://www.facebook.com/riodeaguas

Our team: Siobhan, Jackie, Calma, Ion, Ciprian, Zack and Daq. Translation by Marina.

Spanish translation:
El
Río de Aguas (Almería, España) está enfrentándose a la
extinción. Ayúdanos a proteger y documentar nuestro río alzando la
concienciación sobre su fauna maravillosa.
Nuestra
campaña tiene el objetivo de proteger y documentar nuestro río
local, el Río de Aguas, mediante el aumento de la concienciación
pública sobre su fascinante fauna, flora y sus limitados recursos de agua subterránea. El acuífero de
ancestral agua fósil localizado en la cuenca de Sorbas-Tabernas
(Andalucía, España), que alimenta nuestro río, ha sido
sobre-explotado hasta el extremo de estar a punto de desaparecer. Los
niveles de los manantiales del río han bajado de 40 litros por
segundo a 10 litros por segundo, un descenso de su afluencia en un
75%. Como resultado, este singular ecosistema de río está
enfrentándose a un Ecocidio.
<b>Nuestro
Proyecto
Nuestro
proyecto tiene el objetivo de documentar tantas especies como nos sea
posible, empezando por las que están en mayor peligro de extinción
mientras documentamos también todas las zonas verdes del río a
través de una combinación de grabación aérea, fotografía
paisajística y grabación acuática. Esperamos inspirar así a más
gente para que participe activamente en la conservación de este río
único, sus recursos de agua y el paraje natural que lo rodea.
Nuestras fotos y vídeos fueron destacadas en el documental de RTVE”,
«El último oasis»:
http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/videos/el-escarabajo-verde/escarabajo-verde-ultimo-oasis/3383219/
Nos
encontramos con unos recursos financieros limitados y aquí es donde
necesitamos tu ayuda. Nuestro proyecto empezó en noviembre de 2014 y
hasta ahora los resultados han ido más allá de nuestras
expectativas en términos de biodiversidad: tenemos documentadas más
de 100 especies, incluyendo más de una docena de especies protegidas
y muchas especies raras. Hemos empezado a archivar también todas las
localizaciones de la cuenca del río que todavía tienen agua. En
total, hemos recaudado una base de datos de más de 20.000 fotos de
fauna, flora y paisajes. Algunas de estas fotos serán incluidas en
nuestra próxima guía de bolsillo «Especies protegidas, endémicas
y raras del Río de Aguas», otras, están siendo exhibidas en
mercados locales y ayuntamientos.
<b>¡Nuestro
río está en peligro de extinción!
La
amenaza más seria a la que se enfrenta nuestro río es la creciente
extracción de agua subterránea para regadío industrial. Se han
concedido permisos para extraer agua del acuífero que alimenta
nuestro río, destinada a regar 6000 hectáreas de plantaciones de
olivos. Éstos se plantan con una densidad de 1.800 árboles por
hectárea, usando aproximadamente 5.000 toneladas anuales de agua por
hectárea. Ya han sido plantados más de dos millones de olivos.
En
2010 un acuerdo entre la Junta de Andalucía y la Comisión Europea
estipulaba que para el 2015 la sobre-explotación se habría reducido
en un 200% respecto de las mediciones de agua que en 2010 mostraban
un exceso en la explotación de un 330%. Esta directiva no solo ha
sido totalmente ignorada, sino que además estimamos que con las
nuevas plantaciones la sobre-explotación está ahora en un 500%. A
día de hoy, Medio Ambiente y la Junta de Andalucía se mantienen
indiferentes y no responden a nuestras demandas de información
acerca de las condiciones del acuífero, además de estar evitando
responder al incumplimiento de los acuerdos de la C.E. de 2010. La
plantación <u>(super)</u>intensiva
continúa y la extracción de agua está aumentando, a pesar de que
todo indica que este recurso se está agotando.
El
Río de Aguas es el último oasis de vida abundante en el frágil
ecosistema del Paraje Natural Karst en Yesos de Sorbas y uno de los
pocos ríos en el sur de España que todavía tiene agua todo el año.
El
Río es un ejemplo relevante del efecto que tiene un oasis en la
única zona semi-árida en el oeste de Europa, con una media de
lluvias anuales de unos 200 mm de agua/año, que es a su vez un
santuario para las especies locales y una hábitat temporal para
especies migratorias. La presencia de agua ha dado como resultado una
franja verde, que acoge a un gran número de plantas y especies de
insectos. Esta abundancia de plantas e insectos atrae especies que
normalmente son raras de ver en esta parte de España, como lo son
las tortugas mediterráneas y las tortugas galápago, innumerables
especies de pájaros, grandes herbívoros y omnívoros (como la cabra
montesa del sur de España,tejones
y jabalíes) y, en última instancia, carnívoros como zorros,
garduñas, ginetas, águilas, buitres y búhos.
El
Parque Natural Karst en Yesos de Sorbas es el paisaje con formaciones
de karst en yeso más importante de España y uno de los mejores
ejemplos de este tipo en el mundo. Aunque el parque es bastante
pequeño en tamaño (2,375ha) su flora yesífera es de excepcional
interés botánico, con muchas especies endémicas, raras o en
peligro. El yeso es altamente tóxico para la mayoría de las
plantas, pero las especies yesíferas prosperan en este tipo de suelo
y son abundantes en la zona. El parque solo tiene alrededor de un 5%
del terrirorio total de yeso en España, pero aloja alrededor del 50%
de sus especies yesíferas, muchas de las cuales están ahora en
peligro de extinción.
<b>Nuestro
presupuesto
Con
vuestras donaciones esperamos tener una presencia constante en el
río, como sigue:
2000 libras del presupuesto servirán para comprar más cámaras de
monitoreo, para pagar la impresión de algunos materiales para la
campaña y para garantizar que podamos seguir con nuestro proyecto
hasta el final de la <b>primavera
3000 libras irán destinadas a pagar 10 cámaras más de monitoreo,
cubrir los gastos de impresión y organizar exhibiciones de nuestras
fotos y vídeos en el área local, y mantendrá nuestro proyecto en
marcha hasta el <b>verano
4000 libras se usarán para terminar de comprar todo el equipo
necesario (cámaras de monitoreo, lentes y dispositivos de gps),
permitirán la impresión y exhibición de fotos, la organización de
charlas y campañas sobre nuestro río, financiará nuestro proyecto
de una guía de bolsillo «Especies protegidas, endémicas y raras de
El Río de Aguas» y mantendrá el proyecto en marcha hasta <b>finales
¡Todos
los integrantes de Salva El Río de Aguas te damos las gracias ! Si
quieres colaborar con nosotros o te gustaría cualquier información
adicional, porfavor contáctanos en:
https://www.facebook.com/riodeaguas
Nuestro equipo : Siobhan , Jackie , Calma , Ion , Ciprian , Zack y Daq . Traducción de Marina .

","English (Spanish translation at the bottom):Our campaign aims to protect and document our local river, El Rio de Aguas by raising public awareness of its amazing wildlife and limited underground water resources.The ancient fossil water aquifer located in the Sorbas-Tabernas basin (Andalucia, Spain) that feeds our river has been over exploited to a point that it is about to disappear. The flow rate of the river has decreased from 40 litres per second to 10 litres per second, a drop in flow of 75%. As a result this unique river ecosystem is now facing Ecocide.
Our
Project
Our
project aims to document as many of the current species as possible,
starting with the ones most in danger of extinction, while also
documenting all the green areas on the river through a combination of
aerial filming, landscape photography and underwater filming. We hope
to inspire more people to actively get involved in the conservation
of this unique river, its water resources and surrounding national
park. Our photos and videos were recently featured on Spanish RTVE's
documentary ""El Ultimo Oasis"":
http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/videos/el-escarabajo-verde/escarabajo-verde-ultimo-oasis/3383219/

But our financial resources are limited and here is where we need your help. Our project started in November 2014 and so far, the results have been beyond our expectations in terms of biodiversity: we have documented over 100 species, including over a dozen protected species and many rare species. We have also started an archive of river locations to include all the areas that still have water within the river basin. All together we have gathered a database of over 20,000 photos of both wildlife and landscapes. Some of these photos will be included in our upcoming pocket guide on ""Protected, endemic and rare species of Rio de Aguas"". Other photos are already exhibited in local markets and town halls:
Our river is in danger of extinction!

The most serious threat to our river is the increased pumping of underground water for industrial irrigation. 6000 hectares of olive plantations have been given permissions to extract water from the aquifer that feeds our river. These trees are planted at a density of 1,800 trees per hectare, using approximately 5,000 tons of water per year per hectare. Over 2 million trees have already been planted.

In 2010 an agreement between Junta De Andalucia and the European Commission stipulated that by 2015 the over exploitation would be reduced by 200%, as the withdrawals of water in 2010 were already exceeding available resources by 330%. Not only has this directive been totally ignored, but we estimate that with the new plantations, the over exploitation is now at 500%. To this day Medio Ambiente and Junta de Andalucia remain indifferent and unresponsive to our requests for information relating to the condition of the aquifer, as well as evading responsibility for their non-compliance with their 2010 EC agreements. Intensive planting is continuing and extraction of water is increasing despite all signs of this resource depleting.
Photo: Intensive olive plantations outside Tabernas
Why is Rio de Aguas unique?
El Rio de Aguas is the last oasis of abundant life in the fragile ecosystems of Paraje Natural Karst en Yesos of Sorbas and one of the few rivers in South of Spain that still flows all year round.

The river is a remarkable example of a oasis effect in the only semi-arid zone in Western Europe with an average rainfall of around 200 mm of water/year, that's both a sanctuary for local species and a refuelling temporary home for migratory species. The presence of water has resulted in a corridor of green vegetation, that supports a large number of plant and insect species. This abundance of plants and insects attracts species that are normally rare in this part of Spain, such as endangered Mediterranean tortoises and pond turtles, countless species of birds, big herbivores and omnivores such as the Southern Spanish Ibex, badgers, wild boar and ultimately carnivores such as foxes, stone martens, genets, eagles, vultures and owls.

Parque Natural Karst en Yesos de Sorbas is Spain's most important karst landscape composed of gypsum (yeso), and one of the best examples of its kind in the world. Although the park is fairly small in size (2,375ha) its gypsophyte flora is of exceptional botanical interest, with many endemic, rare or endangered species. Gypsum is highly toxic for most plants, but gypsophyte species thrive in this type of soil and are abundant in this area. The park has only around 5% of Spain's total gypsum territory, but it harbors about  50% of its gypsophyte plant species, several of which are now at risk  of extinction.

Our budgetWith your donations we hope to have a permanent presence on the river, as follows:- a £2000 budget will buy more wildlife monitoring cameras, pay for printing of some campaign materials and ensure that we can continue running our project until the end of spring 2016- a £3000 budget will buy 10 extra monitoring cameras, cover our costs for printing and organizing additional exhibitions of our photos and videos locally, and keep our project running until the summer of 2016- a £4000 budget will buy us all the equipment needed such as monitoring cameras, lenses, gps devices, allow for printing and exhibiting photos, assist with talks and campaigns on the river, finalize our pocket guide on ""Protected, endemic and rare species of Rio de Aguas""  and keep the project running until the end of 2016.

Thank you from everyone at Save El Rio de Aguas! If you wish to volunteer with us or require additional information, please contact us at:  https://www.facebook.com/riodeaguasOur team: Siobhan, Jackie, Calma, Ion, Ciprian, Zack and Daq. Translation by Marina.Spanish translation:
El
Río de Aguas (Almería, España) está enfrentándose a la
extinción. Ayúdanos a proteger y documentar nuestro río alzando la
concienciación sobre su fauna maravillosa.
Nuestra
campaña tiene el objetivo de proteger y documentar nuestro río
local, el Río de Aguas, mediante el aumento de la concienciación
pública sobre su fascinante fauna, flora y sus limitados recursos de agua subterránea. El acuífero de
ancestral agua fósil localizado en la cuenca de Sorbas-Tabernas
(Andalucía, España), que alimenta nuestro río, ha sido
sobre-explotado hasta el extremo de estar a punto de desaparecer. Los
niveles de los manantiales del río han bajado de 40 litros por
segundo a 10 litros por segundo, un descenso de su afluencia en un
75%. Como resultado, este singular ecosistema de río está
enfrentándose a un Ecocidio.
Nuestro
Proyecto
Nuestro
proyecto tiene el objetivo de documentar tantas especies como nos sea
posible, empezando por las que están en mayor peligro de extinción
mientras documentamos también todas las zonas verdes del río a
través de una combinación de grabación aérea, fotografía
paisajística y grabación acuática. Esperamos inspirar así a más
gente para que participe activamente en la conservación de este río
único, sus recursos de agua y el paraje natural que lo rodea.
Nuestras fotos y vídeos fueron destacadas en el documental de RTVE”,
«El último oasis»:
http://www.rtve.es/alacarta/videos/el-escarabajo-verde/escarabajo-verde-ultimo-oasis/3383219/
Nos
encontramos con unos recursos financieros limitados y aquí es donde
necesitamos tu ayuda. Nuestro proyecto empezó en noviembre de 2014 y
hasta ahora los resultados han ido más allá de nuestras
expectativas en términos de biodiversidad: tenemos documentadas más
de 100 especies, incluyendo más de una docena de especies protegidas
y muchas especies raras. Hemos empezado a archivar también todas las
localizaciones de la cuenca del río que todavía tienen agua. En
total, hemos recaudado una base de datos de más de 20.000 fotos de
fauna, flora y paisajes. Algunas de estas fotos serán incluidas en
nuestra próxima guía de bolsillo «Especies protegidas, endémicas
y raras del Río de Aguas», otras, están siendo exhibidas en
mercados locales y ayuntamientos.
¡Nuestro
río está en peligro de extinción!
La
amenaza más seria a la que se enfrenta nuestro río es la creciente
extracción de agua subterránea para regadío industrial. Se han
concedido permisos para extraer agua del acuífero que alimenta
nuestro río, destinada a regar 6000 hectáreas de plantaciones de
olivos. Éstos se plantan con una densidad de 1.800 árboles por
hectárea, usando aproximadamente 5.000 toneladas anuales de agua por
hectárea. Ya han sido plantados más de dos millones de olivos.
En
2010 un acuerdo entre la Junta de Andalucía y la Comisión Europea
estipulaba que para el 2015 la sobre-explotación se habría reducido
en un 200% respecto de las mediciones de agua que en 2010 mostraban
un exceso en la explotación de un 330%. Esta directiva no solo ha
sido totalmente ignorada, sino que además estimamos que con las
nuevas plantaciones la sobre-explotación está ahora en un 500%. A
día de hoy, Medio Ambiente y la Junta de Andalucía se mantienen
indiferentes y no responden a nuestras demandas de información
acerca de las condiciones del acuífero, además de estar evitando
responder al incumplimiento de los acuerdos de la C.E. de 2010. La
plantación (super)intensiva
continúa y la extracción de agua está aumentando, a pesar de que
todo indica que este recurso se está agotando.
El

pocos ríos en el sur de España que todavía tiene agua todo el año.

column1: ","About us
We are a like-minded group connected by a common vision for people and nature.

Our creative founding team has a mix of long experience in education, crafts, organic farming, entrepreneurship and volunteering. Sustainability, environmental awareness, cooperation and enhancement of the well-being of all are our priorities.
What We Need & What You Get
Key to the project is the restoration of the lovely 100 year old building on the site - the future hub of activities.
We need 15,000 euros to fix the roof and walls of this important building.
OUR PERKS
5 seed bombs ready to throw and grow ~ 15 euros
12 gr. of a herbal remedy of your choice ~ 25 euros
200 gr. of herbal seasoning salts of your choice ~ 25 euros
200 gr. of bath salts of your choice ~ 25 euros
300gr. of capers from the gardens ~ 50 euros
Special edition of 3 herbal seasoning salts ~ 60 euros
Special edition of 3 bath salts ~ 60 euros
Our vision

This small Botanical Garden,  will be an ""ark"" of our plant wealth, an autonomous centre of education, environmental awareness, research and study, yet a natural jewel, providing emotional uplift and knowledge for all ages.

Our vision is that the Botanical Garden becomes a place of inspiration and creativity through our genuine relationship with nature but also through community concepts, health, self-sufficiency and sustainable agriculture.

With partnerships and synergies, educational programs and services we want to function as a thematic and alternative tourism attraction and at the same time contribute to the local and regional sustainable development. A harmonious relationship between man and nature is the motivation and goal for our project.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ZWER_PtNvMChallenges

Come and camp on the land and volunteer your time to help create an oasis where nature is protected and encouraged to flourish.

column1: ","Notre Projet
Bonjour à tous,
Cured Vine est un projet scientifique mené par une équipe d'étudiants bordelais.

Bien sûr, ne vous en faites pas, nous allons tout faire pour rendre ce projet le plus compréhensible possible auprès de tous ! Ce projet est tout ce qu’il y a de plus sérieux et s’inscrit dans le cadre d’une compétition étudiante internationale : l’iGEM (international Genetically Engineered Machines). Comme son nom l’indique est une compétition de biologie de synthèse (on reviendra sur ce principe plus tard) organisée par la fondation iGEM qui rassemble cette année plusieurs centaines d’équipes à travers le monde.

Comme chaque équipe participante, nous allons utiliser les outils de la biologie de synthèse pour imaginer et créer de nouveaux systèmes biologiques avec des propriétés étonnantes. La biologie de synthèse, c’est un des domaines qui connait le plus de croissance dans le secteur de la biologie et des biotechnologies. Cette discipline regroupe l’ensemble des techniques utilisées par les généticiens, les biologistes moléculaires et autres scientifiques qui permettent de concevoir des organismes vivants avec des caractéristiques inédites.

Oui bon euh ... ça serait drôle en effet, mais ce n'est rien de tout ça. Ce que nous allons utiliser pour créer notre système biologique est un être vivant bien plus petit, même invisible à l’œil nu et pourtant présent dans chacun de nous. Il s'agit d'Escherichia coli et de Saccharomyces Cerevisae, qui sont respectivement une bactérie et une levure bien connue des scientifiques.

Bien évidemment ! Vous ne le savez surement pas mais les bactéries sont utiles pour plein de choses. Ce sont même elles aujourd’hui qui produisent une partie des biocarburants ou certains de nos médicaments. Ce que nous allons leur faire fabriquer, c'est un traitement préventif pour la vigne et contre le Mildiou.Le Mildiou est une maladie dangereuse pour la vigne dont le seul traitement existant est le sulfate de cuivre. Cette petite poudre bleu est très efficace mais un fois qu'elle s'infiltre dans les sols elle pollue beaucoup et est mauvaise pour notre environnement.

L'iGEM Bordeaux propose une solution écologique qui s'appelle le Curdlan. Nous allons faire produire à notre bactérie et notre levure cette molécule qui n'est autre qu'un enchainement de pleins de glucoses à la suite. L'efficacité du Curdlan sur la vigne est déjà prouvé. En effet, une fois déposé sur ses feuilles, le Curdlan permet à la plante d'améliorer ses défenses immunitaires et de mieux se battre contre le Mildiou.
L'équipe iGEM Bordeaux 2015

Ce projet c’est avant tout une expérience qui se vit en groupe. L’équipe IGEM Bordeaux 2015 c’est Gabriel, Maxime, Hiba, Caroline, Gilles, Nicolas, Jean, Charlie, Emilie, Corentin, Kellian, Jean-Rémy, Edouard, Charlotte, Thomas, Diego, Marjorie, Lily, Claudia, Savandra, Marie, Jordan, Lauriane, Sophia et Cassandra, tous étudiants en école d’ingénieur (ENSTBB) ou à l’Université de Bordeaux et encadrés par Denis Dupuy, chercheur rattaché au IECB (Institut Européen de Chimie et de Biologie). Mais l’équipe IGEM Bordeaux 2015 c’est aussi toutes les personnes qui nous entourent au quotidien et qui nous aident à avancer dans ce projet ambitieux. Et puis, cette équipe c’est aussi un peu vous, passionnés de sciences ou simples curieux, qui comprenez l’intérêt de notre projet et l’intérêt de la biologie dans notre société actuelle. Au nom de toute l’équipe je vous adresse d’ores et déjà nos sincères remerciements pour les quelques minutes passées à découvrir notre projet.",5.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Bordeaux, France",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/cured-vine-igem-bordeaux/pica

Greenbroke Healers

is a unique equine assisted psychotherapy program in which we pair at-risk youth with rescue horses so that everyone gets helped.  This program is paid for with funds generated by our nonprofit, Five Hearts Healing Arts Foundation.  I am the CEO of Five Hearts Healing Arts Foundation and an equine therapist.  I have experienced first-hand the power of horses to help heal human beings.  Because horses are prey animals (compared to human beings which are predators), they have a unique abililty to sense their environment including physical energy, emotion, psychic energy, spiritual energy, sound, vibration and smell.  In this way they take in information about their human companions and utilize their instinct and intuition to make meaningful connection and give helpful feedback.  Many teens are alienated and feel different and alone.  Bonding with and playing with horses provides a sense of belonging, develops self efficacy, builds confidence, and reduces stress.  These are just the behavioral effects.   Effects of contact with these right brain, instinctive creatures helps heal at the neurological level, a level needed to heal trauma and PTSD.  Finally, contact with gentle people helps rescue horses learn that ""humans are good people.""  They can overcome past abuse, develop trust and respect until they are true companions and able to be placed in their ""forever homes.""  

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

In order to provide a healing environment for at risk youth and horses, we need art supplies, food, books, films, horse feed, hoof care, grooming supplies, and tack.  Our budget for the pilot program is $10,000.  We have already raised $7,000.  We need $3,000 to meet expenses for the first program.  Completing it will give us test data which will help us meet ongoing funding goals
column3: >via grants.  If just 30 people gave $100 we would make our goal and the healing could begin.  All donations are tax deductible!

> 

  • $100 per month per horse for hay

column1: • $35 every six weeks per horse for foot care
• $50 a month for healthy snacks for kids
• $600 per week for staff salaries

If we don't make our goal, the funds we do collect will go to direct services.  These services will continue as long as we have funding.  All of your donations will go to help kids.  We pay no rent (our ranch is donated) or utilities (because we are strictly solar powered).  This means your funds really do go to the kids and horses.

The Impact

At risk youth can be our next moms, dads, leaders, executives, artists, mathematicians, and policy makers.  But only if they have a chance to develop the sense of worth and confidence that lets them express their talents and heart.  This program offers direct healing experiences that develop these qualities.  It also invites the kids to return as mentors so they have an ongoing place of belonging.  They also learn the art of giving back.  Finally, they give a gift that few of us would have the courage to give....love and training for an unwanted horse....a devoted companion for the forever owner....a sense of self respect, bravery, compassion, and worth for themselves.
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Not every kid makes nor does every horse.  Some quit.  Some cannot be rehabilitated.  But if even one makes it...one is rehabilitated...one finds a sense of belonging so living makes sense, it is worth it.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

We realize not everyone has money to give.  But you can help us by sharing this link with your friends and family.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h2><span style=""color: #eb1478
Do you have a soft spot in your heart for Greece? If the answer is ""yes"", this probably has a lot to do with the magic of Greek nature! But what will Greece look like if it loses
the most precious pieces of its natural heritage?
Over the past 5 years, Greece
has  featured regularly in global media headlines. The well-publicised
financial crisis has certainly had a painful social and humanitarian impact.
However, there is also a hidden victim of this crisis: Greek nature.
<h3><span style=""color: #eb1478
Right now, nature protection
laws are under attack. Their dismantling is helping to sell off Greece’s
natural heritage to make a quick profit. Could you bear to see every stretch of
unspoilt beach and coastline used and abused within a timespan of only a few
years? No, these are “solutions” that will only add to Greece’s mounting
problems. This is a future we won’t accept! And with your help, we can
challenge it.
<h3><span style=""color: #eb1478
The stakes are high and now is
the time we can really make a difference! Your support will give WWF Greece the
means to fight for Greece’s future. Here are a few reasons to be optimistic:
<ul>
<li>Last
summer we stopped legislation that would effectively turn the Greek
coastline and beaches into large scale concrete tourist developments.
<li>Last winter
we worked in a broad coalition to stop legislation that would remove protection for forests burnt by
wildfires and enable illegal and environmentally destructive appropriation
of forest land.
<li>Throughout
the crisis, we have provided a lifeline for threatened species like the
loggerhead sea turtle and the Mediterranean monk seal. These are rare
Mediterranean species struggling for survival, precious pieces of Greece’s
living future.
Many more threats will be
coming our way in the next few months, but your support can give us the power
to deal with them. We will work on the ground to protect Greek nature and stop the
laws that aim to destroy it.
Ok, I'd like to help Greece, but why help nature and not people?
By helping save Greek nature,
you are protecting the very foundations of a healthy economy and the livelihoods
of Greek people! Important sectors for the country, such as tourism and

agriculture depend on a healthy natural environment!

What is your vision for Greece?
In times of crisis, we look to
our strengths to get us through. The strengths of this
country surely are its natural environment and its history. Greece can build a
more sustainable future but it needs to keep nature alive and
thriving to make it happen! Energy from the sun and wind, landscapes, cool forests
and crystal clear seas, amazing local food products, wines, olive oil, fruit
and vegetables, fresh fish from the sea: we are working hard to protect these
natural assets and to create a development paradigm that will make the best use
of them, rather than deplete and destroy them for short-term gain.
<h3><span style=""color: #eb1478

Our perks start from $5. Scroll down to see pictures of what you will receive to remind you of the amazing contribution you are making for Greek nature. And most importantly: we'll send you updates to let you know what we are accomplishing. After all, you will play a crucial role in helping us deal with emergencies
in the coming months, safeguarding our common natural heritage for many years
to come.
<h3><span style=""color: #eb1478
column4: >- If you are based in Greece and your credit card is restricted due to capital controls, please visit our page here.

column1: - Read more about our work: in English or in Greek

A few of our perks:

Campaign badge
column3:
/>


""Greece's heritage from Nature"" limited-edition book


Action postcard
column4:
/>

Any comments or questions? Please send us your feedback at a.kandarakis@wwf.gr

A simple solution to growing better plants

As any gardener and nursery worker will tell you plants grown
in a pot have to be maintained to prevent them from becoming pot bound. Without
remedial action a pot bound plant is likely to become unhealthy and may even
die. Dealing with a pot bound plant is something that nurseries and keen pot
gardeners work hard to avoid because it means additional work to fix, and then
the plant may still die.
Typically pot plants will be re-potted, potentially several
times, to prevent the plant from becoming bound. Plant pots that have been
developed to reduce the likelihood of a plant becoming root bound have been
around for a while. I have developed a pot technology that goes a bit further
than these and may provide significant benefits.
The
Gro-B-Lo is a re-usable plastic pot insert has the potential to greatly extend
the time that a plant may be kept in a pot thereby reducing the effort required
to maintain the plant and, as a bonus, results in bigger, stronger, healthier pot
plants that use water and fertiliser more efficiently. If the pot plant is
being grown on for planting out, when it is planted out the plant is less likely
to develop root shock, is less likely to die and is generally more robust. This
is likely to be related to improved root architecture and increased root
length.
The Gro-B-Lo is very simple, it forces the plant roots to grow
around the spiral training surface in the defined space. This results in
longer roots with an improved root architecture which utilises the soil matrix
more efficiently. In growing plants in pots, a ratio of above and below ground plant
mass that is close to 1:1 is something that the gardener is trying to achieve
and the Gro-B-Lo frequently comes closer to achieving this. That in itself was quite
a pleasing discovery but I have also found that plants grown using the Gro-B-Lo
appear to grow faster, have a greater stem circumference and stem length and a greater root length. The plants are just more robust. This was bought home to
me very firmly on a day following a 40<sup>o</sup>C day here in Tasmania –
something that is very uncommon. All of my control plants died, but every one
of the Gro-B-Lo plants survived and bounced back quickly.
Now,
following personal investigations and preliminary trials of the Gro-B-Lo carried
out at commercial and teaching plant nurseries, I passionately believe that
this is a product that will not only reduce costs in plant maintenance but will

produce better pot plants for nurseries and the home gardener.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

I have taken out an interim patent on the device but I

column1: need your help to meet the costs of patents in Australia, European Union, United
States, China, Japan, Brazil, Canada and India and if the campaign goes well
enough in South Africa and Kenya. Th  e target of $70,000 covers the costs of the patents

and lawyers and some set up costs.

We are not ready yet to produce the Gro-B-Lo but all donations will be rewarded in some way and certainly all are very much appreciated.
All donators go on a
wall of fame (unless you really don’t want to). Donations of $40 and upwards
will receive Gro-B-Lo pot inserts when they are produced.
Also available is :
a one on one session with Mark on thinking creatively and acting practically -
getting your creative ideas to the market. Mark has studied creative thinking
for a number of years. Together with a former principal he has developed an
innovative creative thinking program.
a portion of some donations to Gro-B-Lo can be passed on to a wildlife charity Cattle for Wildlife. Cattle for
Wildlife is a pilot
project of a larger program trialling a new approach to wildlife conservation. It
is based on the innovative approach of promoting the protection of endangered
wildlife by local communities, which in turn earn the proceeds from cattle
raised and sold in Australia as payment for their achievements.
The project involves the
protection of critically endangered <strong><span>northern
white rhino and endangered black rhino in Kenya, through the Ol Pejeta Conservancy. Having already undergone a
massive depletion of their populations in the 70s and 80s, these species are
again at risk of increases in poaching.
The Cattle for Wildlife

project is the brainchild of Mark (the Gro-B-Lo inventor), check it out on the web at http://www.bookendtrust.com/cfw

I am very confident we can get to the target figure, however, if we are not successful in reaching the goal for Gro-B-Lo that simply means we concentrate the patents applications on the main target markets of Australia and the U.S. and others as we can.

The Impact - ""why hasn't this been done before?""

That the Gro-B-Lo works there is little doubt and I firmly believe that Gro-B-Lo has real potential to reduce the time and effort required to manage plants in pots. That is not just my opinion it is shared by nursery and garden professionals we have involved in the research and development. Any nursery that saves itself even one re-potting or pot maintenance event can make big savings. One of the most common comments we receive from people we are describing the Gro-B-Lo to is ""Why has this not been done before."" 

Another area that is unexpected but really seems to be something that needs to be looked at more is that I am using less water to produce plants that are bigger, better and stronger. I believe it is a consequence of both the Gro-B-Lo itself - e.g. it appears to reduce evaporative loss of water from the pot, and that the root architecture is such that much more of the soil matrix is accessed and utilised.

The Gro-B-Lo device and idea has received support from many within the plant industry and business leaders:

""I have known Mark
Prichard for many years. Foremost to those who know Mark is his unquestionable
personal warmth, integrity and sincerity. He is a person of great character.
Mark is also a talented and creative individual. Matched with his very strong
intellect this affords him a highly inductive, innovative thinking ability which
he plays well in his work and creative passions. It's not surprising that he
would design such an intuitive yet remarkable unit such as the Grow-B-Lo.
In over 30 years as a Marketer and as an investment banker I have been involved
in numerous creative and technical commercial ideas - especially in the home
improvement and DIY space.
I find his Gro-B-Lo idea and prototype to be very well founded in science and
consumer need insight. Mark has extensively trialled and researched the product
which is in and of itself grounded in an obvious yet largely unmet consumer
need. The potential use and geographic markets for this product are extensive.
The core idea of the Gro-B-Lo essentially speaks for itself, I would highly
commend Marks personal integrity, and his idea to potential investors looking
for a positive and potentially very exciting product opportunity.""
Martin Ward
Executive General Manager, Consumer and Construction Products
DuluxGroup Ltd.
<b>Risks &amp
I have worked for many years developing the Gro-B-Lo but I recognise that
there may be improvements and innovations that you will tell us about. By
pledging support you also recognising that this is a new product and refinement
to the device may happen along the way and that there may be challenges.
We have been working with a manufacturer to
develop and refine the manufacturing process. Manufacturing is not part of the
Gro-B-Lo patent crowdfunding campaign. We will keep you up to date with

progress on this front via updates on social media and our web page.

Other Ways You Can Help
Tell your friends, tweet it, facebook it – just let

them know

Who Am I

My name is Mark Prichard. I am a high school teacher and creative artist based in Hobart, Australia.

Our Goal
We are just two friends that have a dream to see the world and help our planet.

Our names are Ryan Dempsey and Seth Ruggiero and we have decided to spend about one year on our bicycles. Starting in June of 2016, we will begin our journey from Prudhoe Bay in northern Alaska to Ushuaia, Argentina, the southernmost city in the world!  That's approximately 19,000 miles and 17 countries! Our route will run along the Pacific Ocean while roughly following the PanAmerican Highway system.

Along the way we will raise money to support a revolutionary non-profit organization, The Ocean Cleanup, which has developed ""the world's first feasible method to rid the oceans of plastic.""

Although we have been saving money and already have purchased much of our necessary gear, we need extra help. Your donation will help with our day-to-day expenses (mostly food and a few untimely bicycle repairs). The remaining sum of money we raise will go directly to The Ocean Cleanup. Click here to check out their website.
<div>

We will have five or six consecutive two-month-long campaigns throughout the duration of our trip (IndieGogo only allows a maximum of 60 days to campaign). Every 2 months we hope to raise over $5,000. We truly hope to raise over $30,000 by the conclusion of our trip, most of which will be donated to The Ocean Cleanup. It's more than possible.

From our total funds raised on this site, we anticipate spending (in addition to our own funds) about $3,000 apiece during our year-long tour. If we can reach our goal of $5,000 per 2-month campaign, we will raise over $30,000 and donate nearly $25,000 to The Ocean Cleanup! In addition to raising money for The Ocean Cleanup, we will also personally remove one grocery bag of trash from a local waterway for each $100 raised before we depart on our journey.

If you don't want to promote our journey, at the very least educate yourselves about the terrible conditions our oceans are currently in. The world needs our help. Read this article posted by The Geological Society of America about how this all affects humans, animals, and the earth.
<div>
About Us

Born and raised in eastern Pennsylvania, we both met while studying at Juniata College in central Pennsylvania. In January of 2015, six months after graduating, we moved to Bend, Oregon, bought and moved into a 1986 trailer, became AmeriCorps volunteers doing conservation work, and tried to save money for a year.
This January, after a year in Oregon, Seth moved to Southwest Utah to work as a field instructor for WinGate Wilderness Therapy while Ryan continues to live and work in Bend at Heart of Oregon Corps.
Unfortunately, we are still poor and need your help!
<div>

This is a once-in-a-lifetime experience that we can't miss out on. We are not professional bikers, just two ordinary fellas that want to see our beautiful earth while learning about the world and ourselves. Our oceans are in dire need, so we couldn't think of a better way to combine two dreams.

What We Need &
column2:
What You Get

We are hitting the road this summer no matter the circumstances. If you want to help, please do. We appreciate any help.

column1: <div>

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this website link and our story with anyone and everyone. Post this IndieGogo page and our social media links to your own social media pages. Do it as often as you can!
It may be hard for us to stay online as often as we need, but we will do our best to update the public as much as possible throughout our journey.
Check out our Facebook page for updates along the way!
The best way to promote anything is through word of mouth, so if you agree with our goals get out there and let others know. We can't do it without your help.
Thanks!
","Our Goal
We are just two friends that have a dream to see the world and help our planet.

Our names are Ryan Dempsey and Seth Ruggiero and we have decided to spend about one year on our bicycles. Starting in June of 2016, we will begin our journey from Prudhoe Bay in northern Alaska to Ushuaia, Argentina, the southernmost city in the world!  That's approximately 19,000 miles and 17 countries! Our route will run along the Pacific Ocean while roughly following the PanAmerican Highway system.

Along the way we will raise money to support a revolutionary non-profit organization, The Ocean Cleanup, which has developed ""the world's first feasible method to rid the oceans of plastic.""Although we have been saving money and already have purchased much of our necessary gear, we need extra help. Your donation will help with our day-to-day expenses (mostly food and a few untimely bicycle repairs). The remaining sum of money we raise will go directly to The Ocean Cleanup. Click here to check out their website.

We will have five or six consecutive two-month-long campaigns throughout the duration of our trip (IndieGogo only allows a maximum of 60 days to campaign). Every 2 months we hope to raise over $5,000. We truly hope to raise over $30,000 by the conclusion of our trip, most of which will be donated to The Ocean Cleanup. It's more than possible.

From our total funds raised on this site, we anticipate spending (in addition to our own funds) about $3,000 apiece during our year-long tour. If we can reach our goal of $5,000 per 2-month campaign, we will raise over $30,000 and donate nearly $25,000 to The Ocean Cleanup! In addition to raising money for The Ocean Cleanup, we will also personally remove one grocery bag of trash from a local waterway for each $100 raised before we depart on our journey.

If you don't want to promote our journey, at the very least educate yourselves about the terrible conditions our oceans are currently in. The world needs our help. Read this article posted by The Geological Society of America about how this all affects humans, animals, and the earth.

Story to Date:

My name is Bruce Ryan. Over the past 17 years I've studied WHAT can be done about a global problem.  CO2 levels have reached 400ppm ~ well above the levels that 350.org points out as being the tipping point. Seven years ago a thesis was submitted to the Virgin Earth Challenge to address this critical issue. Today it is Time to Change the World and CAPTURE THE CARBON.

• Climate change is important to everyone on our planet.
  • There are two ways to solve the rising CO2 levels. Holistic land management and agriculture. Nothing else looks large enough to make an impact.
• I believe that we CAN do something about this.... starting today.
Industrial cannabis (""hemp"") absorbs CO2.

An ancient species from 32 million years ago, cannabis is a ""C3"" plant which captures carbon from the atmosphere. As CO2 levels rise, it gets bigger ~ up to 44% larger.  Cannabis sequesters up to 35% of its total mass in the soil. This puts the carbon back into the soil for decades. Our project is designed to do exactly this.

Using simple agriculture, capturing the carbon and creating products, we can pull CO2 directly from the air.  Reduces our ""carbon footprint"" each step of the way. Every one of the products produced keeps the carbon for the life of the product in a sustainable loop.  A hundred years or more.
• Sustainable, organic, natural and renewable ~ true net-zero carbon.
<li>Cannabis has fantastic potential. Some have estimated 25,000 products can be made from this one source. Food, clothing &amp

• Cannabis can grow an array of essential products that we use each and every day ~including biodegradable plastics and wood-like products. The waste can be turned into fuel. This can, and will, impact several large industries over the next ten years. Imagine what this means.

Now that the world is catching up to this vision, new machinery and techniques are being developed.  This leap-frog application of technology is creating a new green paradigm. Farmers around the world can grow a profitable crop with global impact. Our plan revolves around the critical processing equipment to provide materials for large industrial manufacturers. Act locally, think globally.

Each acre of cannabis produces 7+ tons of raw material that can be turned into home furnishings, buildings, fabrics, plastics, paper and much more.  Taken to a large enough scale we can create ""carbon credits"" for other business operations. This is 'Green Carbon Technology' at its finest.  Our environment is improved. CO2 is captured. Everyone benefits.

Recently I calculated what is needed to reverse CO2 levels. It's not impossible. Yes.  It is a very big goal. Over a twenty year period, atmospheric levels could drop to those of 1915 ~ at the beginning of the industrial revolution.  This is the long haul - one that will affect our children and grandchildren and great grandchildren.
  • This project is valuable to you and to our entire world.  Every species on our planet will benefit as this new industrial evolution takes hold.
• We've been advocates for the ""Tree of Life"" for decades.  The momentum is growing rapidly.  We are relentless.
• Now we are taking it to the internet.  Governments and corporations are not going to do this. We are.

• Your contribution helps make sure that this message gets out there.

    • Our Tactics

We have spent the past two year researching the world for game-changing new technology. Last week we received materials proving that inventors are up to the challenge. We've identified three current innovations to solve the core problem.

We are looking for ""social proof"" ~ a sign that you and other people see the same vision. Then we are approaching major investors to fund the multimillion dollar venture that involves large scale equipment, processing &
We have an extensive business plan to assemble the stellar team to make this happen.  (You can see the first part of this by sending us a private message.)
Spinoffs: Employment, work and more jobs.
Each stage of this project creates employment.  A quick list:
<ul>
• Jobs on the farms.
• Transport jobs.
• Processing work.
• Manufacturing positions.
• Data management.
• Machinery engineering.
<li>Research &amp
• Product design.
<li>Retail &amp

What we are accomplishing:
    Three factors impact our plan. Infrastructure, farmers and industrial consumers. Our mission is to impact each one of these areas.  Machinery and technology are job one.  Encouraging agricultural production is important  ~ profits at the farm gate. Industrial uses follow lock-step with materials production.
<h3>Risks &amp
column2:
Challenges

Largest challenge we face are the laws restricting the cannabis industry. Plenty of change is going on in this arena around the world. Our view is that increased productivity, increased tax revenues and job creation will prevail. We see the core processing problem within the ""hemp"" industry and we know what to do about it.

  • Interest from investors shows serious mainstream acceptance. A combination of talent, skills, financing and technology addresses the challenges.
  • Our plan for solving these challenges includes forming alliances and partnerships with people from many countries: Canada, Australia, Europe, India and the US. We are involved in bringing three innovations into the market.

column1: <li>We promote new equipment &amp
column2: manufacturing development that is taking place around the world. Challenge is to bring all of this together.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Folks, help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
• Go and buy something ""hemp"" today.

• Use the Indiegogo share tools!

    • And that's all there is to it.

The Citizens Coalition for a Safe Community, is a small but
mighty grassroots organization formed in 2008 as a non-profit 501c3 by a group of
community and environmental activists fighting the drilling expansion of the Inglewood oil field
in Los Angeles County, the largest urban oil field in the United States.
What We Want to Do:
We want to file a
lawsuit to protect California’s underground sources of drinking water that are
now being poisoned by the oil &amp
column2: gas industry, a blatant violation of the

column1: Safe Drinking Water Act of 1974.
Who We Want to Sue &
Why:
We want to file against
the California Office of Administrative Law, for allowing the Division of Oil,
Gas &amp
column2: Geothermal Resources (DOGGR), to misuse the adoption of an “Emergency

column1: Regulation” to allow the continued contamination of Protected California Aquifers
until 2017. The sole consideration here being the oil industry’s business plans
that might be negatively impacted if ordered to be in compliance with state and
federal law. DOGGR conceived this biased, twisted concept instead of
immediately ordering the shutting down of all 2500 illegal waste and produced
water injection wells that are potentially contaminating underground sources of
drinking water. These aquifers are meant to be protected by the Safe Drinking
Water Act, DOGGR’s mandate under Public Resources Code 3106 and as the “Primacy”
agency overseer of the states underground injection programs for the
Environmental Protection Agency.
Waste water and produced
water contain carcinogenic compounds, the most deadly being benzene.
The OAL’s acceptance of
DOGGR’s misinterpretation by simply flipping the law onto its head to consider corporate profit as
taking precedence over its first priority the protection of public health and sources of
drinking water is insane. Delay and incompetence, some might say collusion, by
DOGGR, California’s oil and gas industry regulator borders if not crosses over
into criminal behavior.
What We Need:
We need to raise
$35,000.00 ASAP in order to realistically see this litigation through the
California Superior Court in Sacramento. We would request injunctive relief to
require the shut down of the 2500 wells currently identified as operating illegally.
The Citizens Coalition
for a Safe Community’s, San Diego based attorney Todd T. Cardiff, is an
exceptional environmental attorney who represented us in our 2008 CEQA lawsuit

against the County of Los Angeles to great public benefit. We believe that a judge will clearly see the political manipulations and motivations of all agencies and parties involved. This is a legal battle Californian's can't afford to lose.
Perks:
A clear conscience in

knowing that you have taken an action that is correct in protecting the commons. Please make a tax-deductible contribution today. Thank you.

California State is currently
undergoing a major drought. Recently, the State imposed water restrictions,
which would not have been necessary if my water-conservation toilet invention
had been funded and put on the market back when I first brought my project to
the State of California.
All toilets in the world today use
the original suction method, first invented over 200 years ago. In 2006, my
company, New Age Hygienic Systems, began development on a new model of toilet
which preserves water resources and flushes quickly and hygienically. By taking
advantage of nanotechnology and working with the molecular property of water
for the transport of solids through pipelines and sewage systems, we created a
toilet requiring very little water per flush, yet flushes so thoroughly that
its bowl is sanitized after each use.
New Age Hygienic Systems, Inc. has a
complete, production-ready prototype set up, and has a manufacturer ready to
start upon receipt of funding.
The State of California and an
investment network granted us an Award
In 2011, the United States Patent
Office granted Dan Andreiu ""low flow apparatus and methods""  patent.
However, the project received general
disinterest from private investors, who perhaps were put off by the unglamorous
nature of the toilet industry. Even KIckstarter rejected my project...
My toilet will save 25% of the State's
clean water supply, yet they continue to ignore great ideas for conservation
while wasting taxpayer money on costly and pointless advertisement campaigns, pursuing the public to save water.
Inefficient programs cost the taxpayer a lot of money now, and will cost even
more in the near future.
Due to the nature of the product, we
cannot start small in a garage. We need a factory that can deal with porcelain on
an industrial scale, which will cost our company about one million dollars to
start. That may seem a bit much, but if one considers that California alone
will be saving about ten million dollars per day once our system is adopted by
everyone,  the start-up expense does not
look as large. We need about ten millions to swiftly and eficiently bring it to the public.
No one can stop an idea whose time
has come.  For our water saving
toilet, the time is now.

Technological Design and Proof of Concept prototypes 

Below link to Video Demonstrations of Proof of Concept prototypes flushing:
Demo Part 1. Test using 250 mg of medium (TOFU in this case), as required by federal standards.
More info, pictures, videos,  letters of support on our web site AutoToilet.com

column6: ><b>The Karakoram Anomaly Project combines science, sustainable

column1: development and creative media in the tallest mountain range on earth, the
Karakoram of Pakistan. The Karakoram Anomaly Project will investigate one of
the least understood natural hazards on the planet, and help to protect the
people whose lives are under threat.
column7: >The remote Karakoram mountains as seen from the International Space Station

column1: The Science
The Karakoram Anomaly Project will
investigate one of the least understood natural hazards on the planet, glacial

lake outburst floods.

Glacial lake outburst floods are caused when
an ice or moraine dam containing a glacial lake bursts catastrophically. The
resulting torrent of water, ice and rock rushes downstream, much like a
tsunami. The
Karakoram has suffered more than 30 of these devastating outbursts in the
last 20 years, and it is believed that 80,000 people in the region are
currently at risk.
‘During glacial lake
outburst floods, there is severe loss of lives and physical assets.’ UNDP
Pakistan

column7: >A rare photograph of a Glacial Lake Outburst Flood captured in Greenland

column1: The Impact
Glacial lake outburst floods are
not a new phenomenon. However, with current environmental change, their probability has risen in most mountain ranges. Glacial lakes are
particularly dangerous in the Karakoram as they occur at low elevations and
close to settlements. In some cases, potential outbursts allow only 10 to 40
minutes to trigger an alarm for the threatened population to evacuate to
safety.
It is a key time to understand
glacial lake outburst floods in the Karakoram, because of a phenomenon termed
the Karakoram anomaly. The Karakoram anomaly is one of the biggest mysteries of
glacial science. It describes the observation of growing glaciers in the
Karakoram, in contrast to shrinking glaciers in the rest of the world.
“The
Karakoram Anomaly describes the expansion of glaciers in central Karakoram in
contrast to declining glaciers around the world.” Dr Kenneth Hewitt, Wilfrid
Laurier University
There’s a link
between the Karakoram anomaly and glacial lake outburst floods: rapidly
advancing glaciers dam river valleys, causing the accumulation of glacial
melt-water, increasing the risk of glacial lake outburst floods.

column6: >Formation of lakes and glacier lake outburst

column1: floods. Example from Medvezhi glacier, Pamir.
The Karakoram Anomaly Project is
designed to investigate exactly how the Karakoram anomaly is changing the
probability of glacial lake outburst floods in the Shimshal, and Hunza valleys
of the Karakoram.
We’ll be trekking and climbing for 60 days across some of the
biggest glaciers on the planet, carrying much needed scientific equipment to
quantify the risk of catastrophic flooding. We’ll then communicate the results
of our work with the local people, to help develop sustainable solutions.
Our work will improve hazard mitigation and
adaptation strategies in the region, and increase the local population’s resilience to
glacial hazards and climate change, potentially saving thousands of lives.

column1: The Documentary
The Karakoram Anomaly Project is
about developing effective solutions to the glacial lake outburst flood
problem. An absolutely essential part of this is raising awareness about the
phenomenon.
We will document all
expedition stages, the scientific findings and activities carried out in the
field through the aid of photography and film. The result will be professional
photojournalism, time-lapse and repeat photography series and a video
documentary that can be used to communicate with people, both in Pakistan and
across the world. The Karakoram Anomaly Project will display photographs and
scientific results through several exhibitions and presentations including at the
Royal Geographical Society in London.

column1: taken me across the world, from the glaciers and volcanoes of Iceland to
Jamaica’s coral reefs, to the jagged peaks of the Himalayas. In the Himalayas,
I studied the role of glacial lake outburst floods in the 2010 ‘Cloudburst’

experience of environmental and sustainability issues in business.
conserving the natural world for the benefit of future generations.
I am a professional
photographer and adventurer, inspired by the beauty of extreme environments and
the wild places of our planet. My passion lies in exploring and photographing
the remote regions of the world and sharing these adventures with others. To
express my vision I create large format, fine art photographs, multi-media
installations and photographic essays. I also aim to contribute to the
understanding of our environment by collaborating with scientists by using photographic
techniques to support scientific research.I have received awards in
several international competitions including Travel and Landscape Photographer
of The Year. My interest in nature photography has taken me to remote lands
such as the Arctic Circle, Mesoamerican barrier reef, and Himalayas where I
climbed the 5<sup>th</sup> highest mountain in
the world, Makalu (8463m).
I am a technical-creative
problem solver, and a lover of the wild and remote places of this planet. I
work as a photographer, cinematographer and a product designer. I have directed
and shot international advertising campaigns, remote alpine and rafting
expeditions, short and feature length films, and all manner of work in between.
As an alpinist, I started making many journeys to the Southern Alps of New
Zealand, followed by the European Alps and the Scottish Highlands. I have
partnered with various bodies and companies including Australian Geographic,
Sea to Summit and all of Australia and New Zealand’s prominent alpine clubs for
these expeditions. I have a real passion for teaching, and have worked casually
as an outdoor education instructor.
What we need and what you get
Delivering the project requires a massive logistical, physical and financial effort.
We need your help to make the project happen.
We need £12,000 to purchase
research equipment, organise the community workshops, sustain the team and local porters and craft a video documentary and photographic essays to share
our story with the world.
We have designed unique perks to reward your kind
support. Check them out below!
Where are the funds going?
The raised funds will be used
towards the fulfilment of The Karakoram Anomaly Project's goals, including:
complex expedition, including payment of a team of 30 collaborators and
porters in Pakistan

column1: quality photographic essays, including time-lapse and repeat photography series.
The project involves exploring
remote regions of Central Karakoram and travelling to high altitudes. There are
physical risks associated with this project. However, our team has a wealth of experience in the activities The Karakoram Anomaly project will involve.
We have completed a full risk assessment and crisis management
plan, which has been reviewed by the University of Edinburgh Expeditions
Committee. The risk assessment includes an evaluation of physical, biological,
chemical, and man made hazards and also takes into consideration personal and
third party safety. We've also completed an environmental impact assessment, and endeavour to keep our environmental impact to a minimum.
All team members will have travel and medical insurance for the full length of The Karakoram Anomaly Project covering activities associated with trekking and mountaineering.
In case of an emergency we will use our satellite phone to call the Pakistani
Army for helicopter rescue. Our insurance covers such emergency procedures. All
members have first aid training.
In a nutshell our risk assessment will follow the acronym:
C - Clarify the hazards and risks
R - Reassess and revise it where
necessary
I - Involve all participants in
the process
S - State it simply in writing
I - If it’s too risky – don’t do
it!
S - Share knowledge and experience
For more information visit the
Karakoram Anomaly project official website.
Other ways you can help
If you’re not able to donate we
understand. However, we also hope that you share a passion for international
development, people and preserving our environment so please SHARE, SEND,
PROMOTE and SPREAD THE WORD about what we’re trying to accomplish. The planet
needs us – you can help it by helping the Karakoram Anomaly Project. Please
help our campaign by sharing this on social media. Thank you very much for your
support and we look forward to sharing with you our results and story from the
Karakoram Mountains!
","The Karakoram Anomaly Project combines science, sustainable
development and creative media in the tallest mountain range on earth, the
Karakoram of Pakistan. The Karakoram Anomaly Project will investigate one of
the least understood natural hazards on the planet, and help to protect the
people whose lives are under threat.  The remote Karakoram mountains as seen from the International Space Station
The Science
The Karakoram Anomaly Project will
investigate one of the least understood natural hazards on the planet, glacial
lake outburst floods.Glacial lake outburst floods are caused when
an ice or moraine dam containing a glacial lake bursts catastrophically. The
resulting torrent of water, ice and rock rushes downstream, much like a
tsunami. The
Karakoram has suffered more than 30 of these devastating outbursts in the
last 20 years, and it is believed that 80,000 people in the region are
currently at risk.
‘During glacial lake
outburst floods, there is severe loss of lives and physical assets.’ UNDP
Pakistan
A rare photograph of a Glacial Lake Outburst Flood captured in Greenland
The Impact
Glacial lake outburst floods are
not a new phenomenon. However, with current environmental change, their probability has risen in most mountain ranges. Glacial lakes are
particularly dangerous in the Karakoram as they occur at low elevations and
close to settlements. In some cases, potential outbursts allow only 10 to 40
minutes to trigger an alarm for the threatened population to evacuate to
safety.
It is a key time to understand
glacial lake outburst floods in the Karakoram, because of a phenomenon termed
the Karakoram anomaly. The Karakoram anomaly is one of the biggest mysteries of
glacial science. It describes the observation of growing glaciers in the
Karakoram, in contrast to shrinking glaciers in the rest of the world.
“The
Karakoram Anomaly describes the expansion of glaciers in central Karakoram in
contrast to declining glaciers around the world.” Dr Kenneth Hewitt, Wilfrid
Laurier University
There’s a link
between the Karakoram anomaly and glacial lake outburst floods: rapidly
advancing glaciers dam river valleys, causing the accumulation of glacial
melt-water, increasing the risk of glacial lake outburst floods.
Formation of lakes and glacier lake outburst
floods. Example from Medvezhi glacier, Pamir.
The Karakoram Anomaly Project is
designed to investigate exactly how the Karakoram anomaly is changing the
probability of glacial lake outburst floods in the Shimshal, and Hunza valleys
of the Karakoram.
We’ll be trekking and climbing for 60 days across some of the
biggest glaciers on the planet, carrying much needed scientific equipment to
quantify the risk of catastrophic flooding. We’ll then communicate the results
of our work with the local people, to help develop sustainable solutions.
Our work will improve hazard mitigation and
adaptation strategies in the region, and increase the local population’s resilience to
glacial hazards and climate change, potentially saving thousands of lives.
Kashmiri children playing with a shoe in Domkhar - a Himalayan Valley prone to glacial lake outburst floods. Copyrights: Chris Rubey.
Community Development
The ultimate goal of the Karakoram
Anomaly Project is to help inform and develop strategies to protect local
communities from glacial lake outburst floods. After all, the purpose of
understanding glacial lake outburst floods in the Karakoram is to protect the
people most at risk.
The Karakoram Anomaly Project will
carry out interactive workshops with the local communities to raise awareness
and advance understanding in respect of the following aspects:
·  The causes and
effects of regional climate change
·  The risk and
metrics of glacial lake outburst floods
·  And potential
mitigation and adaptation strategies.
We’re not alone here. We’ve teamed
up with the Karakoram Area Development Organisation and Pakistan
Meteorological Department to develop viable solutions to protect
communities in the Karakoram. We’re also following in the footsteps of
the United Nations Development Programme, which has expressed the need for
the better understanding of glacial lake outburst floods and the development of
solutions in the area.
In addition, we're backed by some of the most prestigious organisations in exploration and development...

They've got our back: The University of Edinburgh, The Captain Scott Society, The Royal Geographical Society, The Mount Everest Foundation, The American Alpin Club, Gilchrist Educational Trust, Laser Technology, The Lord Mayor's Trust
The Documentary
The Karakoram Anomaly Project is
about developing effective solutions to the glacial lake outburst flood
problem. An absolutely essential part of this is raising awareness about the
phenomenon.
We will document all
expedition stages, the scientific findings and activities carried out in the
field through the aid of photography and film. The result will be professional
photojournalism, time-lapse and repeat photography series and a video
documentary that can be used to communicate with people, both in Pakistan and
across the world. The Karakoram Anomaly Project will display photographs and
scientific results through several exhibitions and presentations including at the
Royal Geographical Society in London.
We'll use a professional drone to film our expedition

Short Summary

Hi!
First of all, thank you for 'clicking' this far.
We are a family from North Yorkshire who moved to the mountain region of Northern Tuscany in 2013 to begin a new adventure and try to build a simple yet sustainable life for ourselves.
We have learnt such a lot during the past two years and are ready to take our plans to the next level.

Every contribution to our campaign will include an open invitation to come and see us on the farm, see how your money is spent and enjoy a little ""English afternoon tea"" with us.  Just drop us an email with a little notice and we'll get the kettle on.

Our goal is to produce and supply traditional Italian cuisine to the UK market, primarily in the form of beautiful Christmas hampers at a competitive price, our difference will be that, wherever possible, all the products will be grown and produced here, on our smallholding.
We hope to:
Install 5 beehives, equipment &
Plant 48 blueberry bushes                                                       £     475.00
Plant 48 redcurrant bushes                                                     £     475.00
Plant 20 fruit trees                                                                      £     310.00
Plant 135 olive trees                                                                    £4,050.00
See our update for an example of what you can expect to receive in your hamper!
At present we produce much of our own food and over the past two years we have learnt how to make cheese, butter, salami, pancetta and proscuitto.

The ability to widen our experience and produce will take us, from being able to feed ourselves and 'barter' goods with our wonderful neighbours, to assembling a product range which will be cost effective enough to market in the UK.

The environment and animal welfare are topics so very close to our hearts and reasoning behind our adventure.  For many years, as a family, we have worried over what goes in our food, how far it's travelled, how it was treated etc, now we know!
We still worry about the bee population and hope to do our bit in preserving the little fellows who make such a difference to our ecosystem.
And finally, more trees in the world could never be a bad thing?

The leap into the unknown is always a challenge! We had no idea just how challenging moving lock, stock and barrel to another country would be!  The answer is straightforward and so far, our greatest lesson, the Italian's say ""piano, piano"" (step by step) followed by ""pranziamo"" (lets have lunch)!

We have a great support network of friends here who for some reason, are so kind and patient with us, they are never shy of giving advice and with such a wealth of experience, give us the confidence to move forward.
We also go to school twice a week where Gabriella patiently teaches us Yorkshire folk how to speak Italian, the Yorkshire accent actually helps! It seems our ""o"" sound is near perfect.

Spreading the Love . . . . . . 

For every single contribution we receive a charitable donation will be made and full details will be published on our facebook page.
We've had some 'lean' times ourselves and understand that not everyone will want or be able to contribute.
You can help us by spreading the word through social media, everyone who shares our campaign will also be welcome down on the farm if your travels ever bring you to this beautiful part of Italy.
