Depth Chart of the Charles River

The Charles River in Massachusetts is an urban river that is also one of the most active recreational rivers in the country.  Unfortunately, sediment deposition has been a long standing problem in the Charles River. It was recently highlighted in articles published by the Boston Globe in 2011 and WGBH in 2016.  In recent years, sediment deposits have caused several incidents that have resulted in damage to watercraft and personal injury.  While the sediment appears to be a larger problem where major tributaries - Laundry Brook, Hyde Brook, Faneuil Brook, Muddy River, Stony Brook - empty into the Charles, once the sediment is in the river, it can spread to other areas, causing further problems especially where it is already shallow.  This problem is not limited to the areas upstream of the BU Bridge.  A significant bar upriver of the Massachusetts Avenue Bridge is shallow enough and large enough to be a navigation hazard to both sailboats and motorboats.  There are also the extraordinary events such as the water main breaks in Weston in May 2010 and near the Anderson Bridge in August 2015, both of which caused large amounts of sediment to be moved.

It has been difficult to marshal the resources to remediate areas impacted by sedimentation since much of the knowledge about the shallows and bars has been anecdotal, coming from the daily experiences of the boaters on the river but not backed up by quantitative data. To address this issue, the Charles River Alliance of Boaters (CRAB) has developed a partnership with the MIT Sea Grant College Program to create a chart of the river depth between Science Park and the Watertown Dam, and to monitor changes in the river bottom in the future. Based upon some feasibility studies done in late 2015, more detailed and extensive measurements were undertaken in 2016. To date, most of the river between Newton Yacht Club and the New Charles River Dam has been surveyed for depth (see image below) and relative hardness of the river bottom. We plan to complete measuring these remaining sections once the plant growth there has died back with the colder weather that autumn brings.


 

The initial scope of the project is described below:
<li>

Depth Measurements:
Inexpensive fish-finders have been used to record the depth, time, and GPS position. While the depth is measured by the delay in the sonar echo, the relative hardness of the river bottom can be inferred from the strength of the sonar echo. The section of river between the BU Bridge and Community Rowing has been measured by driving sonar tracks at various distances from the shoreline. This has been done at the same time as we retrieve data from the depth data loggers (see below).
<li>

Influence of Daily Water Releases:
As part of flood control measures, water from the river is released into Boston Harbor at low tide and held in the river at high tide, slowly accumulating. This causes the water level in the river to change over several inches during the course of a day. A USGS
column2:
PARAmeter_cd=00065,00060"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">gauge at the First Street Bridge in Cambridge records the variation in the height of the watersheet. While this gauge is a good measure of the watersheet downstream of the BU Bridge, there are no gauges further upriver and the variation in the height of the watersheet is not well understood.
We have installed three gauges and data loggers at the Riverside Boat Club, Herter Park, and Community Rowing. These additional gauges have provided insight into how the height of the watersheet varies along the length of the river. Due to the lack of rainfall over the 2016 summer, the section of the river below the Watertown Dam has acted as a lake with the height of the watersheet varying almost uniformly along it entire length. If there had been more rainfall, it was expected that the height of the watersheet would have been different along the length of the river. We plan to keep the additional gauges installed for a few years and will continue to monitor how the height of the watersheet changes during periods of significant rainfall.
In order to more accurately determine the depth of the river, all raw depth measurements have been adjusted to account for the variation in the height of the watersheet.

column1: <li>

Development of Digital Charts:
In designing this project, we have focused on what we would be able to provide to users of the river:

• Chart Booklet: A printable PDF file that includes an overview of the river from Watertown to Boston Harbor, and more detailed charts of each section of the river. Separate booklets for water depth and river bottom hardness would be available.

• Large Format Overview: Similar to the map developed by the Charles River Conservancy showing the parkland surrounding the river, this would include an overview of the river showing the depth of the river bottom. This would be suitable to be posted on the wall in every boathouse.
• Google Map and Google Earth: On-line versions of the depth and relative hardness data using both Google Maps and Google Earth.
• ArcGIS: ArcGIS is a geographic information system (GIS) that provides an infrastructure for making layered maps openly available on the Web.

More information about the project can be found at our web site. 

We've been fortunate to have some early financial supporters that were critical to get the project started:  Boston Duck Tours, Head of the Charles Regatta, Newton Yacht Club, Union Boat Club, Riverside Boat Club, and Community Boating.  We have commitments for additional financial support from Cambridge Boat Club, Watertown Yacht Club, and Community Rowing.  But we are not yet fully funded and need your help to finish the first phase of this project.  We're asking individuals, boathouses, and other river organizations to consider making a contribution. 

","Depth Chart of the Charles RiverThe Charles River in Massachusetts is an urban river that is also one of the most active recreational rivers in the country.  Unfortunately, sediment deposition has been a long standing problem in the Charles River. It was recently highlighted in articles published by the Boston Globe in 2011 and WGBH in 2016.  In recent years, sediment deposits have caused several incidents that have resulted in damage to watercraft and personal injury.  While the sediment appears to be a larger problem where major tributaries - Laundry Brook, Hyde Brook, Faneuil Brook, Muddy River, Stony Brook - empty into the Charles, once the sediment is in the river, it can spread to other areas, causing further problems especially where it is already shallow.  This problem is not limited to the areas upstream of the BU Bridge.  A significant bar upriver of the Massachusetts Avenue Bridge is shallow enough and large enough to be a navigation hazard to both sailboats and motorboats.  There are also the extraordinary events such as the water main breaks in Weston in May 2010 and near the Anderson Bridge in August 2015, both of which caused large amounts of sediment to be moved.It has been difficult to marshal the resources to remediate areas impacted by sedimentation since much of the knowledge about the shallows and bars has been anecdotal, coming from the daily experiences of the boaters on the river but not backed up by quantitative data. To address this issue, the Charles River Alliance of Boaters (CRAB) has developed a partnership with the MIT Sea Grant College Program to create a chart of the river depth between Science Park and the Watertown Dam, and to monitor changes in the river bottom in the future. Based upon some feasibility studies done in late 2015, more detailed and extensive measurements were undertaken in 2016. To date, most of the river between Newton Yacht Club and the New Charles River Dam has been surveyed for depth (see image below) and relative hardness of the river bottom. We plan to complete measuring these remaining sections once the plant growth there has died back with the colder weather that autumn brings. The initial scope of the project is described below:

Depth Measurements:Inexpensive fish-finders have been used to record the depth, time, and GPS position. While the depth is measured by the delay in the sonar echo, the relative hardness of the river bottom can be inferred from the strength of the sonar echo. The section of river between the BU Bridge and Community Rowing has been measured by driving sonar tracks at various distances from the shoreline. This has been done at the same time as we retrieve data from the depth data loggers (see below).

Influence of Daily Water Releases:As part of flood control measures, water from the river is released into Boston Harbor at low tide and held in the river at high tide, slowly accumulating. This causes the water level in the river to change over several inches during the course of a day. A USGS gauge at the First Street Bridge in Cambridge records the variation in the height of the watersheet. While this gauge is a good measure of the watersheet downstream of the BU Bridge, there are no gauges further upriver and the variation in the height of the watersheet is not well understood.We have installed three gauges and data loggers at the Riverside Boat Club, Herter Park, and Community Rowing. These additional gauges have provided insight into how the height of the watersheet varies along the length of the river. Due to the lack of rainfall over the 2016 summer, the section of the river below the Watertown Dam has acted as a lake with the height of the watersheet varying almost uniformly along it entire length. If there had been more rainfall, it was expected that the height of the watersheet would have been different along the length of the river. We plan to keep the additional gauges installed for a few years and will continue to monitor how the height of the watersheet changes during periods of significant rainfall.In order to more accurately determine the depth of the river, all raw depth measurements have been adjusted to account for the variation in the height of the watersheet.
Development of Digital Charts:In designing this project, we have focused on what we would be able to provide to users of the river:

Chart Booklet: A printable PDF file that includes an overview of the river from Watertown to Boston Harbor, and more detailed charts of each section of the river. Separate booklets for water depth and river bottom hardness would be available.

Large Format Overview: Similar to the map developed by the Charles River Conservancy showing the parkland surrounding the river, this would include an overview of the river showing the depth of the river bottom. This would be suitable to be posted on the wall in every boathouse.
Google Map and Google Earth: On-line versions of the depth and relative hardness data using both Google Maps and Google Earth.
ArcGIS: ArcGIS is a geographic information system (GIS) that provides an infrastructure for making layered maps openly available on the Web.

More information about the project can be found at our web site. We've been fortunate to have some early financial supporters that were critical to get the project started:  Boston Duck Tours, Head of the Charles Regatta, Newton Yacht Club, Union Boat Club, Riverside Boat Club, and Community Boating.  We have commitments for additional financial support from Cambridge Boat Club, Watertown Yacht Club, and Community Rowing.  But we are not yet fully funded and need your help to finish the first phase of this project.  We're asking individuals, boathouses, and other river organizations to consider making a contribution.",1.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Boston, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/depth-chart-of-the-charles-river/pica

About Our Project
Save Cambodian Marine
Life is a non-profit
organization (NGO) based on Koh Rong Samloem, a small island off the coast of
Sihanoukville. Two of us started this project because we have a huge passion
for marine conservation and see a great need for it in this developing country.
I’m James. I’m a New Zealander who has lived here for almost 5 years. Pierre is
Cambodian born and is passionate about protecting his country’s natural resources
and educating fellow local people. Being Khmer and part of this cause is a
great asset as we hope other Cambodians will see this and want to take part to
protect their beautiful country. Our goals of this funding project are:
·
To create artificial Electro Reef systems that help regenerate
reefs damaged by destructive fishing methods and anchor damage.
·
To educate the local community about their reefs and how

important they are to a healthy ocean eco-system.

We had an article written about us in the Phnom Penh post which you can read here: http://www.phnompenhpost.com/post-weekend/electricity-broken-tanks-and-exploded-cars
column5: >It is vitally important that we help the local

column1: reefs around these islands, because without them, the fish population will
diminish even further and the local fishing families will have less food. A
recent study of 200 Khmer families living on these islands showed that 17% of
them were not getting enough seafood to feed their families.
The diving industry in Cambodia is also
growing which brings tourism to the local villages and its people. If there are
no healthy reefs or interesting artificial reefs for divers to look at, they
will stop coming, and everyone will lose out.
What We Need
Here’s where our funds will be spent:
·
Training local people and staff in how to build, maintain and
monitor Electro Reef structures - $3000
·
Cost to build the new artificial Electro Reef structure -$4000
·
Titanium anode - $5000
·
Other materials such epoxy resin, plastic tubing, wiring,
renewable energy source (solar power) and safety equipment - approximately
·
SCUBA diving manpower to help install the artificial reef with
diving equipment and boats - approximately $1000.
If we do not reach our final goal of $15,000
any funds raised will be used to create more natural artificial coral frames to
add to our already well-established coral nursery. From this coral nursery,
once the coral fragments are strong enough and healthy, we transplant them back
directly on to the natural reef where they once were.
The Impact
Cambodia has never seen coral farming or
Electro Artificial reefs before. We have installed one lotus flower already on
a different island, which is still in the very early stages. We did this
without the help of Biorock, but this time we would like to bring in the
experts to help train us and ensure that our methods are correct. By doing this
we will also gain the support of another amazing non-profit organization who we
will work with on future projects together.
Your kind donations will make a massive impact
first and foremost to our local communities, but also to the diving industry in
general in Cambodia.
Our natural coral farms have had tremendous
success and excellent growth rates. Our Electro Reef systems should be able to
increase coral growth rates by 3-5 times.
Risks &
The biggest risks that we face will be
accidental damage to our new artificial Electro Reef from boat anchors. We can
easily avoid this by marking out the area with bright marker buoys.
Another risk we face is utilizing solar panels
on the surface of the sea. We need to make sure that they are well anchored and
attached so they can’t be stolen or damaged by storms.
The structure will be placed quite close to
the local village where Save Cambodian Marine Life is based. That way we can
easily monitor it and visit it on a regular basis to ensure all the connections
are still intact.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to help us with a fiscal
donation we understand. But if you believe in our project and the good work
that we are doing, please share and spread the word of our cause. The Indiegogo
sharing tools make it easy for you to share. We appreciate any help that we can
get and word of mouth is one of the best ways to get heard!
Alternatively, become a
volunteer with Save Cambodian Marine Life and take part in our 1 to 4 week
programs where you learn to scuba dive. You can even stay longer if you wish
and become a long-term volunteer.<div>

Let
us together start a journey to save Antarctica, because fate of the world as we
know, is linked to the fate of Antarctica.
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column3: >Your support is the secret sauce. Let's get on board!

column1: · More
than 99 percent of Antarctic blue whales have been killed by commercial whalers
during the 20th century (From 250,000 Whales, the total has dwindled down to
fewer than 400).
· The
West Antarctica region is shedding a Mount Everest equivalent amount of ice
every two years
· Enough
Ice Has Melted in Antarctica to Alter the Earth’s Gravity
· If
the Antarctic ice sheets were to melt, sea level would rise 60 meters or 200
feet, affecting  600 million people living on land that will go below sea
level or regular flood levels by the end of the century
Most Important Fact: As per Antarctica Treaty, the world’s moratorium on mining
and drilling in Antarctica will expire in 2041, post which this agreement can
be altered, changed, modified, or even abandoned.

column3: I am joining Robert Swan on his

column1:
mission to
SAVE ANTARCTICA!
Robert Swan, the
first man in history to walk to both the North and South Poles, survived two
near-death experiences during his expeditions. He has ever since dedicated hi
life to the preservation of the Antarctic, the last great wilderness on our
planet. I am honored to be selected for an expedition with him in March'2015
along with 60 other chosen few from across the world.
Why is saving
Antarctica so important?
Our planet is a big
interconnected and interdependent family, well-knit through an intricate
intelligence. Antarctica is the heart of ocean, the great Antarctic circumpolar
currents connects the Indian, Atlantic and Pacific Ocean basins and thus
affects the distribution of heat around the world. It holds 90% of the
world's ice. If this ice melts, it could raise the sea level by 200 feet
changing the map that we know.
Post this
expedition, I will develop an interactive game  to help spread awareness
about this cause. The game will make it much easier to understand the
interconnection and interdependence of species, climate and continents. It will
help visualize how breaking a single link in nature's intricate network can
have a cascading effect.

column2: >Of course, all of this CAN NOT happen without YOU.

column1: Would you come with me?
I invite you to
support me in raising awareness about this cause and help make this world a
better place. Please help us raise $20,000 through this forum. Every contribution counts!
Of course monetary
donations are not the only way to help. Any advice, encouragements, or comments
would be awesome!
You can help us in multiple ways!
We appreciate your
support and encourage you to please help us in more ways than one.
· Share
this page with your colleagues, family, friends and people you know are
passionate about sustainability, climate change and saving Antarctica
· Share
the link on your social media pages to help us spread the word
· Use
the Indiegogo share tools.
· Become
active in your local community and make the change to live as sustain-ably as
possible.
· Think
about investing in renewable energy for your house?
Hi, I'm Nitish,
an engineer by education, data scientist by profession and a
conservationist at heart. Born in an agrarian family, I spent most of my
childhood in lap of nature, imbibing philosophies like respect for all species
(“Vasudeva Sarvam”), World is an interconnected family (“Vasudhaiva
Kutumbakam”) and welfare for all (“Sarva Bhuta Hita”).
I believe that nowadays, we are stuck in the web of our personal
problems and we ignore important issues that can impact us all. There are
times, when we need to stop and think about what surrounds us to be aware of
what and who we are, and that experience, will probably change our vision of
the world.
The company 2041 was
founded by polar explorer, environmental leader and public speaker
Robert Swan, OBE. As the first person in history to walk to both the North
and South Poles, Swan has dedicated his life to the preservation of
Antarctica by the promotion of recycling, renewable energy and
sustainability to combat the effects of climate change.
2041’s mission is to
build on Swan’s dedication by informing, engaging and inspiring the
next generation of leaders to take responsibility, to be sustainable, and
to know that now is the time for action in policy development, sustainable
business generation and future technologies.
Vision of this expedition is to have committed leaders, emerging
from every corner of society, and working together to create a sustainable
world: Enlightened, Empowered, Engaged.
Reference links
Robert’s Ted talk -http://www.ted.com/talks/robert_swan_let_s_save_the_last_pristine_continent
Leadership on the edge:-  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCUeX7XdzW0
From words to action - Lessons from Antarctica:-  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w76GGM7SVC0
Website link : http://www.2041.com/overview.php
Join us on Facebook, Twitter !

Project Pig Castle
As we traveled through the country of
Thailand, we met many farmers. In all farms we have seen the same
problems. Pollution, growing consumption of natural resources and no recycling.
There were no species-appropriate husbandry, as well as no medical assistance.
We asked ourselves: how could this happen?
The answer: It was never taught to them to
do it in a different way.
But what can we do?
Teach in practice.

What do we want?

We want to build a farm with
species-appropriate husbandry, water treatment, and
ecological cultivation of fodder.
We want to show that environmental and
animal protection have sustainable benefits.

The sty

The sty is easy to build, animal-friendly,
and easy to clean.
We only use materials and finished parts
that are both easy to find, and are inexpensive to get in the country itself.
The design is efficient and easy to reproduce. You may also adjust all of the
pens to best fit the size of the animals.
The pens for the dams are designed so that
the piglets are always safe. The pens are also linked to group rooms so
that the social behavior of piglets and dams does not suffer.
The floor of the sty is provided with a slight
slope and water grooves, so that the water and dirt can run off easily. This
makes cleaning far easier, and increases the overall hygiene of the animals
living space. The surfaces are covered with non-slip rubber mats as well.
Water treatment
This is also easy to build with materials
available to everyone. Through an underground pipe system, the contaminated
water and the mud go into a 3 chamber purification plant.
First, the water must pass through a sieve
where it is already exempt from the manure. This manure will be recycled as
fertilizer. The dirt in the first basin sinks to the bottom, and the water
flows into the second tank. The water gets released from nitrogen and also
passes through a spillway into the 3rd pool. From there, the purified water
goes through pumps and an underground pipe system onto the fields for
irrigation.

Agriculture

This is used to feed the animals. There is
recycled water supplied by a pipe system. Fertilized exclusively with the dried
dung of the animals.
This farm, this school, is the place to
initiate a rethink, in order to show people there is a solution. The
animals grow just as fast as before, and are much healthier. The treated
water will not cause additional costs and is environmentally friendly, as well
as the manure which is used to be recycled. Organic farming is not only a
good thing for animals, but also for the farmers. We would like to
conclude this section with a quote:
""give a man a fish and you feed him for a day
column2: teach a man to fish and you feed him for a lifetime""

ROLLING HIGH TUNNEL GREENHOUSE​ - HELP US TO ESTABLISH A COLD-CLIMATE LEARNING SITE &
Permaculture Institute (PPI) are a diverse group of professionals, amateurs,
and volunteers working to bring a wealth of edible plant species, growing and propagating
techniques, and season extension methods to gardeners, nurseries, our
supporters, and our communities.  We do
this by providing experiences, education, and demonstration sites to support
<span>SUSTAINABLE FOOD PRODUCTION. This
is our passion and maybe it’s yours too--or can be!
Our immediate
goal is to purchase a <u>Rolling High Tunnel Greenhouse</u>, which will enable
us to operate on a larger scale and supply many varieties of plants to fulfill
the growing needs of our programs, classes and demonstration sites. We will use
it to research, test, develop, and demonstrate methods to perpetuate growing
systems that mimic nature. These methods will produce food in foodscapes that
are abundant in cold climates and less labor-intensive…and will still produce abundance with climate
changes.
Because
of the work necessary to level and prepare the site, complete the greenhouse, prepare
beds, and get the project rolling, we are eager to begin soon. We hope to have
it in operation by August 22 of this year.

column1: Most of us at
least know the major challenges: air, soil and water pollution
food
column2: over-expending of energy transporting food over long distances, and climate

column1: changes. But it takes time to create food sources on our own properties, and not
everyone knows where to begin. And in our windy, cold-climate region we have a
short growing season—only 2-1/2 to 3 months.
To be successful, we must have a transformational shift in how we produce food. The intelligent
design and management of growing systems to support nature’s work is essential.
Creating sustainable ecosystems will help us, and the most successful change
comes from the bottom up. At PPI we are working to create a template for
natural food resilience in cold-climate regions. Using plant guilds, polycultures,
food forests and other permaculture methods, we are continuously amazed at what
you can really grow – increasing our
local food supply with a great abundance of food to be shared. <span>Planting in polycultures and food forests for many levels
of diversity allows us to create sustainable foodscapes for seven generations
into the future.
How we will use the Rolling High
Tunnel Greenhouse
The
Rolling High Tunnel (RHT) Greenhouse will help us solve the challenges of our growing
season. With
its capability and capacity, we can accelerate and expand our research. What we
learn will help others in our communities and anywhere else in the world with

similar climate and conditions. We are all in this together!

A Rolling High Tunnel Greenhouse.
This
greenhouse is an important educational tool for PPI to share knowledge with
farmers, gardeners and students. It will allow us to grow a variety of
plantsmore effectively and efficiently by extending the growing season
on both ends. We plan to create a propagation environment for annuals and hardy
perennials to use in our classes and our <i><u>Paradise
Transition Gardens, and then share our results with the community and
local nurseries.
Because
local nurseries do not supply them, we lack access to good selections of
perennial edible species, native plants, and plants compatible with our climate.
Many of the plants we would like to teach about, grow and use in local gardens
are expensive, and we realize that often people don’t have the funds to
purchase these for their yards. Some have to be specially ordered, because they
aren’t being propagated locally. That’s why we decided to grow and propagate
them at PPI. Mimicking nature’s diversity, bringing back some native species,
and planting for our climate will allow us to create foodscapes capable of
producing abundance for many generations to come.
specific educational objective is to demonstrate a sustainable, closed-loop food production
cycle: grow / harvest food / harvest seeds / plant seeds / grow again. We will also
offer classes on how to prepare the plants for use in nutritious meals, shakes,
and natural remedies.<span> And, since children enjoy the
hands-on experience of smelling and touching the plants, we will provide
various community educational opportunities for them to be involved in

planting and harvesting.

A RHT is a unique mobile greenhouse that can move on a track into 3 or more positions.

The RHT features a high dome for maximum
space and circulation. Its movement allows working, freshening, and
double-digging the soil with ease to enhance fertility
insect infestation
column2: and accommodates plants with different needs for protection

column1: from start to establishment or harvest. Let’s use vegetable crops as an
example. Start an early crop of lettuce in Position 1. Then, as spring weather
warms, raise the ends. Next, move into Position 2 for tomato transplants. In Position
3, fully expose hot-weather sun-loving herbs and vegetables while cucumbers and
melons are protected inside. At the end of the season, move back to Position 2
to protect the tomatoes. Finally, back to Position 1 to plant a late spinach crop
after the lettuce is harvested… and after the spinach, we begin again with
early lettuce!
What will we
propagate and grow…and why?
Our
propagation will be expanded with perennials specifically selected to be
successful for our bio-region: natives, medicinal herbs, vegetables, less
commonly known varieties high in nutritional value, edible trees, small trees,
shrubs, ground cover and vines.
We
are focusing
on plants that work together in polycultures to support each other’s growth—clover,
hairy vetch, and lupine to fix nitrogen in the soil,
and dynamic accumulators such as comfrey, borage and yarrow. Planting
polycultures creates optimal conditions for plant diversity, adding what they
need, while monocultures (planting large areas with one crop) can take away.
Through considering each plant’s needs and the grouping it is placed in, we can
grow happy companions that support each other for higher yields, encourage
beneficial insects, and set the stage for nature to do the bulk of the work.
Then we have happy plants and happy people, right?
Who are
we? Fruit on the vine, ready to share
I’m Mona Lewis, a permaculture designer
and teacher. In 2013 I founded Paradise
Permaculture Institute with my husband, David, in Livingston, Montana’s
Paradise Valley. We purchased 5.7 acres with a vision to create a permaculture
demonstration site and formed a non-profit board. PPI is now approved as an
educational non-profit 501(c)(3).
We now have seven board members: me, Beverly
Axelsen, Michelle Evans, Adele Field, Kari King, Becky Owens, and Zachary Weiss
– if you’re a Montanan, perhaps you know one or more of us. Our skill sets
include teaching, bio-intensive farming, permaculture consulting, managing sustainability,

and business consulting. We have an herbalist and a master gardener, too!

PPI's Board Members.

To
date we have held 33 classes with 12 different instructors from three counties.
We just finished our second annual “Seed Exchange Extravaganza” event, created
moveable planter boxes to bring herbs and edibles to the sidewalks of
Livingston, and held the first annual series of plant walks to identify and
learn about native medicinal plants first-hand. In the summer of 2015 we
adopted a new program, <i>Paradise
Transition Gardens, to help homeowners transition from lawns to food
forests.
We see ourselves as community catalysts—sharing ideas,
knowledge and resources, making connections, and creating meaningful
opportunities for participation. Together with friends, students, gardeners,
permaculture enthusiasts and all of you, we can share the joyous experience of
supporting the growth of community food resilience by:
Working with nature to
create edible landscapes
Spreading the word about co-creating sustainable foodscapes
in cold climates
Building soil and growing an abundance of pesticide and
chemical-free produce
Using fewer non-renewable resources
Respecting the Earth’s natural cycles and all life
How would you like to step right outside your door to choose from a
wealth of nutritious food growing in a resilient, sustainable landscape?
Growing food using gardening principles patterned after nature’s strengths is
less work for you and results in a higher yield of nutrient-dense food. This
can be done on any scale, from back yard to small or large farm.
Where will
your contributions go?
Price of the Rolling High Tunnel with the non-profit
discount* of 15% is   $12,085*

(1. Freight $1,500)

(2. Ground Leveling Prep $500)
(3. Contractor and team for 1 week $5,000)

(4. Plants $915) 

The total for our fundraising campaign is thus $20,000 in order to support these components.

Hoped-for budget allocations for what we raise here. 

What if we exceed our goal?

We will gratefully put the funds to good use! With
$20,000, we can purchase and install the Rolling High Tunnel Greenhouse and buy
a selection of plants to get started. With anything over that, we can cover any
contingencies that may arise with the installation, expand our plant varieties,
augment our gravity-fed irrigation system, and even create an educational video
or eBook that we can share with you.
Our Gift to YOU!
We are offering perks as
gifts in appreciation to our supporters. The generous organizations, artists,
authors, and community members who have graciously provided goods and services
for use as perks have also shown their interest in supporting our desire to
make a difference in the world. And the giant cinnamon rolls…. well they are
just for fun! Our campaign is about reaching out into the community, the world,
and connecting for a common cause.
Join
We
hope that our vision of a model for sustainable agriculture and living will
inspire you to get involved. Please join us as we co-create this exciting,
timely model of sustainable, abundant food production in a cold, Montana
climate.
Together,
we are making a better world not only for ourselves but for our children and future

generations. We look forward to working with you!

How you can help

>
column3:
Donate. Please consider giving your monetary contribution through our nonprofit website.

>
column5:
Share this campaign by forwarding it to your colleagues, friends, and family and applicable communities using Indiegogo's social media ""Share"" tools. Good ole fashioned notes, personal emails and word-of-mouth are much appreciated too!

>
column7:
Contact Us if you know of an organization, group or individuals that might be interested in supporting us and provide and introduction or let us know how to reach them.

>
column9:
Learn about and actively help create Paradise Transition Gardens by volunteering as space becomes available, to help others transform yards to gardens using permaculture principles.

>
column13:
Sign Up for our email list and quarterly newsletter.


To learn more about RHT's see: 

http://www.paradisepermaculture.org/rolling-hig... 

This is also a great brief from the NH NRCS: http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/FSE_DOCUMENTS/nrcs144p2_015534.pdf

column13: >Great news, the Deadline to Buy Back Our Company has been extended.
column17: >We are planning to launch Rethink Waste 2.0 on Indiegogo to continue our crowdfunding effort.
column21: >We are taking a bit more time to regroup and will be back online soon.
column25:
>In gratitude, Algae Systems 


Bucky Fuller told us 40 years ago that planet earth  has no externalities. There is no ""away."" Whatever we create, consume, and waste remains with us.  We have a choice about whether our ""waste"" has either detrimental or beneficial effects. To solve some of the world's most challenging environmental problems, we need solutions that see waste as a resource. We believe this change in perspective coupled with a systems approach to water, energy, and waste can have enormous beneficial impacts for people and the planet.
column29:
>Our team spent nearly every waking moment of the last 6 years of our lives, approximately 394,200 hours, dedicated to developing our waste treatment technology.  We've had numerous successes and exceeded our expectations.  

We figured out how to transform raw sewage into energy-positive clean water and carbon-negative, water-positive green fuels. In the process of growing biomass and turning it into fuel, we discovered something much more valuable. We can purify wastewater without wasting energy.

We are excited about the viability of our technology and the benefits it can bring to a world where millions of children are killed every year by dirty water. 

However, our primary investor, a large Japanese corporation who initially funded our small startup, isn’t interested in wastewater.  They are no longer willing to provide funding to us as our interests no longer align.

The truth is, we are in a tight spot.

column1: We have until Jan 31st (we received an extension from the previous Jan 17th date) to raise enough money to buy back our company and continue operating.  If we do not raise enough capital, our technology and IP will be shelved indefinitely, its benefits never brought to light.
<div>To our knowledge, there is no other process that can provide the benefits we can and do so at a profit.
<div>
<div style=""text-align: left

column5: >We are in a position to invite people like you to help us continue developing our waste treatment system and deploy it at a commercial scale to bring its benefits to communities.

column1: Let's harness the power of the crowd to support existing technology and is so critically needed on this planet. We hope that you are inspired by our work and that you see the benefits it can provide.
WE KNOW IT WORKS!

column2: >In Alabama's Mobile Bay we successfully built and tested a demonstration facility that takes a community’s raw sewage into one end, and outputs carbon-negative fuel, clean water, and fertilizers from the other end.  Unlike most water treatment strategies our system generates energy while producing clean water. A community using this method could get energy back while treating their water.

column1: <div style=""text-align: left

column11: >

column5: >Learn more about the science behind the system

column1:
When Alabama Governor Robert Bentley visited our facility, he had this to say:

""This took a lot of knowledge in biochemistry and the ability to take wastewater and use natural ingredients like algae and be able to produce clean water and oil...it's a great system."" ~ Robert Bentley
AlgaeSystems CEO Matt Atwood (left) speaks with Governor Robert Bentley (right) on a tour of our Mobile Bay facility.

It is our hope that you will decide to support our campaign and empower us to continue on this path.  Every little bit helps. Please donate and share. Together we can change the world. One city water treatment plant at a time.
HOW YOU CAN HELP
column5: >With your contribution, we will be able to:

<li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Obtain full control of our science and patents by buying back our company from our current investor

column1: <li>

column5: >Jumpstart our Mobile Bay facility to get it running again

column1: <li>

column5: >Develop existing relationships for already selected sites to deploy HTL skids + photobioreactor bag technology

column1: <li>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Scale up to an economy of scale that makes our waste treatment system competitive in the marketplace

column1: STILL NOT CONVINCED?

column5: >Our planet is in need of help, and our cities are the places for transformation.  Did you know that some municipalities in the United States use up to 30-40% of total energy for water systems ( EPA)?  The clear message here is,
column9: >we need more energy-friendly water production

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >On the flip side, we use about 40% of all water for fossil fuel energy production (DOE).  Negative implications of this practice include competition for water supplies among agricultural uses and human consumption. Additionally, warmed water coming out of thermoelectric plants has adverse impacts on local aquatic habitats.

column1: <div><b style=""background-color: initial
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >The water-energy nexus is ripe for innovation to decrease greenhouse gas emissions and change the planet's future trajectory to a more stable climate.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Algae Systems is a valid solution for a more resourceful water-energy nexus. You have the power to help us create a more sustainable world for future generations.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div>
<span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Algae Systems disrupts traditional wastewater treatment with a more resourceful, systems approach. Our technology pushes wastewater treatment and energy production into new territory that is far more beneficial for humans and other living systems than current practice.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >Technologies like ours that generate new solutions to climate change, ocean warming, topsoil depletion, and greenhouse gas pollution are needed immediately. The world needs more resilient and resource-efficient infrastructure, and that's what we provide.

column1: <div><span style=""background-color: initial
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column5: >Solar and wind have grown leaps and bounds, but they aren't going to get us all the way there, experts say.  Bill Gates recently announced the creation of a private equity fund to invest money in 20-30 companies with existing technology that can be scaled up to become commercially viable.  Algae Systems is the type of tech Bill Gates is talking about.  It is viable technology that needs financial support to scale up. As the deadline of Jan 31st looms ahead, we are working as hard as we can to capture the attention of the crowd to meet our crowdfunding deadline.

column1: <div>

IN THE NEWS
People are excited about the potential of Algae Systems.
Visit our press room here.
To hear John Perry Barlow's thoughts on the issues our technology addresses, watch this video:

MEET OUR TEAM
We are a group of professionals united in our efforts to apply an entirely new approach to solving some of the most basic problems impacting our communities, our environment and our public utilities. We are entrepreneurs, chemists, engineers (civil, marine, and aeronautic), utility operations managers, vanguards of more sensible futures. Click here to learn more about our team.
<div>
<div>
<div>

","Great news, the Deadline to Buy Back Our Company has been extended.We are planning to launch Rethink Waste 2.0 on Indiegogo to continue our crowdfunding effort.  We are taking a bit more time to regroup and will be back online soon.In gratitude, Algae Systems Bucky Fuller told us 40 years ago that planet earth  has no externalities. There is no ""away."" Whatever we create, consume, and waste remains with us.  We have a choice about whether our ""waste"" has either detrimental or beneficial effects. To solve some of the world's most challenging environmental problems, we need solutions that see waste as a resource. We believe this change in perspective coupled with a systems approach to water, energy, and waste can have enormous beneficial impacts for people and the planet.   Our team spent nearly every waking moment of the last 6 years of our lives, approximately 394,200 hours, dedicated to developing our waste treatment technology.  We've had numerous successes and exceeded our expectations.  We figured out how to transform raw sewage into energy-positive clean water and carbon-negative, water-positive green fuels. In the process of growing biomass and turning it into fuel, we discovered something much more valuable. We can purify wastewater without wasting energy.We are excited about the viability of our technology and the benefits it can bring to a world where millions of children are killed every year by dirty water. However, our primary investor, a large Japanese corporation who initially funded our small startup, isn’t interested in wastewater.  They are no longer willing to provide funding to us as our interests no longer align.The truth is, we are in a tight spot.

We have until Jan 31st (we received an extension from the previous Jan 17th date) to raise enough money to buy back our company and continue operating.  If we do not raise enough capital, our technology and IP will be shelved indefinitely, its benefits never brought to light.
To our knowledge, there is no other process that can provide the benefits we can and do so at a profit.
We are in a position to invite people like you to help us continue developing our waste treatment system and deploy it at a commercial scale to bring its benefits to communities.
Let's harness the power of the crowd to support existing technology and is so critically needed on this planet. We hope that you are inspired by our work and that you see the benefits it can provide.
WE KNOW IT WORKS!

In Alabama's Mobile Bay we successfully built and tested a demonstration facility that takes a community’s raw sewage into one end, and outputs carbon-negative fuel, clean water, and fertilizers from the other end.  Unlike most water treatment strategies our system generates energy while producing clean water. A community using this method could get energy back while treating their water.
Learn more about the science behind the system here.

When Alabama Governor Robert Bentley visited our facility, he had this to say: ""This took a lot of knowledge in biochemistry and the ability to take wastewater and use natural ingredients like algae and be able to produce clean water and oil...it's a great system."" ~ Robert Bentley
AlgaeSystems CEO Matt Atwood (left) speaks with Governor Robert Bentley (right) on a tour of our Mobile Bay facility.

It is our hope that you will decide to support our campaign and empower us to continue on this path.  Every little bit helps. Please donate and share. Together we can change the world. One city water treatment plant at a time.
HOW YOU CAN HELPWith your contribution, we will be able to:
Obtain full control of our science and patents by buying back our company from our current investor
Jumpstart our Mobile Bay facility to get it running again
Reinstate our dedicated employees who want to contribute to the success of our waste treatment system
Develop existing relationships for already selected sites to deploy HTL skids + photobioreactor bag technology
Scale up to an economy of scale that makes our waste treatment system competitive in the marketplace
STILL NOT CONVINCED?

Our planet is in need of help, and our cities are the places for transformation.  Did you know that some municipalities in the United States use up to 30-40% of total energy for water systems ( EPA)?  The clear message here is, we need more energy-friendly water production.

On the flip side, we use about 40% of all water for fossil fuel energy production (DOE).  Negative implications of this practice include competition for water supplies among agricultural uses and human consumption. Additionally, warmed water coming out of thermoelectric plants has adverse impacts on local aquatic habitats. We need more water-friendly energy production.
The water-energy nexus is ripe for innovation to decrease greenhouse gas emissions and change the planet's future trajectory to a more stable climate.
Algae Systems is a valid solution for a more resourceful water-energy nexus. You have the power to help us create a more sustainable world for future generations.

Algae Systems disrupts traditional wastewater treatment with a more resourceful, systems approach. Our technology pushes wastewater treatment and energy production into new territory that is far more beneficial for humans and other living systems than current practice.

Technologies like ours that generate new solutions to climate change, ocean warming, topsoil depletion, and greenhouse gas pollution are needed immediately. The world needs more resilient and resource-efficient infrastructure, and that's what we provide.

Solar and wind have grown leaps and bounds, but they aren't going to get us all the way there, experts say.  Bill Gates recently announced the creation of a private equity fund to invest money in 20-30 companies with existing technology that can be scaled up to become commercially viable.  Algae Systems is the type of tech Bill Gates is talking about.  It is viable technology that needs financial support to scale up. As the deadline of Jan 31st looms ahead, we are working as hard as we can to capture the attention of the crowd to meet our crowdfunding deadline.
IN THE NEWSPeople are excited about the potential of Algae Systems.Visit our press room here.
To hear John Perry Barlow's thoughts on the issues our technology addresses, watch this video:

MEET OUR TEAMWe are a group of professionals united in our efforts to apply an entirely new approach to solving some of the most basic problems impacting our communities, our environment and our public utilities. We are entrepreneurs, chemists, engineers (civil, marine, and aeronautic), utility operations managers, vanguards of more sensible futures. Click here to learn more about our team.",6.0,1,"1 Campaign
|","San Francisco, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/rethink-waste-be-a-part-of-our-green-tech/pica

It is easier to save a kilowatt than
to make a kilowatt.
The easiest solutions are the best
solutions.
My invention
column2: Feather board, is a green innovative new

column1: product that replaces feathers for sawdust in particleboard, which creates a
strong, highly-insulative material. Feathers are an agriculture waste product
that can inexpensively be transformed into construction paneling for building
and insulating houses. Feather board has many benefits: high-thermal resistance,
less flammable than wood, termite resistant, green-recycled product, non-toxic,
abundant and renewable, saves trees, it’s a local resource, reduces energy
consumption, and has the potential to save up to 48% on your energy bills.
Feathers board was created using a vacuum press and a 20-ton mechanical
press to compact the feathers and adhesives into a usable building
material.<span>  Preliminary testing results show
that feather board can handle over 580 psi before signs of stress, and the
material had a thermal resistance R-value around 6.5
The tests
proved that feather board’s strength is sufficient to replace particleboard for
construction of houses, and is equivalent or better than Polyurethane extruded Foam
for insulating a house. Feather Board is
strong enough to replace wood and insulates as well as the best competitor on
the market.
Feathers are an Abundant
Resource.<span>  The poultry industry annually creates
over six billion pounds of feathers in the United States.  If a football field was filled with six
billion pounds of chicken feathers it would be pilled high to 34,700 ft.  The industry turns this waste into 1.6
billion pounds of feather meal which is then feed to cattle.
Feathers are
green materials because they are salvaged from a waste product, as well as, an
abundant renewable resource. It also takes low levels of energy to make
products out of feathers, and they are readily available almost everywhere as a
local resource. Products made feathers also have a relative low impact on the
environment and Materials from feathers are an ecofriendly, profitable

solution to agricultural waste problem.

Today I am asking for $1,000 so I can buy a basic pump so I
create a vacuum press to start production of feather board and feather
insulation.<span>  If a quarter million dollars
was raised, a factory would be built for full-production of feather board.  This would help save the environment, reduce
our energy consumption, improve the lives of cattle, and reduce our need for
trees as a building material.
Please help me in bringing my invention to the marketplace so
we both can help each other and the environment.

Personal:
Two of the founders of EQ
have breathing disorders. One passed away in 2013.
I also have four family
members with serious allergies and/or breathing problems.<span>  Three sleep with machines each night.  EQ’s desire to clean the air we breath is
more than a business it’s a personal mission to help our family as well as the
world around us.
The fact that we have an
opportunity to do this on such a large scale in Mexico is truly amazing and the
impact we could have on a world wide scale after proving our product in Mexico
is mind blowing.
Consider the possibility of
going to Los Angeles or Mexico City and being able to look out your hotel room
window and NOT see a black haze over the city, walk down the street and take a
deep breath and not get a burning feeling from the air.
Short
Summary
EnergyQuest
International is a family owned and operated business.  We have developed
a unique fuel additive that reduces the amount of smoke and emissions caused by
combustion engines.<span>  We believe it can improve
the quality of life for millions of people by reducing the toxins in the
air.  These toxins are especially harmful
for people with breathing problems.  We
know this first hand.  You see, our quest
to solve this problem was started because we have family members and associates
with serious breathing problems.  Each day they must determine if the air
quality is safe enough to allow them to go outside.  So we set out to
create a product that would not only aid our family but reduce emissions each
day, one vehicle at a time, in order to help all those with breathing
problems.  AND WE HAVE CREATED THAT PRODUCT!
We
now have a new opportunity to help clean the air in Mexico one power plant at a time!
The Mexican government is actively looking for environmentally friendly
products to improve air quality all across Mexico:
Mexico News: Government to Invest $32B to Slash
Greenhouse Gases Emissions
<ul>
<li>
Ma. Elena | staff@latinopost.com
• Dec 09, 2015 06:00 AM EST
http://www.latinone.com/articles/28730/20151209/mexico-news-government-invest-32b-slash-greenhouse-gases-emissions.htm
We
have been invited to demonstrate our products by the head of the Mexican Federal
Electricity Commission, (CFE ).<span>  Mexico uses
diesel fuel to operate over 600 power plants throughout the country.  The
Mexican government runs the CFE and has committed billions of dollars to reduce air pollution overall and
specifically reduce smoke and emissions caused by the power plants through out
Mexico.  They are extremely interested in purchasing our products and
would like a demonstration of our products with the expectation that we can
significantly improve air quality resulting in a better quality of life for the
people of Mexico.
We
believe our Unique EQ Product would reduce smoke and emissions coming from each
power plant by a minimum of 30%.<span>  This will
provide a huge impact on the air quality for the Mexican people.
Globally,
4.3 million deaths were attributable to household air pollution (HAP) in 2012,
almost all in low and middle income (LMI) countries according to: Public
Health, Social and Environmental Determinants of Health Department, World
Health Organization.
March 2014 | Geneva - In new estimates released today, WHO
reports that in 2012 around 7 million people died - one in eight of total
global deaths – as a result of air pollution exposure. This finding more than
doubles previous estimates and confirms that air pollution is now the world’s
largest single environmental health risk. Reducing air pollution could save
millions of lives.
“The
risks from air pollution are now far greater than previously thought or
understood, particularly for heart disease and strokes,” says Dr Maria Neira,
Director of WHO’s Department for Public Health, Environmental and Social Determinants
of Health. “Few risks have a greater impact on global health today than air
pollution
column2: the evidence signals the need for concerted action to clean up the

column1: air we all breathe.”
These short videos from reputable sources
around the world explain that we truly have a world wide problem coming from
Power Plants.  Please take a look at just a few of the 1000's of videos that
can be found on the internet :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6ph2JzM0dsU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6BivxQpUsLA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Soclrye-woE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nNwvBbiY2o4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SF7z2UM_mMc
What
We Need &amp
EQ
is seeking $250,000 to do a complete demonstration showing how effective our product works.<span>  The demonstration will take place in
one or more power plants in Mexico.  This demonstration will allow us to
prove to the CFE that by using our products, they will not only save money
on fuel costs, but also save lives by lowering the amount of smoke and harmful
emissions that power plants put out each day.
The
money raises will be used for travel to and from Mexico, for equipment development and deployment, and for
set up and monitoring of the demonstration.  We will also pay a 3<sup>rd</sup>
party (LAPEM) to verify our demonstration so the CFE knows that the test is
accurate and completely transparent.  The demonstration will take
approximately 30 days, and 5 staff members will be assigned for the
demonstration.
We
are providing premiums and perks to our contributors.<span>  They range from our automotive product, EQ Mileage Booster in
a 12 pack, to a tour of one of the power plants in Mexico, along with
accommodations and a whale watching tour.
The
Impact
Using
our unique EQ products in power plants in Mexico and other countries will
have a global impact. By lowering emissions
in these facilities by at least 30%, we will be improving air quality and the
environment, giving all living things a better, healthier life.  Based on the current projections, 7 million people
lose their lives each year due to pollution. We have the opportunity to save over 2 million
of those people each year by simply reducing the amount of smoke and emissions
from Power Plants around the world.   Leaving the planet a cleaner, safer
place for our children and those that come long after we are gone is our goal
at EnergyQuest.  EQ is only one way to help with the massive problem of creating
a cleaner, safer environment.  So if helping EQ is not your thing, please
find something that is unique and needs your support to help make Planet Earth
a better place to live.
Risks
&amp
Our
biggest challenge is convincing people and organizations that they should be
concerned about the environmental crisis that we have created over the last
century.  Massive pollution and global warming affects everyone, and it’s
time everyone pitched in.  Marketing our product to individuals who can
only change one vehicle at a time has been difficult, but marketing and selling our product to a
Government agency, CFE, that has thousands of power plants across Mexico is an achievement that will make a difference globally.
During
the last election in Mexico, the CFE and Mexican Government officials were
elected by the Green Party, which seeks to improve the quality of life for
those in Mexico.  It also doesn’t hurt that by using our EQ additive in
the fuel that operates the power plants, there will be a substantial financial
savings to the CFE and the Government.  By using our unique EQ product, the
CFE will use less fuel and have less maintenance issues on their equipment,
which brings them even greater savings.
Other
Ways You Can Help
If
you don’t believe in this campaign, please don’t just sit by and watch.
Find something you believe in that will help the environment and slow down or
change the destruction we are creating.  Do your part to help.
Use
the Indiegogo share tools, tell someone you know about us and the ways people
can help SAVE THE ENVIRONMENT.
Thank
you for visiting/contributing to any effort that provides clean air and a
better life for our children.

The EcoThermal Filter System is a combination of a patented stainless steel grease filter with a 100% copper heat exchanger inside.

When a cook line is running all the heat generated is waste heat that gets pulled into the hood and out into the environment. The Eco Thermal Filters replace the standard grease filters and captures the heat that is getting wasted. A portion of the ground water entering the restaurant is diverted through the EcoThermal Filters and then gets pre heated by the captured heat. The Eco Thermal Filters can pre heat ground water up to an average of 125 degrees.

EcoThermal Filters was formed in 2014 to bring this patented technology that we had been working on in conduction with the manufacturing company to market. After roughly 18 months of redesigns and testing we are ready to launch into the marketplace.

It is the goal of the EcoThermal Filters team to bring this product to as many full service restaurants, schools, universities and prisons, anywhere that has a full service kitchen that uses dishes across the entire country and globally.
The EcoThermal Filters are 100% made and manufactured in the USA by a 100% union 4th generation family owned business. The EcoThermal Filter System is installed by certified ETF union installers.

The Eco Thermal Filter System shall create manufacturing jobs, create union plumbing jobs, save restaurant owners thousands per year on their energy bills, and also reduce the Green House Gas omissions every time a cook line is turned on, helping to save the environment.

By receiving contributions from caring people like you, it will allow us to proceed and grow and expand into new territories with the EcoThermal Filter System and fast track the rate of growth so we can minimize the hazardous effect that is being generated by the standard grease filters. The funds shall also help us to continue to educate owners of the overall impact that wasted heat has on the environment as well as continue to support our local charities.

The EcoThermal Filters has been endorsed by The Green Restaurant Association, The Massachusetts Restaurant Association, The Rhode Island Restaurant Association, The City Of Boston and major utility companies to name a few. The Eco Thermal Filter system is also supported by The Alliance To Save Energy.

As a contributor to this campaign, every person shall receive an authentic signed certificate from EcoThermal Filters in which they shall be able to show their children that they have played their part in helping to create a better, healthier, cleaner environment for them and have made a difference to global warming.
Please help us achieve this goal and every little bit helps, if it is only directing a restaurant owner to our website then you have played your part.
To Future success and sustainability.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
The Problem:
Bees are in trouble, and so are we.
Since the early years of this
century, bee populations have been declining in unprecedented numbers. While
historical stressors like weather, parasites, and disease may play a role, the
loss of healthy habitat and widespread use of poisons called
neonicotinoids"" are playing a role that is increasingly difficult to
deny.
<i style=""background-color: initial
<i style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
Neonicotinoids, or “neonics” for
short, are a group of synthetic neurotoxin pesticides. Since the introduction
of neonics as chemical pesticides, bee populations have plummeted. In spite of the myriad scientific studies tying
neonics to bee decline, they are still present in the majority of plants sold
in the United States, as well as many seeds and planting soils.
And this catastrophic loss of bees has severe implications not only in terms of
biodiversity, but also for us. Neonicotinoids have been tied to birth defects
and neurological disorders, as well as water pollution and loss of food
security. Bees pollinate over $20 billion of U.S. crops every year (which means
that you can thank a bee for every third bite of food that you take). If we keep
losing bees, both human and animal food supply is at serious risk. No bees, no
food.
Bees are like the storied canary in
the coal mine
column2: their death tells us that our shared environment has become

column1: toxic. But unlike the miners who fled the mine when their canaries died, we
cannot flee, for we—like the bees—live in this mine: it is our global
environment.
The Solution: Bee Safe Boulder

Bee Safe Boulder is committed to enacting change in Boulder County and beyond through community, education, and collaboration.

Here are just a few of the projects that we are currently working on:
<ul>
• Organizing community outreach events around Boulder County to train and mobilize volunteers to make their own neighborhoods bee-safe.
• Partnering with local environmental organizations and student clubs to organize solution-oriented, hands-on youth events and train the next generation of environmental activists.

• Reaching out to local schools and school districts, Boulder Housing Partners, retirement communities, and homeowners associations to organize a major academic conference looking at issues revolving around pesticide-use to take place at the University of Colorado at Boulder in the fall.
• Creating outreach tools and resources that can be used by community organizers to create bee safe chapters all over the nation.

We want to have the biggest impact possible in protecting bees and getting people to say ""no"" to neonics. Our methods have been proven effective over the past year, and we are excited to continue building our organization! Read more about our methods below:
Community

column12: >BSB Co-Founders David Wheeler and Molly Greacen standing with Greacen's beehive in Boulder's first bee safe neighborhood

column1: One of BSB's main focuses is on
creating ""Bee Safe Neighborhoods."" Based on the protocol created by
the Living Systems Institute (Golden, CO) a Bee Safe Neighborhood is a
neighborhood where at least 75 contiguous households pledge not to use
neonicotinoids. This elegant simplicity can have far-reaching effects,
city-wide, state-wide, and even nation-wide.
We founded BSB in the spring of 2014,
inspired by the ""buzz"" surrounding the news of our neighborhood
becoming the first ever Bee Safe Neighborhood, canvassing to get around 200
households to pledge to not use neonicotinoid pesticides, or plants which have
been pre-treated with them, on their lawns and gardens. Over 80% of our
neighbors further pledged not to use ANY synthetic pesticides outside and to
plant bee friendly plants.
In this process, we discovered that celebrating the strength of community is a
powerful means to bring about change. We learned that neighbors talking to
neighbors leads to the kind of communication and education that can bring about
real change.
Education

column7: >Art students at Shining Mountain Waldorf School creating a bee mural for earth day

column1: Working with School Groups:

The youth are our future, and it is of the utmost importance that they realize their vital place in the mission to save the bees. Recently we've done work with several student groups including the Fairview High School Net
Zero Environmental Group in Boulder. These amazing students have spoken at Boulder City Council
and other city-wide events with Bee Safe Boulder, and are remarkable activists for the environment and bees. On Earth Day, we also had the opportunity to send volunteers and
bee-safe materials to elementary schools around Boulder County. We're excited
to expand our educational mission and get more youth involved!

Outreach:

There are now eight official Bee Safe Neighborhoods and
smaller Bee Safe Communities. Around 50 neighborhoods are in process in Boulder
County and other parts of the United States. One of the most impressive things-
all of this was completed in the past year.
Collaboration
Bee Safe Boulder works with businesses, schools, and other government and
private organizations.
<h4><b>Retailers &amp
column2: Businesses:Bee Safe Boulder has secured pledges from local

column1: retailers, landscapers, and lawn care and tree companies to not sell
contaminated plants, bulbs, trees, turf, and topical garden products that
contain neonics, or, if they must sell these products, to label anything that
does contain them.
We have also contacted nurseries and other growers up the wholesale supply line
to secure neonic-free plants for our pledged companies. 33 companies so far
have pledged and are making this transition! Local Colorado growers have jumped
on the bandwagon in response to consumer demand
think about the environment, and about their ability and responsibility to make
important change.
We are empowering citizens to change
their neighborhoods and their cities too! Here is a sticker from a local
business:

column7: >After BSB informed them of the dangers of neonics, McGuckin Hardware put these labels on all plants containing neonicotinoids.

column1:
City Government:

We asked our local Boulder City Council to pass a
Resolution banning the use of neonics on city property: to become a ""Bee
Safe City."" They enthusiastically took up the challenge, and on May 5,
2015, coinciding with the launch of this campaign, Resolution #1159,
A Resolution Concerning the Use of Neonicontinoid Pesticides in the City
of Boulder,"" was passed by a unanimous vote city council.

column12:
>BSB Co-Founder Molly Greacen speaking at City County as Resolution #1159 is passed

Volunteers:

We have over 100 volunteers in Boulder County who are

column1: working restlessly to create Bee Safe neighborhoods, reach out to garden supply
retailers, and otherwise keep this organization successful and buzzing.

Advisory Board:

Bee Safe Boulder collaborated with an advisory
board made up of a variety of educated and productive members. We are working
diligently to be inclusive, organized, energetic, and intelligent about how to
tackle the various obstacles that we meet on our journey to a bee-safe city.

Partners:

BSB also partners with a variety of both local and
national organizations, including Boulder Rights of Nature, Beyond Pesticides,
the Sierra Club, Friends of the Earth, Beyond Toxics, the Xerces Society, and
both the Boulder County and Colorado Beekeepers Associations, to work toward
elimination in of neonics and other pesticide use.
What We Need:
Bee Safe Boulder needs to raise
$25,000, one dollar for each species of bee, in order to hire a part-time
community and volunteer organizer, who can help us continue our critical work
with local businesses in Boulder County, continue our outreach efforts, and
fund special projects, such as those mentioned below. With your help, we will
make not only Boulder, but the whole nation bee safe.
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
Bee Safe Boulder has created a
national conversation about changing pesticide use on lawns and gardens in this
country.  We have established a new path to a bright future, but we cannot
do it alone anymore.
Donate today to make the movement
move and #beethechange.

","The Problem:
Bees are in trouble, and so are we.
Since the early years of this
century, bee populations have been declining in unprecedented numbers. While
historical stressors like weather, parasites, and disease may play a role, the
loss of healthy habitat and widespread use of poisons called
neonicotinoids"" are playing a role that is increasingly difficult to
deny.
Retrieved June 10,2015 from http://www.vox.com/2015/5/13/8602301/honeybees-...
Neonicotinoids, or “neonics” for
short, are a group of synthetic neurotoxin pesticides. Since the introduction
of neonics as chemical pesticides, bee populations have plummeted. In spite of the myriad scientific studies tying
neonics to bee decline, they are still present in the majority of plants sold
in the United States, as well as many seeds and planting soils.
And this catastrophic loss of bees has severe implications not only in terms of
biodiversity, but also for us. Neonicotinoids have been tied to birth defects
and neurological disorders, as well as water pollution and loss of food
security. Bees pollinate over $20 billion of U.S. crops every year (which means
that you can thank a bee for every third bite of food that you take). If we keep
losing bees, both human and animal food supply is at serious risk. No bees, no
food.
Bees are like the storied canary in
the coal mine
column2: their death tells us that our shared environment has become

column1: toxic. But unlike the miners who fled the mine when their canaries died, we
cannot flee, for we—like the bees—live in this mine: it is our global
environment.
The Solution: Bee Safe Boulder
Bee Safe Boulder is committed to enacting change in Boulder County and beyond through community, education, and collaboration. Here are just a few of the projects that we are currently working on:
Organizing community outreach events around Boulder County to train and mobilize volunteers to make their own neighborhoods bee-safe.
Partnering with local environmental organizations and student clubs to organize solution-oriented, hands-on youth events and train the next generation of environmental activists.

Reaching out to local schools and school districts, Boulder Housing Partners, retirement communities, and homeowners associations to organize a major academic conference looking at issues revolving around pesticide-use to take place at the University of Colorado at Boulder in the fall.
Creating outreach tools and resources that can be used by community organizers to create bee safe chapters all over the nation.

We want to have the biggest impact possible in protecting bees and getting people to say ""no"" to neonics. Our methods have been proven effective over the past year, and we are excited to continue building our organization! Read more about our methods below:
Community

In this process, we discovered that celebrating the strength of community is a

Welcome to the future of mas energy storage.

Man has never been able to store large amounts of energy. Our attempts at batteries have in the main been small scale, inefficient, expensive and environmentally damaging.

In
2015 Bill Gates said that the biggest barrier to mankind's future development
was our inability to store energy derived from sustainable and renewable
sources. And Bill does get a lot of things right.
Today Sorrel Technology has the solution that will change the world and change the world for the better.

The Sorrel heat battery can store huge amounts of energy, produced from renewable sources such as solar thermal or wind, for days, weeks or even months. And by huge amounts of energy, we are talking about enough energy to power a town for several days without being recharged. 

Think about that, renewable energy captured and stored, and only used when it is needed. Not like now where energy can only be used straight away. Think of how much energy we waste right now and then think what the ability to store energy achieves.

Suddenly, renewable sources become realistic energy sources
column2:
no sun, no wind, no problem, as we like to say.

And renewable energy sources are environmentally friendly sources. Think about that. No more fossil fuels being burnt to keep us warm or to cook our dinners. Just the safe, non-polluting energy of the sun, or wind, powering our towns and cities now and way, way into the future. 

Infinite energy, stored safely, powering our lives forever. Is that worth getting excited about?

column1: It's efficient too. The Sorrel Heat Battery uses innovative solid-state heat transfer
technology to release the stored heat to either create steam or to heat gases, which in turn drive turbines, which generate electricity in the way electricity has been generated for generations.
column5: >Suddenly, the Sorrel heat battery makes renewable energy sources like wind and solar

column1: reliable, and reliability is what makes the difference to generating power. The world has just changed and changed for the better.
We need your help.
To continue the development of the Sorrel Heat Battery we are looking for
funding totalling $650,000.  We have already constructed a third generation
large scale heat battery for power generating plants, which proves the concept works and works amazingly well.  We have also had the technology looked at by

independent experts.

We want to refine and improve the efficiency and the practicality of the Sorrel Heat Battery. We want to build a new generation of power stations, based on solar thermal collecting points and a battery of Sorrel heat batteries, storing enough energy to power your town or city. This is the start, new ideas, new concepts are being developed which will mean the heat battery will become the core of all energy provision and creation in the future.
Such is the impact of the Sorrel Heat Battery that we believe those involved
will be making history - helping to create the power source of the future.
To
celebrate this we have created a number of exclusive perks for our donors,
ranging from a simple pin badge, through an elegant button badge in enamel of
the Sorrel logo, through to two laser etched perspex display awards, one
containing metal from one of the cores of an early Sorrel Heat Battery
prototype.
The impact.
The
Sorrel Heat Battery is the beginning of a revolution in the way mankind creates,
stores and uses energy and power. It makes renewables such as solar and wind
energy truly viable long-term power sources by providing the ability to store available
energy for very long periods of time until it is needed. No wind, no sun, no
problem.
This
is a genuinely world-changing technology. Get excited and get involved.
Risks and challenges.
The
Sorrel Heat Battery has been in development for over six years. The technology
has been tried, tested and is thoroughly proven.
Our biggest challenge now is to make the Sorrel Heat Battery available
to everyone. We want to avoid the possibility of this world-changing technology
being suppressed by governments, corporations or individuals with a vested
interest in protecting their fossil fuel reserves, old technology or long term
investments.
Please help us to realise the full potential of this
World-changing technology.
We are crowd funding this next step in the development of new, exciting
applications and we need you to become involved in creating a genuinely clean
energy future for everyone.
Other ways you can help.
We
want everyone to know just how important the Sorrel Heat Battery is going to be
in helping mankind produce all our power from renewable sources.  This is just
the beginning. There is more to the story to come in the next few months.
Please let your friends know about the Sorrel Heat Battery. Please look out for
our tweets and join our Facebook page. The more people who are involved the
quicker we can take this world changing technology to market. Please donate.
Please tell people about us.  Please get involved.
